897077_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	Unless the context otherwise requires, the terms the Company, we, our and us refer to Alamo Group Inc. and its subsidiaries on a consolidated basis.
897077_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	The Company is a leader in the design, manufacture, distribution and service of high quality equipment for right-of-way maintenance and agriculture.
897077_11_ITEM1_P1_S1	The Company s products include tractor-mounted mowing and other vegetation maintenance equipment, street sweepers, excavators, vacuum trucks, snow removal equipment, pothole patchers, zero turn radius mowers, agricultural implements and related aftermarket parts and services.
897077_11_ITEM1_P1_S2	The Company emphasizes high quality, cost-effective products for its customers and strives to develop and market innovative products while constantly monitoring and seeking to contain its manufacturing and overhead costs.
897077_11_ITEM1_P1_S3	The Company has a long-standing strategy of supplementing its internal growth through acquisitions of businesses or product lines that currently complement, command, or have the potential to achieve a meaningful share of their niche markets.
897077_11_ITEM1_P1_S4	The Company has approximately 2,300 employees and operates a total of eighteen plants in North America, Europe and Australia.
897077_11_ITEM1_P1_S5	The Company sells its products primarily through a network of independent dealers and distributors, governmental end-users, related independent contractors, as well as to the agricultural and commercial turf markets.
897077_11_ITEM1_P1_S6	The Company operates primarily in the United States, England, France, Canada and Australia.
897077_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	The predecessor corporation to Alamo Group Inc. was incorporated in the State of Texas in 1969, as a successor to a business that began selling mowing equipment in 1955, and Alamo Group Inc. was reincorporated in the State of Delaware in 1987.
897077_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	Since its founding in 1969, the Company has focused on satisfying customer needs through geographic market expansion, product development and refinement, and selected acquisitions.
897077_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	The Company s first products were based on rotary cutting technology.
897077_11_ITEM1_P4_S1	Through acquisitions, the Company added flail cutting technology in 1983 and sickle-bar cutting technology in 1984.
897077_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Company added to its presence in the industrial and governmental vegetation markets with the acquisition of Tiger Corporation ( Tiger ) in late 1994.
897077_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Company entered the agricultural mowing markets in 1986 with the acquisition of Rhino Products Inc. ( Rhino ) , a leading manufacturer in this field.
897077_11_ITEM1_P6_S1	With this acquisition, the Company embarked on a strategy to increase the Rhino dealer distribution network during a period of industry contraction.
897077_11_ITEM1_P6_S2	The addition of M W Gear Company ( M W ) in early 1995 allowed the Company to enter into the manufacturing and distribution of tillage equipment, which complements the Rhino distribution network.
897077_11_ITEM1_P6_S3	M W has been integrated into the agricultural marketing group, utilizing the same sales force to cross sell Rhino and M W products.
897077_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	In 1991, the Company began its international expansion with the acquisition of McConnel Ltd .
897077_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	( McConnel ) , a United Kingdom ( U.K. ) manufacturer of vegetation maintenance equipment, principally hydraulic boom-mounted hedge and grass cutters and related parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P7_S2	( Bomford ) , also a U.K. company, was acquired in 1993.
897077_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	Bomford is a manufacturer of heavy-duty, tractor-mounted grass and hedge mowing equipment.
897077_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	McConnel and Bomford sell their products to dealers and distributors through their respective sales forces.
897077_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	In 1994, the Company acquired Signalisation Moderne Autoroutiere S.A .
897077_11_ITEM1_P9_S1	( SMA ) located in Orleans, France.
897077_11_ITEM1_P9_S2	SMA manufactures and sells principally a line of heavy-duty, tractor-mounted grass and hedge mowing equipment and associated replacement parts primarily to departments of the French government.
897077_11_ITEM1_P9_S3	This acquisition, along with the acquisitions of Forges Gorce, a flail blade manufacturer in France, in 1996 and Rousseau Holdings S.A. ( Rousseau ), a leading French manufacturer of hedge and verge mowers, in 2004, when combined with McConnel and Bomford, has made the Company one of the largest manufacturers in the European market for the kind of equipment sold by the Company.
897077_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	In 1995, the Company expanded its business in the agricultural market with the acquisition of Herschel Corporation ( Herschel ) , a leading manufacturer and distributor of aftermarket farm equipment replacement and wear parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	In 2000, the Company acquired Schwarze Industries, Inc .
897077_11_ITEM1_P11_S1	Schwarze is a manufacturer of a broad range of street sweeping equipment which is sold to governmental agencies and contractors.
897077_11_ITEM1_P11_S2	The Company believes the Schwarze sweeper products fit the Company s strategy of identifying product offerings with brand recognition in the industrial markets the Company serves.
897077_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	In 2004, the Company purchased the pothole patcher from Wildcat Manufacturing, Inc.
897077_11_ITEM1_P12_S1	The product line was merged into the Schwarze operation and is complementary to its current product offerings.
897077_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	In 2000, the Company purchased the product line and associated assets of Twose of Tiverton Ltd.
897077_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	( Twose ) in the U.K. and incorporated its production into the existing facilities at McConnel and Bomford while maintaining its own sales force and dealer distribution network.
897077_11_ITEM1_P13_S2	Twose was a small regional manufacturer of power arm flail mowers and parts, as well as harrows and rollers, which strengthened the Company s market leadership position in the U.K.
897077_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	In 2000, the Company acquired Schulte Industries Ltd. and its related entities ( Schulte ) .
897077_11_ITEM1_P14_S1	Schulte is a Canadian manufacturer of mechanical rotary mowers, snow blowers, and rock removal equipment.
897077_11_ITEM1_P14_S2	Schulte strengthened the Company s Canadian presence in both marketing and manufacturing.
897077_11_ITEM1_P14_S3	It also expanded the Company s range of large, heavy-duty rotary mowers.
897077_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	In 2001, the Company acquired all of the assets of SMC Corporation ( SMC ).
897077_11_ITEM1_P15_S1	SMC manufactures front-end loaders and backhoes principally for Original Equipment Manufacturer ( OEM ) customers and its own SMC brand.
897077_11_ITEM1_P15_S2	This acquisition expanded the product range of our agricultural division by branding a line of loaders for Rhino .
897077_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	In 2002, the Company purchased inventory, fixed assets and certain other assets of Valu-Bilt Tractor Parts ( Valu-Bilt ) , a subsidiary of Quality Stores, Inc., located in Des Moines, Iowa.
897077_11_ITEM1_P16_S1	Valu-Bilt is a distributor of new, used and rebuilt tractor parts and other agricultural spare and wear parts sold directly to customers through its catalog and the internet and on a wholesale basis to dealers.
897077_11_ITEM1_P16_S2	Subsequent to the purchase, the operations of Valu-Bilt in Des Moines, Iowa, were consolidated into the Company s Herschel facility in Indianola, Iowa.
897077_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	In 2002, the Company purchased substantially all of the assets of Faucheux Industries S.A. ( Faucheux ) , a leading French manufacturer of front-end loaders and attachments.
897077_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	The Company acquired Faucheux out of administration, a form of bankruptcy in France.
897077_11_ITEM1_P17_S2	This acquisition broadened the range of our agricultural implements offered in the French.
897077_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	In 2005, the Company, through its European subsidiary Alamo Group (EUR) Ltd., acquired 100% of the issued and outstanding stock of Spearhead Machinery Limited ( Spearhead ) and subsequently merged its manufacturing operations into Bomford s facility.
897077_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	Spearhead manufactures a range of tractor-mounted vegetation maintenance equipment, including reach mowers, flail mowers and rotary cutters.
897077_11_ITEM1_P19_S1	This acquisition extended our product lines and market coverage in Europe.
897077_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	In early 2006, the Company purchased substantially all of the assets of the Gradall excavator business ( Gradall ) of JLG Industries, Inc. including their manufacturing plant in New Philadelphia, Ohio.
897077_11_ITEM1_P20_S1	Gradall is a leading manufacturer of both wheeled and crawler telescopic excavators in North America.
897077_11_ITEM1_P20_S2	This acquisition enhanced our Industrial Division product offering sold to governmental buyers and related contractors for maintenance along right-of-ways.
897077_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	In 2006, the Company purchased the vacuum truck and sweeper lines of Clean Earth Environmental Group, LLC and Clean Earth Kentucky, LLC (collectively referred to as VacAll ) .
897077_11_ITEM1_P21_S1	This includes the product lines, inventory and certain other assets that relate to this business.
897077_11_ITEM1_P21_S2	The production of the vacuum truck line was moved to the Gradall facility in New Philadelphia, Ohio.
897077_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	In, 2006, the Company acquired 100% of the ownership interests in Nite-Hawk Sweepers LLC ( Nite-Hawk ) , a manufacturer of truck mounted sweeping equipment primarily for the contract sweeping market, which expanded its presence in that market and complements its Schwarze sweeper line.
897077_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	On March 6, 2007, the Company purchased Henke Manufacturing Corporation ( Henke ) , a manufacturer of specialty snow removal attachments.
897077_11_ITEM1_P23_S1	Henke s products are mounted on both heavy industrial equipment and medium to heavy-duty trucks.
897077_11_ITEM1_P23_S2	The primary end-users are governmental agencies, related contractors and other industrial users.
897077_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	On May 30, 2008, the Company acquired Rivard Developpement S.A.S. ( Rivard ) , a leading French manufacturer of vacuum trucks, high pressure cleaning systems and trenchers.
897077_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	The acquisition broadened the Company s product offering to its customers in Europe and other markets we serve.
897077_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	On October 22, 2009, the Company acquired substantially all the assets of Bush Hog, LLC.
897077_11_ITEM1_P25_S1	( Bush Hog ) , a leading agricultural equipment manufacturer of rotary cutters, finishing mowers, zero turn radius mowers ( ZTRs ), front-end loaders, backhoes, landscape equipment and a variety of other implements.
897077_11_ITEM1_P25_S2	This acquisition, combined with the Company s existing range of agricultural mowers, created one of the largest manufacturers of agricultural mowers in the world.
897077_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	The Company believes that within the U.S. it is a leading supplier to governmental markets, a major supplier in the U.S. agricultural market, and one of the largest suppliers in the European market for its niche product offerings.
897077_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	The Company s products are sold through the Company s various marketing organizations and extensive worldwide dealer and distributor networks under the Alamo Industrial , Terrain King , Tiger , Gradall , VacAll , Schwarze , Nite-Hawk , Henke , Bush Hog , Rhino , Earthmaster , M W , SMC , Herschel , Valu-Bilt , Fuerst , Schulte , McConnel , Bomford , Spearhead , Twose , SMA , Forges Gorce , Faucheux , Rousseau and Rivard trademarks as well as other trademarks and trade names.
897077_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	Alamo Industrial equipment is principally sold through independent dealers to governmental end-users, related independent contractors and, to a lesser extent, utility and other dealers serving right-of-way maintenance operators and other applications in the U.S. and other countries.
897077_11_ITEM1_P27_S1	Governmental agencies and contractors that perform services for such agencies purchase primarily hydraulically-powered, tractor-mounted mowers, including boom-mounted mowers, other types of cutters and replacement parts for heavy-duty, intensive use applications, including maintenance around highway, airport, recreational and other public areas.
897077_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	A portion of Alamo Industrial s sales includes tractors, which are not manufactured by Alamo Industrial.
897077_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	Tiger equipment includes heavy-duty, tractor- and truck-mounted mowing and vegetation maintenance equipment and replacement parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	Tiger sells to state, county and local governmental entities and related contractors, primarily through a network of independent dealers.
897077_11_ITEM1_P30_S1	Tiger s dealer distribution network is independent of Alamo Industrial s dealer distribution network.
897077_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	A portion of Tiger s sales includes tractors, which are not manufactured by Tiger.
897077_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	Schwarze equipment includes air, mechanical broom, and regenerative air sweepers, pothole patchers and replacement parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	Schwarze sells its products primarily to governmental agencies and independent contractors, either directly or through its independent dealer network.
897077_11_ITEM1_P33_S1	A portion of Schwarze s sales includes chassis which are not manufactured by Schwarze .
897077_11_ITEM1_P33_S2	The Company believes that Schwarze complements Alamo Industrial because the dealer and/or end-user for both products in many cases are the same .
897077_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	Gradall produces a range of models based on high-pressure hydraulic telescoping booms which are sold through dealers primarily to governmental agencies, contractors and to a lesser extent the mining industry, steel mills and other specialty applications in the U.S. and other countries.
897077_11_ITEM1_P34_S1	Many of these products are designed for excavation, grading, shaping and similar tasks involved in land clearing, road building or maintenance.
897077_11_ITEM1_P34_S2	These products are available mounted on various types of undercarriages: wheels for full-speed highway travel, wheels for on/off road use, and crawlers.
897077_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	VacAll produces catch basin cleaners and roadway debris vacuum systems.
897077_11_ITEM1_P35_S1	These units are powerful and versatile with uses including, but not limited to, removal of wet and dry debris, spill elimination, and cleaning of sludge beds.
897077_11_ITEM1_P35_S2	VacAll also offers a line of sewer cleaners.
897077_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	VacAll products are primarily sold through dealers to industrial and commercial contractors as well as governmental agencies.
897077_11_ITEM1_P36_S1	A portion of VacAll s sales includes chassis which are not manufactured by the Company.
897077_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	Nite-Hawk manufactures parking lot sweepers with its unique and innovative hydraulic design.
897077_11_ITEM1_P37_S1	By eliminating the auxiliary engine, Nite-Hawk sweepers have proven to be fuel-efficient, environmentally conscious, and cost-effective to operate.
897077_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	Nite-Hawk focuses mainly on and sells direct to parking lot contractors.
897077_11_ITEM1_P38_S1	A portion of Nite-Hawk s sales includes chassis which are not manufactured by Nite-Hawk .
897077_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	Henke designs and manufactures snow plows and heavy-duty snow removal equipment, hitches and attachments for trucks, loaders and graders sold primarily through independent truck and industrial dealers.
897077_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	Henke s primary end-users are governmental agencies, related contractors and other industrial users.
897077_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	Bush Hog, Rhino and M W equipment is generally sold to farmers and ranchers to clear brush, maintain pastures and unused farmland, shred crops and till fields and for haymaking.
897077_11_ITEM1_P41_S1	It is also sold to other customers, such as mowing contractors and construction contractors, for non-agricultural purposes.
897077_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	Bush Hog and Rhino equipment consists principally of a comprehensive line of tractor-powered equipment, including rotary cutters, finishing mowers, flail mowers, disc mowers, ZTR ride-on mowers, front-end loaders, backhoes, rotary tillers, posthole diggers, scraper blades and replacement parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P42_S1	This equipment is primarily sold through farm equipment dealers, as well as original equipment manufacturers ( OEMs ) and other distributors.
897077_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	SMC equipment includes a broad line of front-end loaders and backhoes that fit many tractors on the market today.
897077_11_ITEM1_P43_S1	The products are sold to OEMs and, as Bush Hog and Rhino branded equipment.
897077_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	Herschel/Valu-Bilt aftermarket replacement parts are sold for many types of farm equipment and tractors and certain types of mowing and construction equipment.
897077_11_ITEM1_P44_S1	Herschel products include a wide range of cutting parts, plain and hard-faced replacement tillage tools, disc blades and fertilizer application components.
897077_11_ITEM1_P44_S2	Herschel replacement tools and parts are sold throughout the United States, Canada and Mexico to five major customer groups: farm equipment dealers; fleet stores; wholesale distributors; OEMs; and construction equipment dealers.
897077_11_ITEM1_P44_S3	Valu-Bilt complements the Herschel product lines while also expanding the Company s offering of aftermarket agricultural parts and added catalog and internet sales direct to end-users.
897077_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	Schulte equipment includes heavy-duty mechanical rotary mowers, snow blowers, rock removal equipment and related replacement parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P45_S1	Schulte serves both the agricultural and industrial markets primarily in Canada and the U.S. Schulte also sells some of the Company s other product lines in their markets and some of its products through independent distributors throughout the world.
897077_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	McConnel equipment principally includes a broad line of hydraulic, boom-mounted hedge and grass cutters, as well as other tractor attachments and implements such as hydraulic backhoes, cultivators, subsoilers, buckets and other digger implements and related replacement parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P46_S1	McConnel equipment is sold primarily in the U.K., Ireland and France and in other parts of Europe and, to a lesser extent, throughout the world through independent dealers and distributors.
897077_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	Bomford equipment includes hydraulic, boom-mounted hedge and hedgerow cutters, industrial grass mowers, agricultural seedbed preparation cultivators and related replacement parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P47_S1	Bomford equipment is sold to governmental agencies, contractors and agricultural end-users in the U.K., Ireland and France and, to a lesser extent, other countries in Europe, North America, Australia and the Far East.
897077_11_ITEM1_P47_S2	Bomford s sales network is similar to that of McConnel in the U.K. Rhino sells some of Bomford s product line in the U.S.
897077_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	SMA equipment includes hydraulic, boom-mounted hedge and hedgerow cutters and related replacement parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	SMA s principal customers are French local authorities.
897077_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	SMA s product offerings include certain quick-attach boom mowers manufactured by the Company in the U.K. to expand its presence in agricultural dealerships.
897077_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	During the third quarter of 2010, the Company closed and sold its SMA facility located in Orleans, France and production was relocated to the Rousseau manufacturing facility near Lyon, France.
897077_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	Forges Gorce manufactures flail blades which are sold to some of the Company s subsidiaries as well as to other customers.
897077_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	Twose equipment includes light-duty power arm mowers, agricultural implements and related replacement parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P52_S1	Twose products are manufactured at the Company s U.K. facilities.
897077_11_ITEM1_P52_S2	These products are sold through Twose s dealer distribution network in the U.K. and through Faucheux s and other independent distributors internationally.
897077_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	The addition of Spearhead expanded the Company s product lines, particularly rotary cutters, and market coverage in Europe and increased utilization of our existing U.K. manufacturing facilities.
897077_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	Faucheux equipment includes front-end loaders, backhoes, attachments and related parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P55_S0	Historically, the majority of Faucheux sales have been in France, but the Company has expanded market coverage to other countries.
897077_11_ITEM1_P56_S0	Rousseau sells hydraulic and mechanical boom mowers, primarily in France through its own sales force and dealer distribution network to mainly agricultural and governmental markets.
897077_11_ITEM1_P56_S1	These products have also been introduced into other markets outside of France.
897077_11_ITEM1_P57_S0	Rivard manufactures vacuum trucks, high pressure cleaning systems and trenchers.
897077_11_ITEM1_P57_S1	Rivard s equipment is primarily sold in France and certain other markets, mainly in Europe and North Africa, to governmental entities and related contractors.
897077_11_ITEM1_P57_S2	It also complements our product offerings in North America.
897077_11_ITEM1_P58_S0	In addition to the sales of Herschel replacement parts, the Company derives a significant portion of its revenues from sales of replacement parts for each of its wholegoods lines.
897077_11_ITEM1_P58_S1	Replacement parts represented approximately 23%, 26% and 27% of the Company s total sales for the years ended December 31, 2008, 2009 and 2010, respectively.
897077_11_ITEM1_P58_S2	The percentage increase in 2010 was mainly from a change in sales mix between wholegoods and parts.
897077_11_ITEM1_P58_S3	Proprietary replacement parts generally are more profitable and less cyclical than wholegoods.
897077_11_ITEM1_P59_S0	While the Company believes that the end-users of its products evaluate their purchases on the basis of price, reputation and product quality, such purchases are also based on a dealer s service, support of and loyalty to the dealer based on previous purchase experiences, as well as other factors such as product and replacement part availability.
897077_11_ITEM1_P60_S0	The Company s ability to provide innovative responses to customer needs, to develop and manufacture new products, and to enhance existing product lines is important to its success.
897077_11_ITEM1_P61_S0	The Company continually conducts research and development activities in an effort to improve existing products and develop new products.
897077_11_ITEM1_P61_S1	As of December 31, 2010, the Company employed 136 people in its various engineering departments, 60 of whom are degreed engineers and the balance of whom are support staff.
897077_11_ITEM1_P61_S2	Amounts expended on research and development activities were approximately $5,774,000 in 2010, $4,762,000 in 2009 and $5,443,000 in 2008.
897077_11_ITEM1_P61_S3	As a percentage of sales, research and development was approximately 1.1% in 2010 and 1.0% in 2009 and 2008, and is expected to continue at similar levels in 2011.
897077_11_ITEM1_P62_S0	Seasonality The Company s sales, both product and spare parts, are generally higher in the second and third quarters of the year, because a substantial number of the Company s products are used for maintenance activities such as vegetation maintenance, highway right-of-way maintenance, construction, and street and parking lot sweeping.
897077_11_ITEM1_P62_S1	Usage of this equipment is lower in harsh weather.
897077_11_ITEM1_P63_S0	The Company utilizes a rolling twelve-month sales forecast provided by the Company s marketing departments and order backlog in order to develop a production plan for its manufacturing facilities.
897077_11_ITEM1_P63_S1	In addition, many of the Company s marketing departments attempt to equalize demand for products throughout the calendar year by offering seasonal sales programs which may provide additional incentives, including discounts and extended payment terms, under these programs.
897077_11_ITEM1_P64_S0	The Company s products are sold in highly competitive markets throughout the world.
897077_11_ITEM1_P64_S1	The principal competitive factors are price, quality, availability, service and reputation.
897077_11_ITEM1_P64_S2	The Company competes with several large national and international companies that offer a broad range of equipment and replacement parts, as well as with numerous small, privately-held manufacturers and suppliers of a limited number of products, mainly on a regional basis.
897077_11_ITEM1_P64_S3	Some of the Company s competitors are significantly larger than the Company and have substantially greater financial and other resources at their disposal.
897077_11_ITEM1_P64_S4	The Company believes that it is able to compete successfully in its markets by effectively managing its manufacturing costs, offering high quality products, developing and designing innovative products and, to some extent, avoiding direct competition with significantly larger potential competitors.
897077_11_ITEM1_P64_S5	There can be no assurance that the Company s competitors will not substantially increase the resources devoted to the development and marketing of products competitive with the Company s products or that new competitors with greater resources will not enter the Company s markets.
897077_11_ITEM1_P65_S0	As of December 31, 2010, the Company had unfilled customer orders of $97,616,000 compared to $71,333,000 at December 31, 2009.
897077_11_ITEM1_P65_S1	The 37% increase was primarily due to the positive impact of improved agricultural market conditions on Bush Hog and Rhino backlogs.
897077_11_ITEM1_P66_S0	The Company continues to be affected by soft market conditions in its Industrial and European divisions due to the downturn in the global economy.
897077_11_ITEM1_P66_S1	Management expects that substantially all of the Company s backlog as of December 31, 2010 will be shipped during fiscal year 2011.
897077_11_ITEM1_P67_S0	The amount of unfilled orders at a particular time is affected by a number of factors, including manufacturing and shipping schedules which, in most instances, are dependent on the Company s seasonal sales programs and the requirements of its customers.
897077_11_ITEM1_P67_S1	Certain of the Company s orders are subject to cancellation at any time before shipment; therefore, a comparison of unfilled orders from period to period is not necessarily meaningful and may not be indicative of future actual shipments.
897077_11_ITEM1_P68_S0	No single customer is responsible for 10% or more of the aggregate revenue of the Company.
897077_11_ITEM1_P69_S0	Sources of Supply The principal raw materials used by the Company include steel, other metal components and hydraulic tubing.
897077_11_ITEM1_P69_S1	During 2010, the raw materials needed by the Company were available from a variety of sources in adequate quantities and at prevailing market prices.
897077_11_ITEM1_P69_S2	No one supplier is responsible for supplying more than 10% of the principal raw materials used by the Company.
897077_11_ITEM1_P70_S0	While the Company manufactures many of the parts for its products, a significant percentage of parts, including most drivelines, gearboxes, industrial engines, and hydraulic components, are purchased from outside suppliers which manufacture to the Company s specifications.
897077_11_ITEM1_P70_S1	In addition, the Company, through its subsidiaries, purchases tractors and truck chassis as a number of the Company s products are mounted and shipped with a tractor or truck chassis.
897077_11_ITEM1_P70_S2	Tractors and truck chassis are generally available, but some delays in receiving tractors or truck chassis can occur throughout the year.
897077_11_ITEM1_P71_S0	U.S. industrial engines over 175 horsepower, which are used in certain of the Company s products, manufactured after January 1, 2011 will be required to meet Tier 4i federal guidelines for emission controls, which will increase the cost of our units and our working capital requirements.
897077_11_ITEM1_P71_S1	Other jurisdictions, particularly in Europe, have already implemented similar requirements.
897077_11_ITEM1_P72_S0	The Company sources its purchased goods from international and domestic suppliers.
897077_11_ITEM1_P72_S1	No single supplier is responsible for supplying more than 10% of the purchased goods used by the Company.
897077_11_ITEM1_P73_S0	The Company owns various U.S. and international patents.
897077_11_ITEM1_P73_S1	While the Company considers its patents to be advantageous to its business, it is not dependent on any single patent or group of patents.
897077_11_ITEM1_P73_S2	The Company amortized approximately $79,000 in patents and trademarks relating to the industrial segment.
897077_11_ITEM1_P73_S3	The Company wrote off $224,000 in older patents which the Company believes no longer provide a competitive advantage.
897077_11_ITEM1_P73_S4	The net book value of the patents and trademarks was $5,500,000 and $5,803,000 as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
897077_11_ITEM1_P74_S0	Products manufactured by the Company are advertised and sold under numerous trademarks.
897077_11_ITEM1_P74_S1	Alamo Industrial , Terrain King , Gradall , VacAll , Henke , Bush Hog , Rhino , Earthmaster , McConnel , Bomford , SMA , Schwarze , Nite-Hawk , Tiger , Schulte , Forges Gorce , Twose , Faucheux , Herschel , Valu-Bilt , Rivard , Rousseau and Spearhead trademarks are the primary marks for the Company s products.
897077_11_ITEM1_P74_S2	The Company also owns other trademarks which it uses to a lesser extent, such as M W , SMC , Fuerst , Triumph , Mott , Turner , and Dandl .
897077_11_ITEM1_P74_S3	Management believes that the Company s trademarks are well known in its markets and are valuable and that their value is increasing with the development of its business.
897077_11_ITEM1_P74_S4	The Company actively protects its trademarks against infringement and believes it has applied for or registered its trademarks in the appropriate jurisdictions.
897077_11_ITEM1_P75_S0	Like other manufacturers, the Company is subject to a broad range of federal, state, local and foreign laws and requirements, including those concerning air emissions, discharges into waterways, and the generation, handling, storage, transportation, treatment and disposal of hazardous substances and waste materials, as well as the remediation of contamination associated with releases of hazardous substances at the Company s facilities and offsite disposal locations, workplace safety and equal employment opportunities.
897077_11_ITEM1_P75_S1	These laws and regulations are constantly changing, and it is impossible to predict with accuracy the effect that changes to such laws and regulations may have on the Company in the future.
897077_11_ITEM1_P76_S0	Like other industrial concerns, the Company s manufacturing operations entail the risk of noncompliance, and there can be no assurance that the Company will not incur material costs or other liabilities as a result thereof.
897077_11_ITEM1_P77_S0	The Company knows that its Indianola, Iowa property is contaminated with chromium which most likely resulted from chrome plating operations which were discontinued before the Company purchased the property.
897077_11_ITEM1_P77_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.
897077_11_ITEM1_P77_S2	The Company voluntarily worked with an environmental consultant and the state of Iowa with respect to these issues and believes it completed its remediation program in June 2006.
897077_11_ITEM1_P77_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_11_ITEM1_P77_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_11_ITEM1_P77_S5	We received a conditional no further action letter in January of 2009.
897077_11_ITEM1_P77_S6	When we demonstrate stable or improving conditions below residential standards by monitoring existing wells, an unconditional no further action letter will be requested.
897077_11_ITEM1_P78_S0	On December 31, 2010, the Company had an environmental reserve in the amount of $1,495,000 related to the acquisition of Gradall s facility in New Philadelphia, Ohio.
897077_11_ITEM1_P78_S1	Three specific remediation projects that were identified prior to the acquisition are in process of remediation with a remaining reserve balance of $30,000.
897077_11_ITEM1_P78_S2	The Company has a reserve of $277,000 concerning a potential asbestos issue that is expected to be remediated over time.
897077_11_ITEM1_P78_S3	The balance of the reserve, $1,188,000, is mainly for potential ground water contamination/remediation that was identified before the acquisition and believed to have been generated by a third party company located near the Gradall facility.
897077_11_ITEM1_P79_S0	The Company knows that Bush Hog s main manufacturing property in Selma, Alabama was contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic compounds which most likely resulted from painting and cleaning operations during the 1960s and 70s.
897077_11_ITEM1_P79_S1	The contaminated areas were primarily in the location of underground storage tanks and underneath the former waste storage area.
897077_11_ITEM1_P79_S2	Under the Asset Purchase Agreement, Bush Hog s prior owner agreed to and has removed the underground storage tanks at its cost and has remedied the identified contamination in accordance with the regulations of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management.
897077_11_ITEM1_P79_S3	An environmental consulting firm was retained by the prior owner and is administering the cleanup and will monitor the sites on an ongoing basis until the remediation program is complete and approved by the applicable authorities.
897077_11_ITEM1_P80_S0	Certain other assets of the Company contain asbestos that may have to be remediated over time.
897077_11_ITEM1_P80_S1	Management has made its best estimate of the cost to remediate these environmental issues.
897077_11_ITEM1_P80_S2	However, such estimates are difficult to determine, including the timing of such costs.
897077_11_ITEM1_P80_S3	The Company believes that any subsequent change in the liability associated with the asbestos removal will not have a material adverse effect on the Company s consolidated financial position or results of operations.

897077_11_ITEM1_P81_S1	A variety of state laws regulate the Company s contractual relationships with its dealers, some of which impose restrictive standards on the relationship between the Company and its dealers, including events of default, grounds for termination, non-renewal of dealer contracts, and equipment repurchase requirements.
897077_11_ITEM1_P81_S2	The Company believes it is currently in material compliance with all such applicable laws and regulations.

897077_11_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements of the Company and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
897077_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	The following tables set forth, for the periods indicated, certain financial data:
897077_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company s net sales in the fiscal year ended December 31, 2010 ( 2010 ) were $524,540,000, an increase of $78,053,000 or 17.5% compared to $446,487,000 for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2009 ( 2009 ).
897077_11_ITEM7_P2_S1	The increase was primarily due to the inclusion of a full year of the results of Bush Hog which was acquired in October 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	North American Industrial sales (net) were $192,379,000 in 2010 compared to $173,905,000 in 2009, an increase of $18,474,000 or 10.6%.
897077_11_ITEM7_P3_S1	The increase resulted from higher sales of replacement parts and, to a lesser extent, a slight improvement in sales of excavator, vacuum truck, sweeper and mowing equipment products.
897077_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	Governmental entities continue to be affected by budget constraints and revenue shortfalls.
897077_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	Compared to 2009, sales to state agencies remained steadier than those to cities and counties.
897077_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	North American Agricultural sales (net) were $173,464,000 in 2010 compared to $92,415,000 in 2009, representing an increase of $81,049,000 or 87.7%.
897077_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	The increase was primarily due to the acquisition of Bush Hog, which contributed $78,030,000 of the increase.
897077_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	The agricultural market was soft during the first six months of 2010 due to the weakness in the overall economy, leading to dealer reluctance to stock farm equipment.
897077_11_ITEM7_P6_S1	During the third quarter of 2010, market conditions reflected some improvement due to increases in commodity prices and growth in farm income.
897077_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	European sales (net) decreased $21,470,000 or 11.9% to $158,697,000 in 2010 compared to $180,167,000 in 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	This decrease was mainly due to soft market conditions caused by the slowdown in the European economy.
897077_11_ITEM7_P7_S2	Specifically, our U.K. units held up better than our French operations, which were responsible for the majority of the decrease.
897077_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	The agricultural market in Europe showed more improvement in 2010 than the governmental market.
897077_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	The European sales in 2010 had a lagging effect from what we saw in the Company s North American markets.
897077_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	Gross margins for 2010 were $116,914,000 (22.3% of net sales) compared to $94,561,000 (21.2% of net sales) in 2009, an increase of $22,353,000.
897077_11_ITEM7_P9_S1	The majority of the increase was due to the acquisition of Bush Hog , which accounts for $20,271,000 of the increase.
897077_11_ITEM7_P9_S2	Increases in the Company s replacement part business supported higher margins as well as improved margin percentages.
897077_11_ITEM7_P9_S3	Margin percentages also improved over 2009 as a result of ongoing cost savings initiatives which helped lower manufacturing costs.
897077_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	Selling, general and administrative expenses ( SG A ) were $86,041,000 (16.4% of net sales) in 2010 compared to $76,100,000 (17.0% of net sales) in 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	The increase of $9,941,000 in SG A in 2010 was due to the acquisition of Bush Hog which added a net increase of $11,799,000.
897077_11_ITEM7_P10_S2	Without Bush Hog expenses in 2010 and 2009 along with acquisition costs related to Bush Hog in 2009, SG A expenses were relatively flat year over year.
897077_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	The Company recorded a $27,689,000 bargain purchase gain during the fourth quarter of 2009 which has since been adjusted to $30,177,000 as a result of retrospective adjustments to the fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed since the date of acquisition.
897077_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	The purchase price consideration was 1,700,000 unregistered shares of Alamo Group stock at a closing price of $16.09 per share plus the assumption of certain liabilities and other considerations.
897077_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	There was no goodwill impairment for 2010 compared to non-cash $14,104,000 impairment in 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P12_S1	In 2009, the Company wrote off the goodwill at Gradall/VacAll and just over 75% of the goodwill at Nite-Hawk in its Industrial Division after performing its required impairment test.
897077_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	Interest expense for 2010 was $3,664,000 compared to $4,766,000 in 2009, a $1,102,000 or a 23.1% decrease.
897077_11_ITEM7_P13_S1	The decrease was due to reduced borrowings in 2010 compared to 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P13_S2	The 2010 interest expense includes $375,000 in amortization of bank fees from the amendment to the Company s revolving credit agreement in November 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P13_S3	In 2009, the Company amortized $63,000 in bank fees relating to the same amendment.
897077_11_ITEM7_P13_S4	Other income net, was $290,000 during 2010 compared to income of $625,000 in 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P13_S5	The gains in both 2010 and 2009 are entirely from changes in exchange rates.
897077_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	Provision for Income Taxes was $7,915,000 (27.3% of income before income taxes) for 2010 compared to $12,473,000 (40.1% of income before income taxes) in 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P14_S1	Included in the 2010 tax provision is an $898,000 tax credit related to prior years research and development expenses.
897077_11_ITEM7_P14_S2	The increase in the effective tax rate for 2009 was from increased state taxes in the United States and from the non-deductible tax write-off of goodwill in the Industrial Division.
897077_11_ITEM7_P14_S3	Net Income for 2010 was $21,117,000 compared to $18,633,000 in 2009 due to the factors described above.
897077_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	The Company s net sales in the fiscal year ended December 31, 2009 ( 2009 ) were $446,487,000, a decrease of $110,648,000 or 19.9% compared to $557,135,000 for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2008 ( 2008 ).
897077_11_ITEM7_P15_S1	The decrease was primarily attributable to the general weakness in the worldwide economy which began in the fourth quarter of 2008 and continues to affect the markets the Company serves.
897077_11_ITEM7_P15_S2	The acquisitions of Rivard and Bush Hog were accretive to the Company s sales for 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	North American Industrial sales (net) were $173,905,000 in 2009 compared to $254,787,000 in 2008, an $80,882,000 or 31.7% decrease.

897077_11_ITEM7_P16_S2	Sales to cities and counties remained steadier than those to state agencies.

897077_11_ITEM7_P43_S1	ASU No. 2010-17 recognizes the milestone method as an acceptable revenue recognition method for substantive milestones in research or development transactions.
897077_11_ITEM7_P43_S2	A milestone is substantive when the consideration earned from achievement of the milestone is commensurate with either (a) the vendor s performance to achieve the milestone or (b) the enhancement of the value of the delivered item(s) as a result of a specific outcome resulting from the vendor s performance to achieve the milestone and the consideration earned from the achievement of a milestone relates solely to past performance and is reasonable relative to all of the deliverables and payment terms (including other potential milestone consideration) within the arrangement.

897077_11_ITEM7_P55_S0	Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations are based upon our Consolidated Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ).
897077_11_ITEM7_P55_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
897077_11_ITEM7_P55_S2	Management bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
897077_11_ITEM7_P55_S3	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
897077_11_ITEM7_P56_S0	An accounting policy is deemed to be critical if it requires an accounting estimate to be made based on assumptions about matters that are highly uncertain at the time the estimate is made, and if different estimates that reasonably could have been used, or changes in the accounting estimates that are reasonably likely to occur periodically, could materially impact the financial statements.
897077_11_ITEM7_P56_S1	Management believes the following critical accounting policies reflect its more significant estimates and assumptions used in the preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements.
897077_11_ITEM7_P56_S2	For further information on the critical accounting policies, see Note 1 of our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
897077_11_ITEM7_P57_S0	The Company evaluates the collectability of its accounts receivable based on a combination of factors.
897077_11_ITEM7_P57_S1	In circumstances where it is aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the Company records a specific reserve to reduce the amounts recorded to what it believes will be collected.
897077_11_ITEM7_P57_S2	For all other customers, it recognizes reserves for bad debt based on historical experience of bad debts as a percent of revenues for each business unit, adjusted for relative improvements or deteriorations in the aging and changes in current economic conditions.
897077_11_ITEM7_P58_S0	The Company evaluates all receivables that are over 60 days old and will reserve specifically on a 90-day basis.
897077_11_ITEM7_P59_S0	The Company has a secured interest on most of its wholegoods that each customer purchases.
897077_11_ITEM7_P59_S1	This allows the Company, in times of a difficult economy when the customer is unable to pay or has filed for bankruptcy (usually Chapter 11), to repossess the customer s inventory.
897077_11_ITEM7_P59_S2	This also allows Alamo Group to maintain only a reserve over its cost, which usually represents the margin on the original sales price.
897077_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts balance was $2,852,000 on December 31, 2010, and $2,548,000 on December 31, 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P60_S1	The increase was mainly from the Company s Agricultural operations.
897077_11_ITEM7_P61_S0	On December 31, 2010, the Company had $11,903,000 in reserves for sales discounts compared to $3,803,000 on December 31, 2009 on product shipped to our customers under various promotional programs.
897077_11_ITEM7_P61_S1	The increase was due primarily to increased sales volume of the Company s agricultural products during the pre-season, which runs from September to December of each year with orders shipped through the first quarter of 2011.
897077_11_ITEM7_P62_S0	The Company reviews the reserve quarterly based on analysis made on each program outstanding at the time.
897077_11_ITEM7_P63_S0	The Company bases its reserves on historical data relating to discounts taken by the customer under each program.
897077_11_ITEM7_P63_S1	Historically, between 85% and 95% of the Company s customers who qualify for each program actually take the discount that is available.
897077_11_ITEM7_P64_S0	The Company had a reserve of $7,506,000 on December 31, 2010 and $9,060,000 on December 31, 2009 to cover obsolete and slow moving inventory.
897077_11_ITEM7_P64_S1	The decrease in the reserve was mainly from the Company s U.S. operations, specifically its facilities in Gibson City and Indianola as a result of greater disposals and sales of slow moving and obsolete inventory.
897077_11_ITEM7_P65_S0	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three-year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three-year supply.
897077_11_ITEM7_P65_S1	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_11_ITEM7_P65_S2	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_11_ITEM7_P65_S3	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three-year history has been established.
897077_11_ITEM7_P66_S0	The reserve is reviewed and, if necessary, adjustments are made on a quarterly basis.
897077_11_ITEM7_P66_S1	The Company relies on historical information when available to support its reserve.
897077_11_ITEM7_P66_S2	The Company does not adjust the reserve balance until the inventory is liquidated.
897077_11_ITEM7_P67_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood units and 90 days on parts.
897077_11_ITEM7_P68_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety-day to six-month lag period.
897077_11_ITEM7_P68_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the unit to file a warranty claim.
897077_11_ITEM7_P68_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_11_ITEM7_P68_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.
897077_11_ITEM7_P69_S0	The current liability warranty reserve balance was $5,554,000 on December 31, 2010 and $5,972,000 on December 31, 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P69_S1	The increase came mainly from the acquisition of Bush Hog.
897077_11_ITEM7_P70_S0	Goodwill must be tested for impairment at least annually.
897077_11_ITEM7_P70_S1	In the fourth quarter of each year, or when events and circumstances warrant such a review, the Company tests the goodwill of all of its reporting units for impairment.
897077_11_ITEM7_P70_S2	The goodwill impairment test is determined using a two-step process.
897077_11_ITEM7_P70_S3	The first step is to identify if a potential impairment exists by comparing the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount, including goodwill (Step 1).
897077_11_ITEM7_P70_S4	If the fair value of a reporting unit exceeds its carrying value amount, goodwill of the reporting unit is not considered to have a potential impairment and the second step is not necessary.
897077_11_ITEM7_P70_S5	However, if the carrying amount of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step (Step 2) is performed to determine if goodwill is impaired and to measure the amount of impairment loss to recognize, if any.
897077_11_ITEM7_P70_S6	Step 2 compares the implied fair value of goodwill with the carrying amount of goodwill.
897077_11_ITEM7_P70_S7	If the implied value of goodwill is less than the carrying amount of goodwill, then a charge is recorded to reduce goodwill to the implied goodwill.
897077_11_ITEM7_P71_S0	The implied goodwill is calculated based on a hypothetical purchase price allocation, in that it takes the implied fair value of the reporting unit and allocates such fair value to the fair value of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit.
897077_11_ITEM7_P72_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_11_ITEM7_P72_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_11_ITEM7_P72_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_11_ITEM7_P72_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.
897077_11_ITEM7_P72_S4	The Company believes that the assumptions and estimates used to determine the estimated fair values of each of its reporting units are reasonable.
897077_11_ITEM7_P72_S5	However, different assumptions could materially affect the estimated fair value.
897077_11_ITEM7_P73_S0	As of December 31, 2010, goodwill was $34,073,000, which represents 9% of total assets.
897077_11_ITEM7_P73_S1	The Company recognized no goodwill impairment in 2010.
897077_11_ITEM7_P73_S2	The North American Industrial segment had a goodwill impairment of $14,104,000 in 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7_P73_S3	During the 2010 impairment analysis review, it was noted that even though the Schwarze reporting unit s fair value was above carrying value it was not materially different.
897077_11_ITEM7_P73_S4	On December 31, 2010, there was approximately $6.8 million of goodwill related to the Schwarze reporting unit.
897077_11_ITEM7_P73_S5	This reporting unit would be most likely affected by changes in the Company s assumptions and estimates.
897077_11_ITEM7_P73_S6	The calculation of fair value could increase or decrease depending on changes in the inputs and assumptions used, such as changes in the reporting unit s future growth rates, discount rates, etc.
897077_11_ITEM7_P74_S0	See Note 6 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for more information regarding goodwill.

897077_11_ITEM7A_P2_S0	International Sales A portion of the Company s operations consists of manufacturing and sales activities in international jurisdictions.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The Company primarily manufactures its products in the United States, the U.K., France, Canada and Australia.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P2_S2	The Company sells its products primarily within the markets where the products are produced, but certain of the Company s sales from its U.K. operations are denominated in other European currencies.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P2_S3	As a result, the Company s financials, specifically the value of its foreign assets, could be affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency exchange rates or weak economic conditions in the other markets in which the subsidiaries of the Company distribute their products.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P3_S0	To mitigate the short-term effect of changes in currency exchange rates on the Company s functional currency-based sales, the Company s U.K. subsidiaries regularly enter into foreign exchange forward contracts to hedge over 90% of its future net foreign currency cash receipts over a period of six months.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P3_S1	As of December 31, 2010, the Company had $2,664,000 outstanding in forward exchange contracts related to accounts receivable.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P3_S2	A 15% fluctuation in exchange rates for these currencies would change the fair value by approximately $400,000.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P3_S3	However, since these contracts hedge foreign currency denominated transactions, any change in the fair value of the contracts should be offset by changes in the underlying value of the transaction being hedged.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P4_S0	On December 31, 2010, the fair value of these agreements was in an unfavorable position; therefore, the derivative financial instruments were recorded as a loss of $43,000, which has been recognized in other income (expense), net.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The Company s earnings are affected by fluctuations in the value of the U.S. dollar as compared to foreign currencies, predominantly in European countries, Canada and Australia, as a result of the sale of its products in international markets.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Foreign currency forward contracts in the U.K. are used to hedge against the earnings effects of such fluctuations.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P6_S0	On December 31, 2010, the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would result in a decrease in gross profit of $4,435,000 for the year ended December 31, 2010.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P6_S1	Comparatively, on December 31, 2009, the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have resulted in a decrease in gross profit of approximately $4,891,000 for the year ended December 31, 2009.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P7_S0	This calculation assumes that each exchange rate would change in the same direction relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P7_S1	In addition to the direct effects of changes in exchange rates, which are a changed dollar value of the resulting sales, changes in exchange rates may also affect the volume of sales or the foreign currency sales price as competitors products become more or less attractive.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P7_S2	The Company s sensitivity analysis of the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates does not factor in a potential change in sales levels or local currency prices.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P7_S3	The translation adjustment during 2010 was a loss of $3,659,000.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P8_S0	On December 31, 2010, the British pound closed at .6411 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at .7479 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P8_S1	By comparison, on December 31, 2009, the British pound closed at .6187 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at .6985 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P8_S2	No assurance can be given as to future valuation of the British pound or Euro or how further movements in those or other currencies could affect future earnings or the financial position of the Company.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P9_S0	The majority of the Company s long-term debt bears interest at variable rates.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P9_S1	Accordingly, the Company s net income is affected by changes in interest rates.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P9_S2	Assuming the current level of borrowings at variable rates and a two hundred basis point change in the 2010 average interest rate under these borrowings, the Company s 2010 interest expense would have changed by approximately $420,000.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P10_S0	In the event of an adverse change in interest rates, management could take actions to mitigate its exposure.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P10_S1	Further, this analysis does not consider the effects of the change in the level of overall economic activity that could exist in such an environment.
897077_11_ITEM7A_P10_S2	However, the challenges affecting the banking industry and credit markets in general can potentially cause changes to credit availability which creates a level of uncertainty.

897077_11_ITEM15_P11_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
897077_11_ITEM15_P11_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
897077_11_ITEM15_P12_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
897077_11_ITEM15_P12_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
897077_11_ITEM15_P13_S0	In our opinion, Alamo Group Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.

897077_11_ITEM15_P43_S0	Goodwill consists of the excess of the purchase price over the fair value of identifiable net assets of businesses acquired.
897077_11_ITEM15_P43_S1	In the fourth quarter of each year, or when events and circumstances warrant such a review, the Company tests the goodwill of all of its reporting units for impairment.
897077_11_ITEM15_P43_S2	The goodwill impairment test is determined using a two-step process.
897077_11_ITEM15_P43_S3	The first step is to identify if a potential impairment exists by comparing the fair value of a reporting unit with its carrying amount, including goodwill (Step 1).
897077_11_ITEM15_P43_S4	If the fair value of a reporting unit exceeds its carrying value amount, goodwill of the reporting unit is not considered to have a potential impairment and the second step is not necessary.
897077_11_ITEM15_P43_S5	However, if the carrying amount of the reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the second step (Step 2) is performed to determine if goodwill is impaired and to measure the amount of impairment loss to recognize, if any.
897077_11_ITEM15_P43_S6	Step 2 compares the implied fair value of goodwill with the carrying amount of goodwill.
897077_11_ITEM15_P43_S7	If the implied value of goodwill is less than the carrying amount of goodwill, then a charge is recorded to reduce goodwill to the implied goodwill.
897077_11_ITEM15_P44_S0	The implied goodwill is calculated based on a hypothetical purchase price allocation, in that it takes the implied fair value of the reporting unit and allocates such fair value to the fair value of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit.
897077_11_ITEM15_P45_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_11_ITEM15_P45_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_11_ITEM15_P45_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_11_ITEM15_P45_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.
897077_11_ITEM15_P45_S4	The Company believes that the assumptions and estimates used to determine the estimated fair values of each of its reporting units are reasonable.
897077_11_ITEM15_P45_S5	However, different assumptions could materially affect the estimated fair value.
897077_11_ITEM15_P46_S0	As of December 31, 2010, goodwill was $34,073,000, which represents 9% of total assets.

897077_11_ITEM15_P50_S0	The Company tests its indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment on an annual basis at year-end, or more frequently if an event occurs or circumstances change that indicate that the fair value of an indefinite-lived intangible asset could be below its carrying amount.
897077_11_ITEM15_P50_S1	The impairment test consists of comparing the fair value of the indefinite-lived intangible asset, determined using the relief from royalty method, with its carrying amount.
897077_11_ITEM15_P50_S2	An impairment loss would be recognized for the carrying amount in excess of its fair value.

897077_11_ITEM15_P58_S0	Revenue Recognition The Company recognizes revenue when each of the following four criteria are met: 1) a contract or sales arrangement exists; 2) products have been shipped per agreed terms and title has been transferred or services have been rendered; 3) the prices of the products or services are fixed or determinable; and 4) collectability is reasonably assured.
897077_11_ITEM15_P59_S0	Pre-season sales orders are solicited in the fall in advance of the dealer s sales season in the spring and summer.
897077_11_ITEM15_P59_S1	Pre-season sales orders are shipped beginning in the fall and continuing through the spring and represent an opportunity for the Company s factories to level their production/shipping volumes through the winter months.
897077_11_ITEM15_P59_S2	These pre-season shipments carry descending discounts in conjunction with delayed payment terms of up to six months from the dealer s requested delivery date.
897077_11_ITEM15_P60_S0	Revenue from sales is recorded net of a provision for discounts that are anticipated to be earned and deducted at time of payment by the customer.
897077_11_ITEM15_P60_S1	These approximated discounts represent an average of historical amounts taken and are adjusted as program terms are changed.
897077_11_ITEM15_P60_S2	The reserves for discounts are reviewed and adjusted quarterly.
897077_11_ITEM15_P60_S3	From time to time, revenue is recognized under a bill and hold arrangement.

897077_11_ITEM15_P61_S1	Internal use software costs are expensed or capitalized depending on whether they are incurred in the preliminary project stage, application development stage or the post-implementation stage.
897077_11_ITEM15_P61_S2	Amounts capitalized are amortized over the estimated useful lives of the software.

897077_11_ITEM15_P68_S0	Federal Income Taxes Deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between the financial reporting basis and tax basis of assets and liabilities and are measured by applying enacted statutory tax rates applicable to the future years in which deferred tax assets or liabilities are expected to be settled or realized.
897077_11_ITEM15_P69_S0	In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, management considers whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will be realized.
897077_11_ITEM15_P69_S1	The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income during the periods in which those temporary differences become deductible.
897077_11_ITEM15_P69_S2	Management considers the scheduled reversals of deferred tax liabilities, projected future taxable income, and tax planning strategies in making this assessment.
897077_11_ITEM15_P69_S3	Based upon projections of future taxable income over the periods in which the deferred tax assets are deductible, management believes it is more likely than not that we will realize the benefits of these deductible differences.

897077_11_ITEM15_P81_S0	The Company evaluates the collectability of its accounts receivable based on a combination of factors.
897077_11_ITEM15_P81_S1	In circumstances where it is aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the Company records a specific reserve to reduce the amounts recorded to what it believes will be collected.
897077_11_ITEM15_P81_S2	For all other customers, it recognizes reserves for bad debt based on historical experience of bad debts as a percent of revenues for each business unit, adjusted for relative improvements or deteriorations in the aging and changes in current economic conditions.
897077_11_ITEM15_P82_S0	The Company evaluates all receivables that are over 60 days old and will reserve specifically on a 90-day basis.
897077_11_ITEM15_P83_S0	The Company has a secured or insured interest on most of its wholegoods that each customer purchases.
897077_11_ITEM15_P83_S1	This allows the Company, in times of a difficult economy when the customer is unable to pay or has filed for bankruptcy (usually Chapter 11), to repossess the customer s inventory.
897077_11_ITEM15_P83_S2	This also allows Alamo Group to maintain only a reserve over its cost, which usually represents the margin on the original sales price.

897077_11_ITEM15_P87_S1	Historically, between 85% and 95% of the Company s customers who qualify for each program actually take the discount that is available.
897077_11_ITEM15_P88_S0	The Company had a reserve of $7,506,000 on December 31, 2010 and $9,060,000 on December 31, 2009 to cover obsolete and slow moving inventory.
897077_11_ITEM15_P88_S1	The decrease in the reserve was mainly from the Company s U.S. operations, specifically its facilities in Gibson City and Indianola as a result of greater disposals and sales of slow moving and obsolete inventory.
897077_11_ITEM15_P89_S0	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three-year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three-year supply.
897077_11_ITEM15_P89_S1	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_11_ITEM15_P89_S2	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_11_ITEM15_P89_S3	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three-year history has been established.
897077_11_ITEM15_P90_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood units and 90 days on parts.
897077_11_ITEM15_P91_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety-day to six-month lag period.
897077_11_ITEM15_P91_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the unit to file a warranty claim.
897077_11_ITEM15_P91_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_11_ITEM15_P91_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.

897077_11_ITEM15_P112_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS Fair value is defined as the exchange price that would be received for an asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit price) in the principal or most advantageous market for the asset or liability in an orderly transaction between market participants.
897077_11_ITEM15_P113_S0	There is a three-tier fair value hierarchy based upon the observability of inputs used in valuation techniques.
897077_11_ITEM15_P113_S1	Observable inputs (highest level) reflect market data obtained from independent sources, while unobservable inputs (lowest level) reflect internally developed market assumptions.
897077_11_ITEM15_P113_S2	In Fair value measurements are classified under the following hierarchy:
897077_11_ITEM15_P114_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices for identical instruments in active markets.
897077_11_ITEM15_P115_S0	Level 2 Quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets; quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active; and model-derived valuations in which all significant inputs or significant value-drivers are observable in active markets.
897077_11_ITEM15_P116_S0	When available, the Company uses quoted market prices to determine fair value, and the Company classifies such measurements within Level 1.
897077_11_ITEM15_P116_S1	In some cases where market prices are not available, the Company makes use of observable market-based inputs to calculate fair value, in which case the measurements are classified with Level 2.
897077_11_ITEM15_P117_S0	If quoted or observable market prices are not available, fair value is based upon internally developed models that use, where possible, current market-based parameters such as interest rates, yield curves, currency rates, etc.
897077_11_ITEM15_P117_S1	These measurements are classified within Level 3.
897077_11_ITEM15_P118_S0	Fair value measurements are classified to the lowest level input or value-driver that is significant to the valuation.
897077_11_ITEM15_P118_S1	A measurement may therefore be classified within Level 3 even though there may be significant inputs that are readily observable.
897077_11_ITEM15_P119_S0	The fair value of interest rate swap derivatives is primarily based on third-party pricing service models.
897077_11_ITEM15_P119_S1	These models use discounted cash flows that utilize the appropriate market-based forward swap curves and zero-coupon interest rates.
897077_11_ITEM15_P119_S2	Interest rate swap derivatives are Level 2 measurements and have a fair value of $231,000 in a liability position as of December 31, 2010.
897077_11_ITEM15_P120_S0	The fair value of foreign currency forward contracts is based on a valuation model that discounts cash flows resulting from the differential between the contract price and the market-based forward rate and is a Level 2 measurement and has a fair value of $43,000 in a liability position as of December 31, 2010.

897077_11_ITEM15_P156_S0	The Company employs a building block approach in determining the expected long-term rate on return on plan assets.
897077_11_ITEM15_P156_S1	Historical markets are studied and long-term historical relationships between equities and fixed income are preserved consistent with the widely accepted capital market principle that assets with higher volatility generate a greater return over the long run.
897077_11_ITEM15_P156_S2	Current market factors such as inflation and interest rates are evaluated before long-term market assumptions are determined.
897077_11_ITEM15_P156_S3	The long-term portfolio return is established via a building block approach with proper consideration of diversification and rebalancing.
897077_11_ITEM15_P156_S4	Peer data and historical returns are reviewed to check for reasonability and appropriateness.

897077_11_ITEM15_P159_S0	The Company employs a total return investment approach whereby a mix of equities and fixed income investments are used to maximize the long-term return of plan assets for a prudent level of risk.
897077_11_ITEM15_P159_S1	Risk tolerance is established through careful consideration of plan liabilities, plan funded status, and corporate financial condition.
897077_11_ITEM15_P160_S0	The investment portfolio contains a diversified blend of equity and fixed income investments.
897077_11_ITEM15_P160_S1	Furthermore, equity investments are diversified across U.S. and non-U.S. stocks, as well as growth, value, and small and large capitalizations.
897077_11_ITEM15_P160_S2	Other assets such as real estate, private equity, and hedge funds are used judiciously to enhance long-term returns while improving portfolio diversification.
897077_11_ITEM15_P160_S3	Derivatives may be used to gain market exposure in an efficient and timely manner; however, derivatives may not be used to leverage the portfolio beyond the market value of the underlying investments.
897077_11_ITEM15_P161_S0	Investment risk is measured and monitored on an ongoing basis through quarterly investment portfolio reviews, annual liability measurements, and periodic asset/liability studies.

897077_11_ITEM15_P193_S0	On October 22, 2009 ( Closing Date ), the Company acquired the majority of the assets and assumed certain liabilities of Bush Hog located in Selma, Alabama.
897077_11_ITEM15_P193_S1	The purchase included substantially all of the ongoing business of Bush Hog, including the Bush Hog brand name and all related product names and trademarks (the Acquisition ).
897077_11_ITEM15_P193_S2	The purchase price consideration was 1.7 million unregistered shares of Alamo Group common stock which represented approximately 14.5% of the outstanding stock of Alamo Group.
897077_11_ITEM15_P193_S3	Because the restricted stock was issued in an unregistered private transaction, resale of the shares is restricted and the shares may be resold only if registered or sold in a transaction exempt from the registration requirements of the Securities Act, including pursuant to Rule 144 under the Securities Act.
897077_11_ITEM15_P193_S4	Under Rule 144, the restricted stock is subject to, among other things, an initial 6-month holding period before any of the shares can be sold in the public market.
897077_11_ITEM15_P193_S5	Accordingly, the fair value of the 1.7 million shares was based on the public market price of Alamo common stock less a discount for lack of marketability associated with the 6-month holding period.
897077_11_ITEM15_P193_S6	We utilized an Asian put option model to measure the discount for lack of marketability.
897077_11_ITEM15_P194_S0	An Asian put option is an option that entitles the holder to a payoff based on the average price of an underlying asset, over a predetermined period.
897077_11_ITEM15_P194_S1	The closing price of our common stock on October 22, 2009 was $16.09 per share.
897077_11_ITEM15_P195_S0	The Acquisition was accounted for in accordance with ASC Topic 805, Business Combinations ( ASC Topic 805 ).
897077_11_ITEM15_P195_S1	Accordingly, the total purchase price was allocated on a provisional basis to assets acquired and net liabilities assumed in connection with the Acquisition based on their estimated fair values as of the completion of the Acquisition.
897077_11_ITEM15_P195_S2	These allocations reflected various provisional estimates that were available at the time and were subject to change during the purchase price allocation period as valuations are finalized.
897077_11_ITEM15_P196_S0	The Company believes that it was able to acquire Bush Hog for less than the fair value of its assets because of (i) the Company s unique position as a market leader in this industry segment and (ii) the seller s intent to exit its Bush Hog operations.
897077_11_ITEM15_P196_S1	Bush Hog was an unprofitable venture, and the seller approached the Company in an effort to sell Bush Hog and exit the agricultural equipment manufacturing business that no longer fit its strategy.
897077_11_ITEM15_P197_S0	With the seller's intent to exit the agricultural manufacturing business segment and the Company s position as a market leader, the Company was able to agree on a favorable purchase price.
897077_11_ITEM15_P198_S0	The primary reason for the Bush Hog acquisition was to help the Company further the goal of becoming the largest manufacturer of agricultural mowers in the world.
897077_11_ITEM15_P198_S1	This acquisition enabled the Company to expand its market presence, expand its product offerings and enter new markets.

897077_11_ITEM15_P199_S1	Accordingly, the Company recognized the excess of the fair value of the net assets over the purchase price of approximately $27.7 million as a gain on bargain purchase.
