897077_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	You should carefully consider each of the risks described below, together with all of the other information contained in this Annual Report on Form 10-K, before making an investment decision with respect to the Company s securities.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	If any of the following risks develop into actual events, the Company s business, financial condition or results from operations could be materially and adversely affected and you could lose all or part of your investment.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Deterioration of industry conditions could harm our business, results of operations and financial condition.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our business depends to a large extent upon the prospects for the mowing, right-of-way maintenance and agricultural markets in general.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Future prospects of the industry depend largely on factors outside of our control.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Any of those factors could adversely impact demand for our products, which could adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	increase in unfunded pension plan liability due to financial market deterioration.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	In addition, our business is susceptible to a number of factors that specifically affect agricultural customer spending patterns, including the following:
897077_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	A downturn in general economic conditions and outlook in the United States and around the world could adversely affect our net sales and earnings.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The strength and profitability of our business depends on the overall demand for our products and upon economic conditions and outlook, including but not limited to economic growth rates; consumer spending levels; financing availability, pricing and terms for our dealers and end-users; employment rates; interest rates; inflation; consumer confidence and general economic and political conditions and expectations in the United States and the foreign economies in which we conduct business.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Slow or negative growth rates, inflationary pressures, higher commodity costs and energy prices, reduced credit availability or unfavorable credit terms for our dealers and end-user customers, increased unemployment rates, and continued recessionary economic conditions and outlook could cause consumers to continue to reduce spending, which may cause them to delay or forego purchases of our products and could have an adverse effect on our net sales and earnings.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	We depend on governmental sales and a decrease in such sales could adversely affect us.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	A substantial portion of our revenues is derived from sales to federal, state and local governmental entities both in the U.S. and in other countries in which we sell our products.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P8_S1	These sales depend primarily on the levels of budgeted and appropriated expenditures for highway, airport, roadside and parks maintenance by various governmental entities and are affected by changes in local and national economic conditions.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our dependence on, and the price and availability of, raw materials as well as purchased components may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	We are subject to fluctuations in market prices for raw materials such as steel and energy.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Additionally, although most of the raw materials and purchase components we use are commercially available from a number of sources, we could experience disruptions in the availability of such materials.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P10_S2	If we are unable to purchase materials we require or are unable to pass on price increases to our customers or otherwise reduce our cost of goods sold, our business, results of operations and financial condition may be adversely affected.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P10_S3	In addition, higher energy costs may negatively affect spending by farmers, including their purchases of our products.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Impairment in the carrying value of goodwill could negatively impact our consolidated results of operations and net worth.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P12_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P12_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P12_S4	The Company believes that the assumptions and estimates used to determine the estimated fair values of each of its reporting units are reasonable.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P12_S5	However, different assumptions could materially affect the estimated fair value.

897077_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	We operate in a highly competitive industry, and some of our competitors and potential competitors have greater resources than we do.

897077_11_ITEM1A_P26_S2	Any or all of these reasons could adversely affect our business, results of operation and financial condition.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	The agricultural industry and the mowing and right of way maintenance industry are seasonal and are affected by the weather, and seasonal fluctuations may cause our results of operations and working capital to fluctuate from quarter to quarter.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	In general, agricultural and governmental end-users typically purchase new equipment during the first and second calendar quarters.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P28_S1	Other products such as street sweepers, excavators, snow blowers, front-end loaders and pothole patchers have different seasonal patterns, as do replacement parts in general.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P28_S2	In attempting to achieve efficient utilization of manpower and facilities throughout the year, we estimate seasonal demand months in advance and manufacturing capacity is scheduled in anticipation of such demand.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P28_S3	We utilize a rolling twelve-month sales forecast provided by our marketing divisions and order backlog in order to develop a production plan for our manufacturing facilities.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P28_S4	Additionally, many of our marketing departments attempt to equalize demand for their products throughout the calendar year by offering seasonal sales programs which may provide additional incentives, including discounts and extended payment terms, on equipment that is ordered during off-season periods.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P28_S5	Because we spread our production and wholesale shipments throughout the year to take into account the factors described above, sales in any given period may not reflect the timing of dealer orders and retail demand.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Weather conditions and general economic conditions may affect the timing of purchases and actual industry conditions might differ from our forecasts.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P29_S1	Consequently, we cannot assure that sudden or significant declines in industry demand would not adversely affect our working capital or results of operations.

897077_11_ITEM1A_P36_S0	The Company knows that its Indianola, Iowa property is contaminated with chromium which most likely resulted from chrome plating operations which were discontinued before the Company purchased the property.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P36_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.

897077_11_ITEM1A_P36_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P36_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P36_S5	We received a conditional no further action letter in January of 2009.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P36_S6	When we demonstrate stable or improving conditions below residential standards by future monitoring of existing wells, an unconditional no further action letter will be requested.

897077_11_ITEM1A_P53_S0	Provisions of our corporate documents may have anti-takeover effects that could prevent a change in control.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P54_S0	Provisions of our charter, bylaws and Delaware law could make it more difficult for a third party to acquire us, even if doing so would be beneficial to our stockholders.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P54_S1	These provisions include supermajority voting requirements, prohibiting the stockholder from calling stockholder meetings, removal of directors for cause only and prohibiting shareholder actions by written consent.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P54_S2	Our Certificate of Incorporation and By-laws state that any amendment to certain provisions, including those provisions regarding the removal of directors and limitations on action by written consent discussed above, be approved by the holders of at least two-thirds of our common stock.
897077_11_ITEM1A_P54_S3	We are also afforded the protections of Section 203 of the Delaware General Corporation Law, which would prevent us from engaging in a business combination with a person who becomes a 15% or greater shareholder for a period of three years from the date such person acquired such status unless certain board or shareholder approvals were obtained.

897077_12_ITEM1_P0_S0	The Company is a global leader in the design and manufacture of high quality agricultural equipment and infrastructure maintenance equipment for governmental and industrial use.
897077_12_ITEM1_P0_S1	The Company s products include tractor-mounted mowing and other vegetation maintenance equipment, street sweepers, excavators, vacuum trucks, snow removal equipment, pothole patchers, zero turn radius mowers, agricultural implements and related aftermarket parts and services.
897077_12_ITEM1_P0_S2	The Company emphasizes high quality, cost-effective products for its customers and strives to develop and market innovative products while constantly monitoring and seeking to contain its manufacturing and overhead costs.
897077_12_ITEM1_P0_S3	The Company has a long-standing strategy of supplementing its internal growth through acquisitions of businesses or product lines that currently complement, command, or have the potential to achieve a meaningful share of their niche markets.
897077_12_ITEM1_P0_S4	The Company has approximately 2,500 employees and operates a total of eighteen plants in North America, Europe and Australia.
897077_12_ITEM1_P0_S5	The Company sells its products primarily through a network of independent dealers and distributors to governmental end-users, related independent contractors, as well as to the agricultural and commercial turf markets.
897077_12_ITEM1_P0_S6	The Company operates primarily in the United States, England, France, Canada and Australia.
897077_12_ITEM1_P1_S0	The predecessor corporation to Alamo Group Inc. was incorporated in the State of Texas in 1969, as a successor to a business that began selling mowing equipment in 1955, and Alamo Group Inc. was reincorporated in the State of Delaware in 1987.
897077_12_ITEM1_P2_S0	Since its founding in 1969, the Company has focused on satisfying customer needs through geographic market expansion, product development and refinement, and selected acquisitions.
897077_12_ITEM1_P3_S0	The Company s first products were based on rotary cutting technology.
897077_12_ITEM1_P3_S1	Through acquisitions, the Company added flail cutting technology in 1983 and sickle-bar cutting technology in 1984.
897077_12_ITEM1_P4_S0	The Company added to its presence in the industrial and governmental vegetation markets with the acquisition of Tiger Corporation ( Tiger ) in late 1994.
897077_12_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Company entered the agricultural mowing markets in 1986 with the acquisition of Rhino Products Inc. ( Rhino ) , a leading manufacturer in this field.
897077_12_ITEM1_P5_S1	With this acquisition, the Company embarked on a strategy to increase the Rhino dealer distribution network during a period of industry contraction.
897077_12_ITEM1_P5_S2	The addition of M W Gear Company ( M W ) in early 1995 allowed the Company to enter into the manufacturing and distribution of tillage equipment, which complements the Rhino distribution network.
897077_12_ITEM1_P5_S3	M W has been integrated into the agricultural marketing group.
897077_12_ITEM1_P6_S0	In 1991, the Company began its international expansion with the acquisition of McConnel Ltd .
897077_12_ITEM1_P6_S1	( McConnel ) , a United Kingdom ( U.K. ) manufacturer of vegetation maintenance equipment, principally hydraulic boom-mounted hedge and grass cutters and related parts.
897077_12_ITEM1_P6_S2	( Bomford ) , also a U.K. company, was acquired in 1993.
897077_12_ITEM1_P7_S0	Bomford is a manufacturer of heavy-duty, tractor-mounted grass and hedge mowing equipment.
897077_12_ITEM1_P7_S1	McConnel and Bomford sell their products to dealers and distributors through their respective sales forces.
897077_12_ITEM1_P8_S0	In 1994, the Company acquired Signalisation Moderne Autoroutiere S.A .
897077_12_ITEM1_P8_S1	( SMA ) located in Orleans, France.
897077_12_ITEM1_P8_S2	SMA manufactures and sells principally a line of heavy-duty, tractor-mounted grass and hedge mowing equipment and associated replacement parts primarily to departments of the French government.
897077_12_ITEM1_P8_S3	This acquisition, along with the acquisitions of Forges Gorce, a flail blade manufacturer in France, in 1996 and Rousseau Holdings S.A. ( Rousseau ), a leading French manufacturer of hedge and verge mowers, in 2004, when combined with McConnel and Bomford, has made the Company one of the largest manufacturers in the European market for the kind of equipment sold by the Company.
897077_12_ITEM1_P9_S0	In 2000, the Company acquired Schwarze Industries, Inc .
897077_12_ITEM1_P9_S1	Schwarze is a manufacturer of a broad range of street sweeping equipment which is sold to governmental agencies and contractors.
897077_12_ITEM1_P9_S2	The Company believes the Schwarze sweeper products fit the Company s strategy of identifying product offerings with brand recognition in the industrial markets the Company serves.
897077_12_ITEM1_P10_S0	In 2004, the Company purchased the pothole patcher from Wildcat Manufacturing, Inc.
897077_12_ITEM1_P10_S1	The product line was merged into the Schwarze operation and is complementary to its current product offerings.
897077_12_ITEM1_P11_S0	In 2000, the Company purchased the product line and associated assets of Twose of Tiverton Ltd.
897077_12_ITEM1_P11_S1	( Twose ) in the U.K. and incorporated its production into the existing facilities at McConnel and Bomford while maintaining its own sales force and dealer distribution network.
897077_12_ITEM1_P11_S2	Twose was a small regional manufacturer of power arm flail mowers and parts, as well as harrows and rollers, which strengthened the Company s market leadership position in the U.K.
897077_12_ITEM1_P12_S0	In 2000, the Company acquired Schulte Industries Ltd. and its related entities ( Schulte ) .
897077_12_ITEM1_P12_S1	Schulte is a Canadian manufacturer of mechanical rotary mowers, snow blowers, and rock removal equipment.
897077_12_ITEM1_P12_S2	Schulte strengthened the Company s Canadian presence in both marketing and manufacturing.
897077_12_ITEM1_P12_S3	It also expanded the Company s range of large, heavy-duty rotary mowers.
897077_12_ITEM1_P13_S0	In 2001, the Company acquired all of the assets of SMC Corporation ( SMC ).
897077_12_ITEM1_P13_S1	SMC manufactures front-end loaders and backhoes principally for Original Equipment Manufacturer ( OEM ) customers and its own SMC brand.
897077_12_ITEM1_P13_S2	This acquisition expanded the product range of our agricultural division by branding a line of loaders for Rhino .
897077_12_ITEM1_P14_S0	In 2002, the Company purchased inventory, fixed assets and certain other assets of Valu-Bilt Tractor Parts ( Valu-Bilt ) , a subsidiary of Quality Stores, Inc., located in Des Moines, Iowa.
897077_12_ITEM1_P14_S1	Valu-Bilt is a distributor of new, used and rebuilt tractor parts and other agricultural spare and wear parts sold directly to customers through its catalog and the internet and on a wholesale basis to dealers.
897077_12_ITEM1_P14_S2	Subsequent to the purchase, the operations of Valu-Bilt in Des Moines, Iowa, were consolidated into the Company s Herschel facility in Indianola, Iowa.
897077_12_ITEM1_P15_S0	In 2002, the Company purchased substantially all of the assets of Faucheux Industries S.A. ( Faucheux ) , a leading French manufacturer of front-end loaders and attachments.
897077_12_ITEM1_P15_S1	The Company acquired Faucheux out of administration, a form of bankruptcy in France.
897077_12_ITEM1_P15_S2	This acquisition broadened the range of our agricultural implements offered in the French market.
897077_12_ITEM1_P15_S3	In 2005, the Company, through its European subsidiary Alamo Group (EUR) Ltd., acquired 100% of the issued and outstanding stock of Spearhead Machinery Limited ( Spearhead ) and subsequently merged its manufacturing operations into Bomford s facility.
897077_12_ITEM1_P16_S0	Spearhead manufactures a range of tractor-mounted vegetation maintenance equipment, including reach mowers, flail mowers and rotary cutters.
897077_12_ITEM1_P16_S1	This acquisition extended our product lines and market coverage in Europe.
897077_12_ITEM1_P17_S0	In early 2006, the Company purchased substantially all of the assets of the Gradall excavator business ( Gradall ) of JLG Industries, Inc. including their manufacturing plant in New Philadelphia, Ohio.
897077_12_ITEM1_P17_S1	Gradall is a leading manufacturer of both wheeled and crawler telescopic excavators in North America.
897077_12_ITEM1_P17_S2	This acquisition enhanced our Industrial Division product offering sold to governmental buyers and related contractors for maintenance along right-of-ways.
897077_12_ITEM1_P18_S0	In 2006, the Company purchased the vacuum truck and sweeper lines of Clean Earth Environmental Group, LLC and Clean Earth Kentucky, LLC (collectively referred to as VacAll ) .
897077_12_ITEM1_P18_S1	This includes the product lines, inventory and certain other assets that relate to this business.
897077_12_ITEM1_P18_S2	The production of the vacuum truck line was moved to the Gradall facility in New Philadelphia, Ohio.
897077_12_ITEM1_P19_S0	In 2006, the Company acquired 100% of the ownership interests in Nite-Hawk Sweepers LLC ( Nite-Hawk ) , a manufacturer of truck mounted sweeping equipment primarily for the contract sweeping market, which expanded its presence in that market and complements our Schwarze sweeper line.
897077_12_ITEM1_P20_S0	In 2007, the Company purchased Henke Manufacturing Corporation ( Henke ) , a manufacturer of specialty snow removal attachments.
897077_12_ITEM1_P20_S1	Henke s products are mounted on both heavy industrial equipment and medium to heavy-duty trucks.
897077_12_ITEM1_P20_S2	The primary end-users are governmental agencies, related contractors and other industrial users.

897077_12_ITEM1_P21_S1	The acquisition broadened the Company s product offering to its customers in Europe and other markets we serve.

897077_12_ITEM1_P21_S3	( Bush Hog ) , a leading agricultural equipment manufacturer of rotary cutters, finishing mowers, zero turn radius mowers ( ZTRs ), front-end loaders, backhoes, landscape equipment and a variety of other implements.
897077_12_ITEM1_P21_S4	This acquisition, combined with the Company s existing range of agricultural mowers, created one of the largest manufacturers of agricultural mowers in the world.

897077_12_ITEM1_P23_S0	Tenco is a Canadian based manufacturer of snow removal equipment including snow blades, blowers, dump bodies, spreaders and/associated parts and service.

897077_12_ITEM1_P58_S0	While the Company believes that the end-users of its products evaluate their purchases on the basis of price, reputation and product quality, such purchases are also based on a dealer s service, support of and loyalty to the dealer based on previous purchase experiences, as well as other factors such as product and replacement part availability.
897077_12_ITEM1_P58_S1	The Company s ability to provide innovative responses to customer needs, to develop and manufacture new products, and to enhance existing product lines is important to its success.
897077_12_ITEM1_P59_S0	The Company continually conducts research and development activities in an effort to improve existing products and develop new products.
897077_12_ITEM1_P59_S1	As of December 31, 2011 , the Company employed 135 people in its various engineering departments, 61 of whom are degreed engineers and the balance of whom are support staff.
897077_12_ITEM1_P59_S2	Amounts expended on research and development activities were approximately $ 6,017,000 in 2011 , $ 5,774,000 in 2010 and $ 4,762,000 in 2009 .
897077_12_ITEM1_P59_S3	As a percentage of sales, research and development was approximately 1.0% in 2011 and 1.1% in 2010 and 2009 , and is expected to continue at similar levels in 2012 .
897077_12_ITEM1_P59_S4	Seasonality The Company s sales, both product and replacement parts, are generally higher in the second and third quarters of the year, because a substantial number of the Company s products are used for maintenance activities such as vegetation maintenance, highway right-of-way maintenance, construction, and street and parking lot sweeping.
897077_12_ITEM1_P59_S5	Usage of this equipment is lower in harsh weather.
897077_12_ITEM1_P60_S0	The Company utilizes a rolling twelve-month sales forecast provided by the Company s marketing departments and order backlog in order to develop a production plan for its manufacturing facilities.
897077_12_ITEM1_P60_S1	In addition, many of the Company s marketing departments attempt to equalize demand for products throughout the calendar year by offering seasonal sales programs which may provide additional incentives, including discounts and extended payment terms, under these programs.
897077_12_ITEM1_P61_S0	Competition The Company s products are sold in highly competitive markets throughout the world.
897077_12_ITEM1_P61_S1	The principal competitive factors are price, quality, availability, service and reputation.
897077_12_ITEM1_P61_S2	The Company competes with several large national and international companies that offer a broad range of equipment and replacement parts, as well as with numerous small, privately-held manufacturers and suppliers of a limited number of products, mainly on a regional basis.
897077_12_ITEM1_P61_S3	Some of the Company s competitors are significantly larger than the Company and have substantially greater financial and other resources at their disposal.
897077_12_ITEM1_P61_S4	The Company believes that it is able to compete successfully in its markets by effectively managing its manufacturing costs, offering high quality products, developing and designing innovative products and, to some extent, avoiding direct competition with significantly larger potential competitors.
897077_12_ITEM1_P61_S5	There can be no assurance that the Company s competitors will not substantially increase the resources devoted to the development and marketing of products competitive with the Company s products or that new competitors with greater resources will not enter the Company s markets.
897077_12_ITEM1_P62_S0	As of December 31, 2011 , the Company had unfilled customer orders of $ 119,923,000 compared to $ 97,616,000 at December 31, 2010 .
897077_12_ITEM1_P62_S1	The 23% increase was primarily due to the positive impact of improved agricultural market conditions on Bush Hog and Rhino backlogs.
897077_12_ITEM1_P63_S0	The Company continues to be affected by soft market conditions and reduced government spending in parts of its Industrial and European divisions due to the downturn in the global economy.
897077_12_ITEM1_P63_S1	Management expects that substantially all of the Company s backlog as of December 31, 2011 will be shipped during fiscal year 2012 .
897077_12_ITEM1_P64_S0	The amount of unfilled orders at a particular time is affected by a number of factors, including manufacturing and shipping schedules which, in most instances, are dependent on the Company s seasonal sales programs and the requirements of its customers.
897077_12_ITEM1_P64_S1	Certain of the Company s orders are subject to cancellation at any time before shipment; therefore, a comparison of unfilled orders from period to period is not necessarily meaningful and may not be indicative of future actual shipments.
897077_12_ITEM1_P65_S0	No single customer is responsible for 10% or more of the aggregate revenue of the Company.
897077_12_ITEM1_P66_S0	Sources of Supply The principal raw materials used by the Company include steel, other metal components and hydraulic tubing.
897077_12_ITEM1_P66_S1	During 2011 , the raw materials needed by the Company were available from a variety of sources in adequate quantities and at prevailing market prices.
897077_12_ITEM1_P66_S2	No one supplier is responsible for supplying more than 10% of the principal raw materials used by the Company.
897077_12_ITEM1_P67_S0	While the Company manufactures many of the parts for its products, a significant percentage of parts, including most drivelines, gearboxes, industrial engines, and hydraulic components, are purchased from outside suppliers which manufacture to the Company s specifications.
897077_12_ITEM1_P67_S1	In addition, the Company, through its subsidiaries, purchases tractors and truck chassis as a number of the Company s products are mounted and shipped with a tractor or truck chassis.
897077_12_ITEM1_P67_S2	Tractors and truck chassis are generally available, but some delays in receiving tractors or truck chassis can occur throughout the year.
897077_12_ITEM1_P68_S0	The Company sources its purchased goods from international and domestic suppliers.
897077_12_ITEM1_P68_S1	No single supplier is responsible for supplying more than 10% of the purchased goods used by the Company.
897077_12_ITEM1_P69_S0	The Company owns various U.S. and international patents.
897077_12_ITEM1_P69_S1	While the Company considers its patents to be advantageous to its business, it is not dependent on any single patent or group of patents.
897077_12_ITEM1_P69_S2	The Company amortized approximately $79,000 in patents and trademarks relating to the industrial segment.
897077_12_ITEM1_P69_S3	In 2010, the Company wrote off $224,000 in older patents which the Company believes no longer provide a competitive advantage.
897077_12_ITEM1_P69_S4	The net book value of trademarks was $ 5,500,000 as of December 31, 2011 and 2010 .
897077_12_ITEM1_P70_S0	Products manufactured by the Company are advertised and sold under numerous trademarks.

897077_12_ITEM1_P70_S2	The Company also owns other trademarks which it uses to a lesser extent, such as M W , SMC , Fuerst , Triumph , Mott , Turner , and Dandl .

897077_12_ITEM1_P72_S0	Environmental and Other Governmental Regulations Like other manufacturers, the Company is subject to a broad range of federal, state, local and foreign laws and requirements, including those concerning air emissions, discharges into waterways, and the generation, handling, storage, transportation, treatment and disposal of hazardous substances and waste materials, as well as the remediation of contamination associated with releases of hazardous substances at the Company s facilities and offsite disposal locations, workplace safety and equal employment opportunities.
897077_12_ITEM1_P72_S1	These laws and regulations are constantly changing, and it is impossible to predict with accuracy the effect that changes to such laws and regulations may have on the Company in the future.
897077_12_ITEM1_P73_S0	Like other industrial concerns, the Company s manufacturing operations entail the risk of noncompliance, and there can be no assurance that the Company will not incur material costs or other liabilities as a result thereof.
897077_12_ITEM1_P74_S0	The Company knows that its Indianola, Iowa property is contaminated with chromium which most likely resulted from chrome plating operations which were discontinued before the Company purchased the property.
897077_12_ITEM1_P74_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.
897077_12_ITEM1_P74_S2	The Company voluntarily worked with an environmental consultant and the state of Iowa with respect to these issues and believes it completed its remediation program in June 2006.
897077_12_ITEM1_P74_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_12_ITEM1_P74_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_12_ITEM1_P74_S5	We received a conditional no further action letter in January of 2009.
897077_12_ITEM1_P74_S6	When we demonstrate stable or improving conditions below residential standards for a certain period of time by monitoring existing wells, an unconditional no further action letter will be requested.
897077_12_ITEM1_P75_S0	On December 31, 2011 , the Company had an environmental reserve in the amount of $ 1,185,000 related to the acquisition of Gradall s facility in New Philadelphia, Ohio.
897077_12_ITEM1_P75_S1	The reserve of $ 1,185,000 , is for potential ground water contamination/remediation that was identified before the acquisition and believed to have been generated by a third party company located near the Gradall facility.
897077_12_ITEM1_P76_S0	The Company knows that Bush Hog s main manufacturing property in Selma, Alabama was contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic compounds which most likely resulted from painting and cleaning operations during the 1960s and 1970s.
897077_12_ITEM1_P76_S1	The contaminated areas were primarily in the location of underground storage tanks and underneath the former waste storage area.
897077_12_ITEM1_P76_S2	Under the Asset Purchase Agreement, Bush Hog s prior owner agreed to and has removed the underground storage tanks at its cost and has remediated the identified contamination in accordance with the regulations of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management.
897077_12_ITEM1_P76_S3	An environmental consulting firm was retained by the prior owner and administered the cleanup and will monitor the site on an ongoing basis until the remediation program is complete and approved by the applicable authorities.
897077_12_ITEM1_P77_S0	Certain other assets of the Company contain asbestos that may have to be remediated over time.
897077_12_ITEM1_P77_S1	The Company believes that any subsequent change in the liability associated with the asbestos removal will not have a material adverse effect on the Company s consolidated financial position or results of operations.
897077_12_ITEM1_P78_S0	The Company is subject to various other federal, state, and local laws affecting its business, as well as a variety of regulations relating to such matters as working conditions, equal employment opportunities, and product safety.
897077_12_ITEM1_P78_S1	A variety of state laws regulate the Company s contractual relationships with its dealers, some of which impose restrictive standards on the relationship between the Company and its dealers, including events of default, grounds for termination, non-renewal of dealer contracts, and equipment repurchase requirements.
897077_12_ITEM1_P78_S2	The Company believes it is currently in material compliance with all such applicable laws and regulations.

897077_12_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Slow or negative growth rates, inflationary pressures, higher commodity costs and energy prices, reduced credit availability or unfavorable credit terms for our dealers and end-user customers, increased unemployment rates, and continued recessionary economic conditions and outlook could cause consumers to continue to reduce spending, which may cause them to delay or forego purchases of our products and could have an adverse effect on our net sales and earnings.

897077_12_ITEM1A_P18_S3	If we are unable to successfully integrate acquired businesses, our future results may be negatively impacted.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P18_S4	In addition, we may be adversely affected if businesses that we have acquired, or that we acquire in the future, do not perform as expected.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P18_S5	An acquired business could perform below our expectations for a number of reasons, including legislative or regulatory changes that affect the areas in which the acquired business specializes, the loss of customers and dealers, general economic factors that directly affect the acquired business, and the cultural incompatibility of its management team.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P18_S6	Any or all of these reasons could adversely affect our business, results of operation and financial condition.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P18_S7	The agricultural industry and the mowing and right of way maintenance industry are seasonal and are affected by the weather, and seasonal fluctuations may cause our results of operations and working capital to fluctuate from quarter to quarter.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P18_S8	In general, agricultural and governmental end-users typically purchase new equipment during the first and second calendar quarters.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P18_S9	Other products such as street sweepers, excavators, snow blowers, front-end loaders and pothole patchers have different seasonal patterns, as do replacement parts in general.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P19_S0	advance and manufacturing capacity is scheduled in anticipation of such demand.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P19_S1	We utilize a rolling twelve-month sales forecast provided by our marketing divisions and order backlog in order to develop a production plan for our manufacturing facilities.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P19_S2	Additionally, many of our marketing departments attempt to equalize demand for their products throughout the calendar year by offering seasonal sales programs which may provide additional incentives, including discounts and extended payment terms, on equipment that is ordered during off-season periods.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P19_S3	Because we spread our production and wholesale shipments throughout the year to take into account the factors described above, sales in any given period may not reflect the timing of dealer orders and retail demand.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P19_S4	Weather conditions and general economic conditions may affect the timing of purchases and actual industry conditions might differ from our forecasts.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P19_S5	Consequently, sudden or significant declines in industry demand could adversely affect our working capital or results of operations.
897077_12_ITEM1A_P19_S6	If we do not retain key personnel and attract and retain other highly skilled employees, our business may suffer.

897077_12_ITEM7_P43_S0	In May 2011, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued a new accounting standard update, which amends the fair value measurement guidance and includes some enhanced disclosure requirements.
897077_12_ITEM7_P43_S1	The most significant change in disclosures is an expansion of the information required for Level 3 measurements based on unobservable inputs.
897077_12_ITEM7_P43_S2	The standard is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
897077_12_ITEM7_P43_S3	We will adopt this standard in the first quarter of 2012 and we do not expect the adoption will have a material impact on our financial statements and disclosures.
897077_12_ITEM7_P44_S0	In June 2011, the FASB issued a new accounting standard, which eliminates the current option to report other comprehensive income and its components in the statement of stockholders' equity.
897077_12_ITEM7_P44_S1	Instead, an entity will be required to present items of net income and other comprehensive income in one continuous statement or in two separate, but consecutive, statements.
897077_12_ITEM7_P44_S2	The standard is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
897077_12_ITEM7_P44_S3	We will adopt this standard in the first quarter of 2012.
897077_12_ITEM7_P45_S0	In September 2011, the FASB issued a revised accounting standard, which is intended to reduce the cost and complexity of the annual goodwill impairment test by providing entities an option to perform a qualitative assessment to determine whether further impairment testing is necessary.
897077_12_ITEM7_P45_S1	Specifically, an entity has the option to first assess qualitative factors to determine whether it is necessary to perform the current two-step test.
897077_12_ITEM7_P45_S2	If an entity believes, as a result of its qualitative assessment, that it is more-likely-than-not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, the quantitative impairment test is required.
897077_12_ITEM7_P45_S3	Otherwise, no further testing is required.
897077_12_ITEM7_P45_S4	This standard is effective for annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
897077_12_ITEM7_P45_S5	We have elected to adopt this guidance for the year ended December 31, 2011 and the guidance did not have a material impact on our financial statements.

897077_12_ITEM7_P50_S0	Critical Accounting Estimates Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations are based upon our Consolidated Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ).
897077_12_ITEM7_P50_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
897077_12_ITEM7_P50_S2	Management bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
897077_12_ITEM7_P50_S3	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
897077_12_ITEM7_P51_S0	An accounting policy is deemed to be critical if it requires an accounting estimate to be made based on assumptions about matters that are highly uncertain at the time the estimate is made, and if different estimates that reasonably could have been used, or changes in the accounting estimates that are reasonably likely to occur periodically, could materially impact the financial statements.
897077_12_ITEM7_P51_S1	Management believes the following critical accounting policies reflect its more significant estimates and assumptions used in the preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements.
897077_12_ITEM7_P51_S2	For further information on the critical accounting policies, see Note 1 of our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
897077_12_ITEM7_P52_S0	The Company evaluates the collectability of its accounts receivable based on a combination of factors.
897077_12_ITEM7_P52_S1	In circumstances where it is aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the Company records a specific reserve to reduce the amounts recorded to what it believes will be collected.
897077_12_ITEM7_P52_S2	For all other customers, it recognizes reserves for bad debt based on historical experience of bad debts as a percent of revenues for each business unit, adjusted for relative improvements or deteriorations in the aging and changes in current economic conditions.
897077_12_ITEM7_P53_S0	The Company evaluates all receivables that are over 60 days old and will reserve specifically on a 90-day basis.
897077_12_ITEM7_P54_S0	The Company has a secured interest on most of its wholegoods that each customer purchases.
897077_12_ITEM7_P54_S1	This allows the Company, in times of a difficult economy when the customer is unable to pay or has filed for bankruptcy (usually Chapter 11), to repossess the customer s inventory.
897077_12_ITEM7_P54_S2	This also allows Alamo Group to maintain only a reserve over its cost, which usually represents the margin on the original sales price.
897077_12_ITEM7_P55_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts balance was $ 3,215,000 on December 31, 2011 , and $ 2,852,000 on December 31, 2010 .
897077_12_ITEM7_P55_S1	The increase was mainly from the Company s Industrial and European operations.
897077_12_ITEM7_P56_S0	On December 31, 2011 , the Company had $ 14,567,000 in reserves for sales discounts compared to $ 11,903,000 on December 31, 2010 on product shipped to our customers under various promotional programs.
897077_12_ITEM7_P56_S1	The increase was due primarily to increased sales volume of the Company s agricultural products during the pre-season, which runs during the third and fourth quarters of each year with orders shipped through the second quarter of 2012.
897077_12_ITEM7_P57_S0	The Company reviews the reserve quarterly based on analysis made on each program outstanding at the time.
897077_12_ITEM7_P58_S0	The Company bases its reserves on historical data relating to discounts taken by the customer under each program.
897077_12_ITEM7_P58_S1	Historically, between 85% and 95% of the Company s customers who qualify for each program actually take the discount that is available.
897077_12_ITEM7_P59_S0	The Company had a reserve of $ 7,630,000 on December 31, 2011 and $ 7,506,000 on December 31, 2010 to cover obsolete and slow moving inventory.
897077_12_ITEM7_P59_S1	The increase in the reserve was mainly from the Company s U.S. operations.
897077_12_ITEM7_P60_S0	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three-year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three-year supply.
897077_12_ITEM7_P60_S1	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_12_ITEM7_P60_S2	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_12_ITEM7_P60_S3	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three-year history has been established.
897077_12_ITEM7_P61_S0	The reserve is reviewed and, if necessary, adjustments are made on a quarterly basis.
897077_12_ITEM7_P61_S1	The Company relies on historical information when available to support its reserve.
897077_12_ITEM7_P61_S2	The Company does not adjust the reserve balance until the inventory is liquidated.
897077_12_ITEM7_P62_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood units and 90 days on parts though some components can have warranty for longer terms.
897077_12_ITEM7_P63_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety-day to six-month lag period.
897077_12_ITEM7_P63_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the unit to file a warranty claim.
897077_12_ITEM7_P63_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_12_ITEM7_P63_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.
897077_12_ITEM7_P64_S0	The current liability warranty reserve balance was $ 5,313,000 on December 31, 2011 and $ 5,554,000 on December 31, 2010 .
897077_12_ITEM7_P64_S1	The decrease was mainly from the Company s Agricultural Division.
897077_12_ITEM7_P65_S0	We test goodwill for impairment annually, at the reporting unit level, and whenever events or circumstances make it likely that an impairment may have occurred, such as a significant adverse change in the business climate or a decision to sell all or a portion of a reporting unit.
897077_12_ITEM7_P65_S1	We perform our annual goodwill impairment test as of October 1 and monitor for interim triggering events on an ongoing basis.
897077_12_ITEM7_P66_S0	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment utilizing a qualitative assessment or a two-step process.
897077_12_ITEM7_P66_S1	We have an option to make a qualitative assessment of a reporting unit's goodwill for impairment.
897077_12_ITEM7_P66_S2	If we choose to perform a qualitative assessment and determine the fair value more likely than not exceeds the carrying value, no further evaluation is necessary.
897077_12_ITEM7_P67_S0	For reporting units where we perform the two-step process, the first step requires us to compare the fair value of each reporting unit, which we primarily determine using an income approach based on the present value of discounted cash flows, to the respective carrying value, which includes goodwill.
897077_12_ITEM7_P67_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying value, the goodwill is not considered impaired.
897077_12_ITEM7_P67_S2	If the carrying value is higher than the fair value, there is an indication that an impairment may exist and the second step is required.
897077_12_ITEM7_P68_S0	In step two, the implied fair value of goodwill is calculated as the excess of the fair value of a reporting unit over the fair values assigned to its assets and liabilities.
897077_12_ITEM7_P68_S1	If the implied fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value of the reporting unit's goodwill, the difference is recognized as an impairment loss.
897077_12_ITEM7_P69_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_12_ITEM7_P69_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_12_ITEM7_P69_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_12_ITEM7_P69_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.
897077_12_ITEM7_P70_S0	As of December 31, 2011 , goodwill was $ 31,751,000 , which represents 8% of total assets.
897077_12_ITEM7_P70_S1	The Company recognized goodwill impairment at two of its French operations, SMA and Rousseau , in the Company's European division of $1,898,000 in 2011 and no goodwill impairment in 2010.
897077_12_ITEM7_P70_S2	During the 2011 impairment analysis review, it was noted that even though the Schwarze, Rivard and Faucheux reporting unit s fair value was above carrying value it was not materially different.
897077_12_ITEM7_P70_S3	On December 31, 2011 , there was approximately $6.8 million, $11.6 million and $0.6 million of goodwill related to the Schwarze, Rivard and Faucheux reporting units respectively.
897077_12_ITEM7_P70_S4	These reporting units would be most likely affected by changes in the Company s assumptions and estimates.
897077_12_ITEM7_P70_S5	The calculation of fair value could increase or decrease depending on changes in the inputs and assumptions used, such as changes in the reporting unit s future growth rates, discount rates, etc.
897077_12_ITEM7_P71_S0	Management believes that the estimated valuations it arrived at are reasonable and consistent with what other marketplace participants would use in valuing the Company's components.
897077_12_ITEM7_P71_S1	However, management cannot give any assurance that these market values will not change in the future.
897077_12_ITEM7_P71_S2	For example, if discount rates demanded by the market increase, this could lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_12_ITEM7_P71_S3	If the Company's projections are not achieved in the future, this could lead management to reassess their assumptions and lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_12_ITEM7_P71_S4	If the market price of the Company's stock decreases, this could cause the Company to reassess the reasonableness of the implied control premium, which might cause management to assume a higher discount rate under the income approach which could lead to reduced valuations.
897077_12_ITEM7_P71_S5	If future similar transactions exhibit lower multiples than those observed in the past, this could lead to reduced valuations under the similar transactions approach.
897077_12_ITEM7_P71_S6	And finally, if there is a general decline in the stock market and particularly in those companies selected as comparable to the Company's components, this could lead to reduced valuations under the public company market multiple approach.
897077_12_ITEM7_P72_S0	The Company's annual impairment test is performed during the fourth quarter of each fiscal year.
897077_12_ITEM7_P72_S1	Given the current market conditions and continued economic uncertainty, the fair value of the Company's components could deteriorate which could result in the need to record impairment charges in future periods.
897077_12_ITEM7_P72_S2	The Company also monitors potential triggering events including changes in the business climate in which it operates, attrition of key personnel, volatility in the capital markets, the Company's market capitalization compared to its book value, the Company's recent operating performance, and the Company's financial projections.
897077_12_ITEM7_P72_S3	The occurrence of one or more triggering events could require additional impairment testing, which could result in future impairment charges.
897077_12_ITEM7_P72_S4	In particular, since the Schwarze , Rivard and Faucheux , reporting unit's carrying value is not materially different from fair value, any changes to the Company's assumptions could lead to an indicated impairment in step one, requiring the Company to proceed to step two and potentially record an impairment charge.
897077_12_ITEM7_P72_S5	See Note 6 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for more information regarding goodwill.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The Company is exposed to various financial market risks.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market prices and rates.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The Company does not enter into derivative or other financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P2_S0	International Sales A portion of the Company s operations consists of manufacturing and sales activities in international jurisdictions.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The Company primarily manufactures its products in the United States, the U.K., France, Canada and Australia.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P2_S2	The Company sells its products primarily within the markets where the products are produced, but certain of the Company s sales from its U.K. operations are denominated in other European currencies.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P2_S3	As a result, the Company s financials, specifically the value of its foreign assets, could be affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency exchange rates or weak economic conditions in the other markets in which the subsidiaries of the Company distribute their products.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P2_S4	To mitigate the short-term effect of changes in currency exchange rates on the Company s functional currency-based sales, the Company s U.K. subsidiaries regularly enter into foreign exchange forward contracts to hedge over 90% of its future net foreign currency cash receipts over a period of six months.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P2_S5	As of December 31, 2011 , the Company had $ 3,460,000 outstanding in forward exchange contracts related to accounts receivable.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P2_S6	A 15% fluctuation in exchange rates for these currencies would change the fair value by approximately $ 519,000 .
897077_12_ITEM7A_P2_S7	However, since these contracts hedge foreign currency denominated transactions, any change in the fair value of the contracts should be offset by changes in the underlying value of the transaction being hedged.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P2_S8	On December 31, 2011 , the fair value of these agreements was in an unfavorable position; therefore, the derivative financial instruments were recorded as a gain of $ 102,000 , which has been recognized in other income (expense), net.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Exposure to Exchange Rates The Company s earnings are affected by fluctuations in the value of the U.S. dollar as compared to foreign currencies, predominantly in European countries, Canada and Australia, as a result of the sale of its products in international markets.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P3_S1	Foreign currency forward contracts in the U.K. are used to hedge against the earnings effects of such fluctuations.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P4_S0	On December 31, 2011 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would result in a decrease in gross profit of $ 4,816,000 .
897077_12_ITEM7A_P4_S1	Comparatively, on December 31, 2010 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have resulted in a decrease in gross profit of approximately $ 4,435,000 .
897077_12_ITEM7A_P5_S0	This calculation assumes that each exchange rate would change in the same direction relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P5_S1	In addition to the direct effects of changes in exchange rates, which are a changed dollar value of the resulting sales, changes in exchange rates may also affect the volume of sales or the foreign currency sales price as competitors products become more or less attractive.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P5_S2	The Company s sensitivity analysis of the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates does not factor in a potential change in sales levels or local currency prices.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P5_S3	The translation adjustment during 2011 was a loss of $ 2,879,000 .
897077_12_ITEM7A_P6_S0	On December 31, 2011 , the British pound closed at 0.6434 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.7716 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P6_S1	By comparison, on December 31, 2010 , the British pound closed at 0.6411 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.7479 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P6_S2	No assurance can be given as to future valuation of the British pound or Euro or how further movements in those or other currencies could affect future earnings or the financial position of the Company.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P7_S0	Interest Rate Risk The majority of the Company s long-term debt bears interest at variable rates.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P7_S1	Accordingly, the Company s net income is affected by changes in interest rates.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P7_S2	Assuming the current level of borrowings at variable rates and a two hundred basis point change in the 2011 average interest rate under these borrowings, the Company s 2011 interest expense would have changed by approximately $ 140,000 .
897077_12_ITEM7A_P8_S0	In the event of an adverse change in interest rates, management could take actions to mitigate its exposure.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P9_S0	change in the level of overall economic activity that could exist in such an environment.
897077_12_ITEM7A_P9_S1	However, the challenges affecting the banking industry and credit markets in general can potentially cause changes to credit availability which creates a level of uncertainty.

897077_12_ITEM15_P11_S4	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
897077_12_ITEM15_P12_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
897077_12_ITEM15_P12_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
897077_12_ITEM15_P13_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
897077_12_ITEM15_P13_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
897077_12_ITEM15_P14_S0	In our opinion, Alamo Group Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011 , based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.

897077_12_ITEM15_P23_S1	The Company manages its business in three principal reporting segments: North American Agricultural, North American Industrial and European, which are discussed in Notes 15 and 16.

897077_12_ITEM15_P24_S5	The reclassification of revenue and cost of sales for the years ended December 31, 2011 , 2010 and 2009 resulted in an increase of approximately $15.6 million, $14.0 million and $8.3 million, respectively, with no impact on reported net income.

897077_12_ITEM15_P33_S0	Goodwill Goodwill consists of the excess of the purchase price over the fair value of identifiable net assets of businesses acquired.
897077_12_ITEM15_P33_S1	We perform our annual goodwill impairment test as of October 1 and monitor for interim triggering events on an ongoing basis.
897077_12_ITEM15_P34_S0	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment utilizing a qualitative assessment or a two-step process.
897077_12_ITEM15_P34_S1	We have an option to make a qualitative assessment of a reporting unit's goodwill for impairment.
897077_12_ITEM15_P34_S2	If we choose to perform a qualitative assessment and determine the fair value more likely than not exceeds the carrying value, no further evaluation is necessary.
897077_12_ITEM15_P35_S0	For reporting units where we perform the two-step process, the first step requires us to compare the fair value of each reporting unit, which we primarily determine using an income approach based on the present value of discounted cash flows, to the respective carrying value, which includes goodwill.
897077_12_ITEM15_P35_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying value, the goodwill is not considered impaired.
897077_12_ITEM15_P35_S2	If the carrying value is higher than the fair value, there is an indication that an impairment may exist and the second step is required.
897077_12_ITEM15_P36_S0	In step two, the implied fair value of goodwill is calculated as the excess of the fair value of a reporting unit over the fair values assigned to its assets and liabilities.
897077_12_ITEM15_P36_S1	If the implied fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value of the reporting unit's goodwill, the difference is recognized as an impairment loss.
897077_12_ITEM15_P37_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_12_ITEM15_P37_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_12_ITEM15_P37_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_12_ITEM15_P37_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.
897077_12_ITEM15_P38_S0	As of December 31, 2011 , goodwill was $ 31,751,000 , which represents 8% of total assets.
897077_12_ITEM15_P38_S1	The Company recognized goodwill impairment at two of its French operations, SMA and Rousseau, in the Company's European division of $1,898,000 in 2011 and no goodwill impairment in 2010.
897077_12_ITEM15_P38_S2	During the 2011 impairment analysis review, it was noted that even though the Schwarze, Rivard and Faucheux reporting unit s fair value was above carrying value it was not materially different.
897077_12_ITEM15_P38_S3	On December 31, 2011 , there was approximately $6.8 million, $11.6million and $0.6 million of goodwill related to the Schwarze, Rivard and Faucheux reporting units respectively.
897077_12_ITEM15_P38_S4	These reporting units would be most likely affected by changes in the Company s assumptions and estimates.
897077_12_ITEM15_P38_S5	The calculation of fair value could increase or decrease depending on changes in the inputs and assumptions used, such as changes in the reporting unit s future growth rates, discount rates, etc.
897077_12_ITEM15_P39_S0	Management believes that the estimated valuations it arrived at are reasonable and consistent with what other marketplace participants would use in valuing the Company's components.
897077_12_ITEM15_P39_S1	However, management cannot give any assurance that these market values will not change in the future.
897077_12_ITEM15_P39_S2	For example, if discount rates demanded by the market increase, this could lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_12_ITEM15_P39_S3	If the Company's projections are not achieved in the future, this could lead management to reassess their assumptions and lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_12_ITEM15_P39_S4	If the market price of the Company's stock decreases, this could cause the Company to reassess the reasonableness of the implied control premium, which might cause management to assume a higher discount rate under the income approach which could lead to reduced valuations.
897077_12_ITEM15_P39_S5	If future similar transactions exhibit lower multiples than those observed in the past, this could lead to reduced valuations under the similar transactions approach.
897077_12_ITEM15_P40_S0	The Company's annual impairment test is performed during the fourth quarter of each fiscal year.
897077_12_ITEM15_P40_S1	Given the current market conditions and continued economic uncertainty, the fair value of the Company's components could deteriorate which could result in the need to record impairment charges in future periods.
897077_12_ITEM15_P40_S2	The Company also monitors potential triggering events including changes in the business climate in which it operates, attrition of key personnel, volatility in the capital markets, the Company's market capitalization compared to its book value, the Company's recent operating performance, and the Company's financial projections.
897077_12_ITEM15_P40_S3	The occurrence of one or more triggering events could require additional impairment testing, which could result in future impairment charges.
897077_12_ITEM15_P40_S4	In particular, since the Schwarze, Rivard and Faucheux, reporting unit's carrying value is not materially different from fair value, any changes to the Company's assumptions could lead to an indicated impairment in step one, requiring the Company to proceed to step two and potentially record an impairment charge.
897077_12_ITEM15_P40_S5	See Note 6 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for more information regarding goodwill.

897077_12_ITEM15_P41_S5	The impairment test consists of comparing the fair value of the indefinite-lived intangible asset, determined using the relief from royalty method, with its carrying amount.
897077_12_ITEM15_P41_S6	An impairment loss would be recognized for the carrying amount in excess of its fair value.

897077_12_ITEM15_P58_S0	Federal Income Taxes Deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between the financial reporting basis and tax basis of assets and liabilities and are measured by applying enacted statutory tax rates applicable to the future years in which deferred tax assets or liabilities are expected to be settled or realized.
897077_12_ITEM15_P59_S0	In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, management considers whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will be realized.
897077_12_ITEM15_P59_S1	The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income during the periods in which those temporary differences become deductible.
897077_12_ITEM15_P59_S2	Management considers the scheduled reversals of deferred tax liabilities, projected future taxable income, and tax planning strategies in making this assessment.
897077_12_ITEM15_P59_S3	Based upon projections of future taxable income over the periods in which the deferred tax assets are deductible, management believes it is more likely than not that we will realize the benefits of these deductible differences.

897077_12_ITEM15_P71_S0	The Company evaluates the collectability of its accounts receivable based on a combination of factors.
897077_12_ITEM15_P71_S1	In circumstances where it is aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the Company records a specific reserve to reduce the amounts recorded to what it believes will be collected.
897077_12_ITEM15_P71_S2	For all other customers, it recognizes reserves for bad debt based on historical experience of bad debts as a percent of revenues for each business unit, adjusted for relative improvements or deteriorations in the aging and changes in current economic conditions.
897077_12_ITEM15_P72_S0	The Company evaluates all receivables that are over 60 days old and will reserve specifically on a 90-day basis.
897077_12_ITEM15_P73_S0	The Company has a secured or insured interest on most of its wholegoods that each customer purchases.
897077_12_ITEM15_P73_S1	This allows the Company, in times of a difficult economy when the customer is unable to pay or has filed for bankruptcy (usually Chapter 11), to repossess the customer s inventory.
897077_12_ITEM15_P73_S2	This also allows Alamo Group to maintain only a reserve over its cost, which usually represents the margin on the original sales price.
897077_12_ITEM15_P74_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts balance was $ 3,215,000 on December 31, 2011 , and $ 2,852,000 on December 31, 2010 .
897077_12_ITEM15_P74_S1	The increase was mainly from the Company s Industrial and European operations.

897077_12_ITEM15_P75_S1	The increase was due primarily to higher sales activity of the Company s agricultural products during the pre-season, which runs from September to December of each year with orders shipped through the first quarter of 2011.
897077_12_ITEM15_P76_S0	The Company reviews the reserve quarterly based on analysis made on each program outstanding at the time.
897077_12_ITEM15_P77_S0	Historically, between 85% and 95% of the Company s customers who qualify for each program actually take the discount that is available.
897077_12_ITEM15_P78_S0	The Company had a reserve of $ 7,630,000 on December 31, 2011 and $ 7,506,000 on December 31, 2010 to cover obsolete and slow moving inventory.
897077_12_ITEM15_P78_S1	The increase in the reserve was mainly from the Company s U.S. operations.
897077_12_ITEM15_P79_S0	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three-year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three-year supply.
897077_12_ITEM15_P79_S1	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_12_ITEM15_P79_S2	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_12_ITEM15_P79_S3	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three-year history has been established.
897077_12_ITEM15_P80_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood units and 90 days on parts though some components can have warranty for longer terms.
897077_12_ITEM15_P81_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety-day to six-month lag period.
897077_12_ITEM15_P81_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the unit to file a warranty claim.
897077_12_ITEM15_P81_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_12_ITEM15_P81_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.
897077_12_ITEM15_P82_S0	The current liability warranty reserve balance was $ 5,313,000 on December 31, 2011 and $ 5,554,000 on December 31, 2010 .
897077_12_ITEM15_P82_S1	The decrease was mainly from the Company s Agricultural Division.

897077_12_ITEM15_P99_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS Fair value is defined as the exchange price that would be received for an asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit price) in the principal or most advantageous market for the asset or liability in an orderly transaction between market participants.
897077_12_ITEM15_P100_S0	There is a three-tier fair value hierarchy based upon the observability of inputs used in valuation techniques.
897077_12_ITEM15_P100_S1	Observable inputs (highest level) reflect market data obtained from independent sources, while unobservable inputs (lowest level) reflect internally developed market assumptions.
897077_12_ITEM15_P100_S2	In Fair value measurements are classified under the following hierarchy:
897077_12_ITEM15_P101_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices for identical instruments in active markets.
897077_12_ITEM15_P101_S1	Level 2 Quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets; quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active; and model-derived valuations in which all significant inputs or significant value-drivers are observable in active markets.
897077_12_ITEM15_P102_S0	When available, the Company uses quoted market prices to determine fair value, and the Company classifies such measurements within Level 1.
897077_12_ITEM15_P102_S1	In some cases where market prices are not available, the Company makes use of observable market-based inputs to calculate fair value, in which case the measurements are classified with Level 2.
897077_12_ITEM15_P103_S0	use, where possible, current market-based parameters such as interest rates, yield curves, currency rates, etc.
897077_12_ITEM15_P103_S1	These measurements are classified within Level 3.
897077_12_ITEM15_P104_S0	Fair value measurements are classified to the lowest level input or value-driver that is significant to the valuation.
897077_12_ITEM15_P104_S1	A measurement may therefore be classified within Level 3 even though there may be significant inputs that are readily observable.

897077_12_ITEM15_P138_S0	The Company employs a building block approach in determining the expected long-term rate on return on plan assets.
897077_12_ITEM15_P138_S1	Historical markets are studied and long-term historical relationships between equities and fixed income are preserved consistent with the widely accepted capital market principle that assets with higher volatility generate a greater return over the long run.
897077_12_ITEM15_P138_S2	Current market factors such as inflation and interest rates are evaluated before long-term market assumptions are determined.
897077_12_ITEM15_P138_S3	The long-term portfolio return is established via a building block approach with proper consideration of diversification and rebalancing.
897077_12_ITEM15_P138_S4	Peer data and historical returns are reviewed to check for reasonability and appropriateness.

897077_12_ITEM15_P141_S0	The Company employs a total return investment approach whereby a mix of equities and fixed income investments are used to maximize the long-term return of plan assets for a prudent level of risk.
897077_12_ITEM15_P141_S1	Risk tolerance is established through careful consideration of plan liabilities, plan funded status, and corporate financial condition.
897077_12_ITEM15_P142_S0	The investment portfolio contains a diversified blend of equity and fixed income investments.
897077_12_ITEM15_P142_S1	Furthermore, equity investments are diversified across U.S. and non-U.S. stocks, as well as growth, value, and small and large capitalizations.
897077_12_ITEM15_P142_S2	Other assets such as real estate, private equity, and hedge funds are used judiciously to enhance long-term returns while improving portfolio diversification.
897077_12_ITEM15_P142_S3	Derivatives may be used to gain market exposure in an efficient and timely manner; however, derivatives may not be used to leverage the portfolio beyond the market value of the underlying investments.
897077_12_ITEM15_P143_S0	Investment risk is measured and monitored on an ongoing basis through quarterly investment portfolio reviews, annual liability measurements, and periodic asset/liability studies.

897077_12_ITEM15_P151_S0	The Board of Directors of the Company adopted the Alamo Group Inc. Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (the SERP ), effective as of January 3, 2011.
897077_12_ITEM15_P151_S1	The SERP will benefit certain key management or other highly compensated employees of the Company and/or certain subsidiaries who are selected by the Compensation Committee and approved by the Board to participate.
897077_12_ITEM15_P152_S0	The SERP is intended to provide a benefit from the Company upon retirement, death or disability, or a change in control of the Company.
897077_12_ITEM15_P152_S1	Accordingly, the SERP obligates the Company to pay to a participant a Retirement Benefit (as defined in the SERP) upon the occurrence of certain payment events to the extent a participant has a vested right thereto.
897077_12_ITEM15_P152_S2	A participant s right to his or her Retirement Benefit becomes vested in the Company s contributions upon 10 years of Credited Service (as defined in the SERP) or a change in control of the Company.
897077_12_ITEM15_P152_S3	The Retirement Benefit is based on 20% of the final three-year average salary of each participant on or after his or her normal retirement age (65 years of age).
897077_12_ITEM15_P152_S4	In the event of the participant s death or a change in control, the participant s vested retirement benefit will be paid in a lump sum to the participant or his or her estate, as applicable, within 90 days after the participant s death or a change in control, as applicable.
897077_12_ITEM15_P152_S5	In the event the participant is entitled to a benefit from the SERP due to disability, retirement or other termination of employment, the benefit will be paid in monthly installments over a period of fifteen years.
897077_12_ITEM15_P153_S0	The Company records amounts relating to the SERP based on calculations that incorporate various actuarial and other assumptions, including discount rates, rate of compensation increases, retirement dates and life expectancies.
897077_12_ITEM15_P153_S1	The net periodic costs are recognized as employees render the services necessary to earn the SERP benefits.
