897077_14_ITEM3_P3_S2	Under the Asset Purchase Agreement, Bush Hog s prior owner agreed to and has removed the underground storage tanks at its cost and has remediated the identified contamination in accordance with the regulations of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management.
897077_14_ITEM3_P3_S3	An environmental consulting firm was retained by the prior owner to administer the cleanup and monitor the site on an ongoing basis until the remediation program is complete and approved by the applicable authorities.
897077_14_ITEM3_P4_S0	Certain properties of the Company contain asbestos that may have to be remediated over time.
897077_14_ITEM3_P4_S1	The Company believes that any subsequent change in the liability associated with the asbestos removal will not have a material adverse effect on the Company s consolidated financial position or results of operations.
897077_14_ITEM3_P5_S0	In December of 2012, a federal district court jury in Louisiana found that Gradall was unjustly enriched in the amount of $1,000,000 plus interest when it sold several telescopic fire apparatuses after properly terminating what the jury determined to be an enforceable contract with the plaintiff, a fire truck manufacturer.
897077_14_ITEM3_P5_S1	Gradall is appealing the decision and has reserved the full amount.
897077_14_ITEM3_P6_S0	Alamo Group Inc. and Bush Hog, Inc. were added as defendants in 2013 to ongoing litigation by Deere Company as plaintiff against Bush Hog, LLC (now Duroc, LLC) and Great Plains Manufacturing Incorporated, in which Deere alleged infringement of a mower-related patent.
897077_14_ITEM3_P6_S1	The jury concluded that not only did the defendants not infringe the patent but that the patent was invalid as well.
897077_14_ITEM3_P6_S2	The Company expensed $2,100,000 in legal fees related to this lawsuit in 2013.
897077_14_ITEM3_P7_S0	Some of the former employees of SMA in Orleans, France, conteste d the severance offered by the Company as a result of the closure of that facility in 2010 and were awarded additional payments by a French labor court.
897077_14_ITEM3_P7_S1	The Company is appealing the award but did accrue the full exposure of the severance.
897077_14_ITEM3_P8_S0	The Company is subject to various other federal, state, and local laws affecting its business, as well as a variety of regulations relating to such matters as working conditions, equal employment opportunities, and product safety.
897077_14_ITEM3_P8_S1	A variety of state laws regulate the Company s contractual relationships with its dealers, some of which impose restrictive standards on the relationship between the Company and its dealers, including events of default, grounds for termination, non-renewal of dealer contracts, and equipment repurchase requirements.
897077_14_ITEM3_P8_S2	The Company believes it is currently in material compliance with all such applicable laws and regulations.

897077_14_ITEM7_P1_S0	The Company s net sales in the fiscal year ended December 31, 2013 ( 2013 ) were $ 676,836,000 , an increase of $ 48,434,000 or 7.7% compared to $ 628,402,000 for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2012 ( 2012 ).
897077_14_ITEM7_P1_S1	The increase was mainly from improved sales in the Company's North American and Agricultural Divisions.
897077_14_ITEM7_P1_S2	The Industrial Division was up 12.6% as sales of all product lines increased over 2012.
897077_14_ITEM7_P1_S3	Likewise, sales in the Agricultural Division were up 7.4% over last year as mowing products for all three major brands showed improvement.
897077_14_ITEM7_P1_S4	Sales in the European Division were slightly up compared to 2012 as markets for our products showed increases in the second half of 2013 for the first time in several years.
897077_14_ITEM7_P2_S0	North American Industrial sales (net) were $ 296,617,000 in 2013 compared to $ 263,353,000 in 2012 , an increase of $ 33,264,000 or 12.6% .
897077_14_ITEM7_P2_S1	The increase was primarily from higher sales of sweepers, excavator, vacuum trucks and snow equipment as demand for infrastructure maintenance equipment was strong for most of 2013.
897077_14_ITEM7_P3_S0	North American Agricultural sales (net) were $ 215,340,000 in 2013 compared to $ 200,467,000 in 2012 , representing an increase of $ 14,873,000 or 7.4% .
897077_14_ITEM7_P3_S1	The increase in sales compared to 2012 was from improved demand for Bush Hog, Schulte and Rhino products in the agricultural market in North America.
897077_14_ITEM7_P3_S2	Favorable weather conditions during the middle of 2013 helped improve sales to both row crop and hobby farmers.
897077_14_ITEM7_P3_S3	Commodity prices retreated somewhat during the year from levels experienced over prior years, but still remain strong.
897077_14_ITEM7_P4_S0	European sales (net) increased $ 297,000 or 0.2% to $ 164,879,000 in 2013 compared to $ 164,582,000 in 2012 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P4_S1	This slight increase was mainly from improved sales during the last half of 2013 as European markets showed some signs of improvement after being in decline for the last several years.
897077_14_ITEM7_P4_S2	However, challenging market conditions and uncertainty in the European economy continued to affect this Division.
897077_14_ITEM7_P5_S0	Gross margins for 2013 were $ 158,510,000 ( 23.4% of net sales) compared to $ 143,512,000 ( 22.8% of net sales) in 2012 , an increase of $ 14,998,000 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P5_S1	The increase was from higher sales volume during 2013 which led to favorable production efficiencies.
897077_14_ITEM7_P5_S2	Increased lower margin tractor and chassis sales combined with lower sales of higher margin replacement parts negatively affecting the gross profit in 2013.
897077_14_ITEM7_P6_S0	Selling, general and administrative expenses ( SG A ) were $ 107,773,000 ( 15.9% of net sales) in 2013 compared to $ 97,507,000 ( 15.5% of net sales) in 2012 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P6_S1	The increase of $ 10,266,000 in SG A in 2013 was primarily litigation expenses from a patent infringement lawsuit, which we were successful in defending, in the amount of $2,137,000, $972,000 of acquisition related expenses and $586,000 of additional stock option expense related to the accelerated vesting of options to retirement eligible recipients.
897077_14_ITEM7_P6_S2	Also during 2013, the Company had restructuring costs at one of its French operations, higher performance based incentive compensation expense, increased sales commissions on higher sales and increased trade show expenses in both North America and Europe.
897077_14_ITEM7_P7_S0	Interest expense for 2013 was $ 1,161,000 compared to $ 1,620,000 in 2012 , a decrease of $ 459,000 or 28.3% .
897077_14_ITEM7_P7_S1	The decrease came from reduced borrowings in 2013 compared to 2012 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P8_S0	Other income (expense), net was income of $ 1,626,000 during 2013 compared to an expense of $ 517,000 in 2012 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P8_S1	The income in 2013 included a grant of $475,000 from the UK government related to R D training and employment, a $70,000 gain realized from the sale of the Company's Memphis warehouse in the first quarter of 2013 and fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.
897077_14_ITEM7_P8_S2	In 2012 the expense was entirely the result of foreign exchange rate fluctuations.
897077_14_ITEM7_P9_S0	Provision for Income Taxes was $ 15,294,000 ( 29.8% of income before income taxes) for 2013 compared to $ 14,543,000 ( 33.5% of income before income taxes) in 2012 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P9_S1	Due to the delay in signing the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012 which extended the research and development tax credits, the Company was not able to include $350,000 of tax credits in its 2012 financial statements but instead recognized this tax benefit in the first quarter of 2013 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P9_S2	Also included in the 2013 provision is a credit related to the reversal of reserves for uncertain tax positions and a tax benefit relating to current losses in one of our French companies.
897077_14_ITEM7_P10_S0	Net Income for 2013 was $ 36,094,000 compared to $ 28,903,000 in 2012 due to the factors described above.
897077_14_ITEM7_P11_S0	The Company s net sales in the fiscal year ended December 31, 2012 ( 2012 ) were $ 628,402,000 , an increase of $ 24,809,000 or 4.1% compared to $ 603,593,000 for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2011 ( 2011 ).
897077_14_ITEM7_P11_S1	The increase was mainly due to the acquisition of Tenco in October of 2011 and improved sales of mowing and vacuum truck equipment in the Industrial Division.
897077_14_ITEM7_P11_S2	The Company's Agricultural Division was slightly down as agricultural markets experienced slower growth as farmers remained cautious about the weak U.S. economy.
897077_14_ITEM7_P11_S3	Sales in the European Division were also down in 2012 compared to 2011 as governmental markets remained soft due to the economic slowdown that has continued to affect Europe.
897077_14_ITEM7_P12_S0	North American Industrial sales (net) were $ 263,353,000 in 2012 compared to $ 229,594,000 in 2011 , an increase of $ 33,759,000 or 14.7% .
897077_14_ITEM7_P12_S1	The increase was from the acquisition of Tenco which contributed $21,444,000 of sales in 2012 compared to $6,950,000 in 2011, and improved sales from VacAll vacuum trucks and mowing equipment from both the Alamo Industrial and Tiger branded products.
897077_14_ITEM7_P12_S2	Sales of excavators and street sweepers were negatively affected by slower markets resulting from continued budget pressures at governmental entities.
897077_14_ITEM7_P13_S0	North American Agricultural sales (net) were $ 200,467,000 in 2012 compared to $ 203,993,000 in 2011 , representing a decrease of $ 3,526,000 or 1.7% .
897077_14_ITEM7_P13_S1	The decrease was from market conditions and the summer drought that affected the Midwest part of the U.S. during the first nine months of 2012.
897077_14_ITEM7_P13_S2	However, preseason orders during the last quarter of 2012 for both Bush Hog and Rhino products were up compared to 2011.
897077_14_ITEM7_P13_S3	This improvement reflected strengthening in the agricultural sector by increases in commodity prices and farm incomes.
897077_14_ITEM7_P14_S0	European sales (net) decreased $ 5,424,000 or 3.2% to $ 164,582,000 in 2012 compared to $ 170,006,000 in 2011 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P14_S1	This decrease reflected soft governmental market conditions that affected this Division for all of 2012.
897077_14_ITEM7_P14_S2	French markets in particular were down as economic uncertainty in the European economy negatively affected product sales in France.
897077_14_ITEM7_P15_S0	Gross margins for 2012 were $ 143,512,000 ( 22.8% of net sales) compared to $ 135,085,000 ( 22.4% of net sales) in 2011 , an increase of $ 8,427,000 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P15_S1	The increase was from the acquisition of Tenco in the amount of $4,378,000 and improved vacuum trucks and mowers sales in the Company's Industrial Division.
897077_14_ITEM7_P15_S2	Gross margin percentages also improved over last year as a result of continued improvements from efficiency initiatives which helped lower manufacturing costs.
897077_14_ITEM7_P16_S0	Selling, general and administrative expenses ( SG A ) were $ 97,507,000 ( 15.5% of net sales) in 2012 compared to $ 92,347,000 ( 15.3% of net sales) in 2011 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P16_S1	The increase of $ 5,160,000 in SG A in 2012 was primarily from the acquisition of Tenco in the amount of $3,515,000.
897077_14_ITEM7_P16_S2	During the fourth quarter of 2012, the Company incurred $2,420,000 in expenses relating to various litigation matters.
897077_14_ITEM7_P16_S3	These additional SG A expenses were partially offset by the reversal of an environmental reserve at Gradall in the amount of $1,185,000.
897077_14_ITEM7_P17_S0	The Company incurred goodwill impairment non-cash charges of $656,000 in 2012 and $1,898,000 in 2011.
897077_14_ITEM7_P17_S1	In 2012, the Company wrote off all the goodwill at its French company Faucheux .
897077_14_ITEM7_P17_S2	In 2011, the Company wrote off all of the goodwill pertaining to two of its French companies, SMA and Rousseau.
897077_14_ITEM7_P17_S3	The primary reason for the goodwill impairment in 2012 and 2011 was the general economic downturn that continues to affect the Company's European operations.
897077_14_ITEM7_P17_S4	All three companies are part of its European Division.

897077_14_ITEM7_P18_S2	Other income (expense), net was an expense of $ 517,000 during 2012 compared to income of $ 848,000 in 2011 .

897077_14_ITEM7_P22_S0	In addition to normal operating expenses, the Company has ongoing cash requirements which are necessary to conduct the Company s business, including inventory purchases and capital expenditures.
897077_14_ITEM7_P22_S1	The Company s inventory and accounts payable levels, particularly in its North American Agricultural Division, build in the first quarter and early spring and, to a lesser extent, in the fourth quarter in anticipation of the spring and fall selling seasons.
897077_14_ITEM7_P22_S2	Accounts receivable historically build in the first and fourth quarters of each year as a result of pre-season sales.
897077_14_ITEM7_P22_S3	These sales help balance the Company s production during the first and fourth quarters.
897077_14_ITEM7_P22_S4	Some of the Company s recent acquisitions which are not involved in vegetation maintenance have helped to soften this seasonality pattern.

897077_14_ITEM7_P36_S0	In July 2013, the provisions of Accounting Standards Codification Topic 740, Income Taxes, were amended to provide specific guidance on the financial statement presentation of an unrecognized tax benefit when a net operating loss carryforward, a similar tax loss, or a tax credit carryforward exists at the reporting date.
897077_14_ITEM7_P36_S1	The amendment requires entities to present an unrecognized tax benefit as a reduction to the deferred tax asset generated by the net operating loss carryforward, similar tax loss, or tax credit carryforward, if such items are available to be used to offset the unrecognized tax benefit.
897077_14_ITEM7_P36_S2	These provisions are effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2013 and should be applied prospectively to all unrecognized tax benefits that exist at the effective date, with retrospective application permitted.
897077_14_ITEM7_P37_S0	On January 2, 2013, President Obama signed into law the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012 (the ATR Act ) which included an extension of the federal research and development credit retroactively to 2012 and prospectively through 2013.
897077_14_ITEM7_P37_S1	The effects of the ATR Act are recognized in 2013.
897077_14_ITEM7_P38_S0	The SEC adopted the conflict mineral rules under Section 1502 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act on August 22, 2012.
897077_14_ITEM7_P38_S1	The rules require public companies to disclose information about their use of specific minerals originating from and financing armed groups in the Democratic Republic of the Congo or adjoining countries.
897077_14_ITEM7_P38_S2	The conflict mineral rules cover minerals frequently used to manufacture a wide array of electronic and industrial products including semiconductor devices.
897077_14_ITEM7_P38_S3	The rules do not ban the use of minerals from conflict sources, but require public disclosure beginning with calendar year 2013.
897077_14_ITEM7_P38_S4	We have determined that we are subject to the rules and are evaluating our supply chain and continue to develop processes to assess the impacts and comply with the regulation.

897077_14_ITEM7_P41_S0	Definitions: (A) Long-term debt obligation means a principal payment obligation under long-term borrowings.

897077_14_ITEM7_P41_S2	(C) Interest obligation represents interest due on long-term debt and capital lease obligations.
897077_14_ITEM7_P41_S3	Interest on long-term debt assumes all floating rates of interest remain the same as those in effect at December 31, 2013 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P42_S0	(D) Operating lease obligation means a payment obligation under a lease classified as an operating lease.
897077_14_ITEM7_P42_S1	(E) Purchase obligation means an agreement to purchase goods or services that is enforceable and legally binding on the registrant that specifies all significant terms, including: fixed or minimum quantities to be purchased; fixed, minimum or variable price provisions; and the approximate timing of the transactions.
897077_14_ITEM7_P43_S0	Critical Accounting Estimates Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations are based upon our Consolidated Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ).
897077_14_ITEM7_P43_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
897077_14_ITEM7_P43_S2	Management bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
897077_14_ITEM7_P43_S3	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
897077_14_ITEM7_P44_S0	An accounting policy is deemed to be critical if it requires an accounting estimate to be made based on assumptions about matters that are highly uncertain at the time the estimate is made, and if different estimates that reasonably could have been used, or changes in the accounting estimates that are reasonably likely to occur periodically, could materially impact the financial statements.
897077_14_ITEM7_P44_S1	Management believes the following critical accounting policies reflect its more significant estimates and assumptions used in the preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements.
897077_14_ITEM7_P44_S2	For further information on the critical accounting policies, see Note 1 of our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
897077_14_ITEM7_P45_S0	The Company evaluates the collectability of its accounts receivable based on a combination of factors.
897077_14_ITEM7_P45_S1	In circumstances where it is aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the Company records a specific reserve to reduce the amounts recorded to what it believes will be collected.
897077_14_ITEM7_P45_S2	For all other customers, it recognizes reserves for bad debt based on historical experience of bad debts as a percent of revenues for each business unit, adjusted for relative improvements or deteriorations in the aging and changes in current economic conditions.
897077_14_ITEM7_P46_S0	The Company evaluates all receivables that are over 60 days old and will reserve specifically on a 90-day basis.
897077_14_ITEM7_P47_S0	The Company has a secured or insured interest on most of its wholegoods that each customer purchases.
897077_14_ITEM7_P47_S1	This allows the Company, in times of a difficult economy when the customer is unable to pay or has filed for bankruptcy, to repossess its inventory.
897077_14_ITEM7_P47_S2	This also allows Alamo Group to maintain only a reserve over its cost, which usually represents the margin on the original sales price.
897077_14_ITEM7_P48_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts balance was $ 2,738,000 on December 31, 2013 , and $ 3,077,000 on December 31, 2012 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P48_S1	The decrease was mainly from the Company s Industrial Division.
897077_14_ITEM7_P49_S0	On December 31, 2013 , the Company had $ 16,724,000 in reserves for sales discounts compared to $ 15,005,000 on December 31, 2012 on product shipped to our customers under various promotional programs.
897077_14_ITEM7_P49_S1	The increase was due primarily to increased sales volume of the Company s agricultural products during the 2013 pre-season, which runs during the third and fourth quarters of each year with orders shipped through the second quarter of 2014.
897077_14_ITEM7_P50_S0	The Company reviews the reserve quarterly based on analysis made on each program outstanding at the time.
897077_14_ITEM7_P51_S0	The Company bases its reserves on historical data relating to discounts taken by the customer under each program.
897077_14_ITEM7_P51_S1	Historically, between 85% and 95% of the Company s customers who qualify for each program actually take the discount that is available.
897077_14_ITEM7_P52_S0	The Company had a reserve of $ 8,596,000 on December 31, 2013 and $ 9,099,000 on December 31, 2012 to cover obsolete and slow moving inventory.
897077_14_ITEM7_P52_S1	The decrease in the reserve was mainly from the Industrial Division and to a lesser extent the Company's Agricultural Division.
897077_14_ITEM7_P53_S0	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three-year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three-year supply.
897077_14_ITEM7_P53_S1	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_14_ITEM7_P53_S2	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_14_ITEM7_P53_S3	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three-year history has been established.
897077_14_ITEM7_P54_S0	The reserve is reviewed and, if necessary, adjustments are made on a quarterly basis.
897077_14_ITEM7_P54_S1	The Company relies on historical information when available to support its reserve.
897077_14_ITEM7_P54_S2	The Company does not adjust the reserve balance until the inventory is liquidated.
897077_14_ITEM7_P55_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood units and 90 days on parts, though some components can have warranty for longer terms.
897077_14_ITEM7_P56_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety-day to six-month lag period.
897077_14_ITEM7_P56_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the unit to file a warranty claim.
897077_14_ITEM7_P56_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_14_ITEM7_P56_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.
897077_14_ITEM7_P57_S0	The current liability warranty reserve balance was $ 4,994,000 on December 31, 2013 and $ 5,007,000 on December 31, 2012 .
897077_14_ITEM7_P58_S0	We test goodwill for impairment annually, at the reporting unit level, and whenever events or circumstances make it likely that an impairment may have occurred, such as a significant adverse change in the business climate or a decision to sell all or a portion of a reporting unit.
897077_14_ITEM7_P58_S1	We perform our annual goodwill impairment test as of October 1 and monitor for interim triggering events on an ongoing basis.
897077_14_ITEM7_P59_S0	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment utilizing a qualitative assessment or a two-step process.
897077_14_ITEM7_P59_S1	We have an option to make a qualitative assessment of a reporting unit's goodwill for impairment.
897077_14_ITEM7_P59_S2	If we choose to perform a qualitative assessment and determine the fair value more likely than not exceeds the carrying value, no further evaluation is necessary.
897077_14_ITEM7_P60_S0	For reporting units where we perform the two-step process, the first step requires us to compare the fair value of each reporting unit, which we primarily determine using an income approach based on the present value of discounted cash flows, to the respective carrying value, which includes goodwill.
897077_14_ITEM7_P60_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying value, the goodwill is not considered impaired.
897077_14_ITEM7_P60_S2	If the carrying value is higher than the fair value, there is an indication that an impairment may exist and the second step is required.
897077_14_ITEM7_P61_S0	In step two, the implied fair value of goodwill is calculated as the excess of the fair value of a reporting unit over the fair values assigned to its assets and liabilities.
897077_14_ITEM7_P61_S1	If the implied fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value of the reporting unit's goodwill, the difference is recognized as an impairment loss.
897077_14_ITEM7_P62_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_14_ITEM7_P62_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_14_ITEM7_P62_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_14_ITEM7_P62_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.
897077_14_ITEM7_P63_S0	As of December 31, 2013 , goodwill was $ 32,073,000 , which represents 7% of total assets.
897077_14_ITEM7_P64_S0	The Company recognized no goodwill impairment in 2013.
897077_14_ITEM7_P64_S1	The Company recognized goodwill impairment at one of its French operations, Faucheux of $ 656,000 in 2012 and at two of its French operations, SMA and Rousseau of $1,898,000 in 2011.
897077_14_ITEM7_P64_S2	The primary reason for the goodwill impairment in 2012 and 2011 was the general economic downturn that continues to affect the Company's European operations.
897077_14_ITEM7_P64_S3	This caused the Company to revise its expectations about future revenue, which is a significant factor in the discounted cash flow analysis used to estimate the fair value of the Company's reporting units.
897077_14_ITEM7_P64_S4	During the 2013 impairment analysis review, we performed a sensitivity analysis for goodwill impairment with respect to each of our reporting units and determined that a hypothetical 15% decline in the fair value of each reporting unit as of December 31, 2013 would not result in an impairment of goodwill for any of the reporting units.
897077_14_ITEM7_P65_S0	During the 2012 impairment analysis review, it was noted that even though the Schwarze and Rivard reporting units' fair value was above carrying value, it was not materially different.
897077_14_ITEM7_P65_S1	On December 31, 2013 , there was approximately $6.9 million and $12.3 million of goodwill related to the Schwarze and Rivard reporting units, respectively.
897077_14_ITEM7_P65_S2	These reporting units would be most likely affected by changes in the Company s assumptions and estimates.
897077_14_ITEM7_P65_S3	The calculation of fair value could increase or decrease depending on changes in the inputs and assumptions used, such as changes in the reporting unit s future growth rates, discount rates, etc.
897077_14_ITEM7_P66_S0	Management believes that the estimated valuations it arrived at are reasonable and consistent with what other marketplace participants would use in valuing the Company's components.
897077_14_ITEM7_P66_S1	However, management cannot give any assurance that these market values will not change in the future.
897077_14_ITEM7_P66_S2	For example, if discount rates demanded by the market increase, this could lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_14_ITEM7_P66_S3	If the Company's projections are not achieved in the future, this could lead management to reassess their assumptions and lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_14_ITEM7_P66_S4	If the market price of the Company's stock decreases, this could cause the Company to reassess the reasonableness of the implied control premium, which might cause management to assume a higher discount rate under the income approach which could lead to reduced valuations.
897077_14_ITEM7_P66_S5	If future similar transactions exhibit lower multiples than those observed in the past, this could lead to reduced valuations under the similar transactions approach.
897077_14_ITEM7_P66_S6	And finally, if there is a general decline in the stock market and particularly in those companies selected as comparable to the Company's components, this could lead to reduced valuations under the public company market multiple approach.
897077_14_ITEM7_P67_S0	The Company's annual impairment test is performed during the fourth quarter of each fiscal year.
897077_14_ITEM7_P67_S1	Given the current market conditions and continued economic uncertainty, the fair value of the Company's components could deteriorate which could result in the need to record impairment charges in future periods.
897077_14_ITEM7_P67_S2	The Company also monitors potential triggering events including changes in the business climate in which it operates, attrition of key personnel, volatility in the capital markets, the Company's market capitalization compared to its book value, the Company's recent operating performance, and the Company's financial projections.
897077_14_ITEM7_P67_S3	The occurrence of one or more triggering events could require additional impairment testing, which could result in future impairment charges.
897077_14_ITEM7_P67_S4	In particular, since the Schwarze and Rivard , reporting units' carrying value are not materially different from fair value, any changes to the Company's assumptions could lead to an indicated impairment in step one, requiring the Company to proceed to step two and potentially record an impairment charge.
897077_14_ITEM7_P67_S5	See Note 6 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for more information regarding goodwill.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The Company is exposed to various financial market risks.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market prices and rates.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The Company does not enter into derivative or other financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P2_S0	A portion of the Company s operations consists of manufacturing and sales activities in international jurisdictions.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The Company manufactures its products primarily in the United States, the U.K., France, Canada and Australia.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P2_S2	The Company sells its products primarily within the markets where the products are produced, but certain of the Company s sales from its U.K. and Canadian operations are denominated in other currencies.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P2_S3	As a result, the Company s financials, specifically the value of its foreign assets, could be affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency exchange rates or weak economic conditions in the other markets in which the subsidiaries of the Company distribute their products.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P3_S0	To mitigate the short-term effect of changes in currency exchange rates on the Company s functional currency-based sales, the Company s U.K. and Canadian subsidiaries regularly enter into foreign exchange contracts to hedge over 90% of its future net foreign currency cash receipts over a period of six months.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P3_S1	As of December 31, 2013 , the Company had $ 2,884,000 outstanding in forward exchange contracts related to accounts receivable.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P3_S2	A 15% fluctuation in exchange rates for these currencies would change the fair value by approximately $ 433,000 .
897077_14_ITEM7A_P3_S3	However, since these contracts hedge foreign currency denominated transactions, any change in the fair value of the contracts should be offset by changes in the underlying value of the transaction being hedged.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P4_S0	On December 31, 2013 , the fair value of these agreements was in an unfavorable position; therefore, the derivative financial instruments were recorded as a gain of $17,000 , which has been recognized in other income (expense), net.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The Company s earnings are affected by fluctuations in the value of the U.S. dollar as compared to foreign currencies, predominantly in European countries, Canada and Australia, as a result of the sale of its products in international markets.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Foreign currency forward exchange contracts in the U.K. are used to hedge against the earnings effects of such fluctuations.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P5_S2	On December 31, 2013 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have resulted in a decrease in gross profit of $ 5,475,000 .
897077_14_ITEM7A_P5_S3	Comparatively, on December 31, 2012 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have resulted in a decrease in gross profit of approximately $ 5,275,000 .
897077_14_ITEM7A_P6_S0	This calculation assumes that each exchange rate would change in the same direction relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P6_S1	In addition to the direct effects of changes in exchange rates, which are a changed dollar value of the resulting sales, changes in exchange rates may also affect the volume of sales or the foreign currency sales price as competitors products become more or less attractive.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P6_S2	The Company s sensitivity analysis of the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates does not factor in a potential change in sales levels or local currency prices.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P6_S3	The translation adjustment during 2013 was a loss of $479,000 .
897077_14_ITEM7A_P6_S4	On December 31, 2013 , the British pound closed at 0.6040 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.7275 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P6_S5	By comparison, on December 31, 2012 , the British pound closed at 0.6155 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.7579 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P6_S6	No assurance can be given as to future valuation of the British pound or Euro or how further movements in those or other currencies could affect future earnings or the financial position of the Company.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P7_S0	Interest Rate Risk The majority of the Company s long-term debt bears interest at variable rates.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P7_S1	Accordingly, the Company s net income is affected by changes in interest rates.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P7_S2	Assuming the average level of borrowings at variable rates and a two hundred basis point change in the 2013 average interest rate under these borrowings, the Company s 2013 interest expense would have changed by approximately $ 50,000 .
897077_14_ITEM7A_P8_S0	In the event of an adverse change in interest rates, management could take actions to mitigate its exposure.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P8_S1	Further, this analysis does not consider the effects of the change in the level of overall economic activity that could exist in such an environment.
897077_14_ITEM7A_P8_S2	However, challenges affecting the banking industry and credit markets in general can potentially cause changes to credit availability and cost of borrowing which creates a level of uncertainty.

897077_14_ITEM15_P12_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
897077_14_ITEM15_P12_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
897077_14_ITEM15_P13_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
897077_14_ITEM15_P13_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
897077_14_ITEM15_P14_S0	In our opinion, Alamo Group Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2013 , based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (1992) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.

897077_14_ITEM15_P34_S0	Goodwill consists of the excess of the purchase price over the fair value of identifiable net assets of businesses acquired.
897077_14_ITEM15_P34_S1	We perform our annual goodwill impairment test as of October 1 and monitor for interim triggering events on an ongoing basis.
897077_14_ITEM15_P35_S0	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment utilizing a qualitative assessment or a two-step process.
897077_14_ITEM15_P35_S1	We have an option to make a qualitative assessment of a reporting unit's goodwill for impairment.
897077_14_ITEM15_P35_S2	If we choose to perform a qualitative assessment and determine the fair value more likely than not exceeds the carrying value, no further evaluation is necessary.
897077_14_ITEM15_P36_S0	For reporting units where we perform the two-step process, the first step requires us to compare the fair value of each reporting unit, which we primarily determine using an income approach based on the present value of discounted cash flows, to the respective carrying value, which includes goodwill.
897077_14_ITEM15_P36_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying value, the goodwill is not considered impaired.
897077_14_ITEM15_P36_S2	If the carrying value is higher than the fair value, there is an indication that an impairment may exist and the second step is required.
897077_14_ITEM15_P37_S0	In step two, the implied fair value of goodwill is calculated as the excess of the fair value of a reporting unit over the fair values assigned to its assets and liabilities.
897077_14_ITEM15_P37_S1	If the implied fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value of the reporting unit's goodwill, the difference is recognized as an impairment loss.
897077_14_ITEM15_P38_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_14_ITEM15_P38_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_14_ITEM15_P38_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_14_ITEM15_P38_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.
897077_14_ITEM15_P39_S0	As of December 31, 2013 , goodwill was $ 32,073,000 , which represents 7% of total assets.
897077_14_ITEM15_P40_S0	The Company recognized no goodwill impairment in 2013.
897077_14_ITEM15_P40_S1	The Company recognized goodwill impairment at one of its French operations, Faucheux , of $ 656,000 in 2012 and two of its French operations, SMA and Rousseau , of $1,898,000 in 2011.
897077_14_ITEM15_P40_S2	The primary reason for the goodwill impairment in 2012 and 2011 was the general economic downturn that continues to affect the Company's European operations.
897077_14_ITEM15_P40_S3	This caused the Company to revise its expectations about future revenue, which is a significant factor in the discounted cash flow analysis used to estimate the fair value of the Company's reporting units.
897077_14_ITEM15_P40_S4	During the 2013 impairment analysis review, we performed a sensitivity analysis for goodwill impairment with respect to each of our reporting units and determined that a hypothetical 15% decline in the fair value of each reporting unit as of December 31, 2013 would not result in an impairment of goodwill for any of the reporting units.
897077_14_ITEM15_P41_S0	During the 2012 impairment analysis review, it was noted that even though the Schwarze and Rivard reporting units' fair value was above carrying value, it was not materially different.
897077_14_ITEM15_P41_S1	On December 31, 2013 , there was approximately $6.9 million and $12.3 million of goodwill related to the Schwarze and Rivard reporting units, respectively.
897077_14_ITEM15_P41_S2	These reporting units would be most likely affected by changes in the Company s assumptions and estimates.
897077_14_ITEM15_P41_S3	The calculation of fair value could increase or decrease depending on changes in the inputs and assumptions used, such as changes in the reporting unit s future growth rates, discount rates, etc.
897077_14_ITEM15_P42_S0	Management believes that the estimated valuations it arrived at are reasonable and consistent with what other marketplace participants would use in valuing the Company's components.
897077_14_ITEM15_P42_S1	However, management cannot give any assurance that these market values will not change in the future.
897077_14_ITEM15_P42_S2	For example, if discount rates demanded by the market increase, this could lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_14_ITEM15_P42_S3	If the Company's projections are not achieved in the future, this could lead management to reassess their assumptions and lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_14_ITEM15_P42_S4	If the market price of the Company's stock decreases, this could cause the Company to reassess the reasonableness of the implied control premium, which might cause management to assume a higher discount rate under the income approach which could lead to reduced valuations.
897077_14_ITEM15_P42_S5	If future similar transactions exhibit lower multiples than those observed in the past, this could lead to reduced valuations under the similar transactions approach.
897077_14_ITEM15_P42_S6	And finally, if there is a general decline in the stock market and particularly in those companies selected as comparable to the Company's components, this could lead to reduced valuations under the public company market multiple approach.
897077_14_ITEM15_P43_S0	Given the current market conditions and continued economic uncertainty, the fair value of the Company's components could deteriorate which could result in the need to record impairment charges in future periods.
897077_14_ITEM15_P43_S1	The Company also monitors potential triggering events including changes in the business climate in which it operates, attrition of key personnel, volatility in the capital markets, the Company's market capitalization compared to its book value, the Company's recent operating performance, and the Company's financial projections.
897077_14_ITEM15_P43_S2	The occurrence of one or more triggering events could require additional impairment testing, which could result in future impairment charges.
897077_14_ITEM15_P43_S3	In particular, since the Schwarze and Rivard reporting units' carrying values are not materially different from fair value, any changes to the Company's assumptions could lead to an indicated impairment in step one, requiring the Company to proceed to step two and potentially record an impairment charge.

897077_14_ITEM15_P73_S0	3. VALUATION AND QUALIFYING ACCOUNTS Valuation and qualifying accounts included the following:
897077_14_ITEM15_P74_S0	The Company evaluates the collectability of its accounts receivable based on a combination of factors.
897077_14_ITEM15_P74_S1	In circumstances where it is aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the Company records a specific reserve to reduce the amounts recorded to what it believes will be collected.
897077_14_ITEM15_P74_S2	For all other customers, it recognizes reserves for bad debt based on historical experience of bad debts as a percent of revenues for each business unit, adjusted for relative improvements or deteriorations in the aging and changes in current economic conditions.
897077_14_ITEM15_P75_S0	The Company evaluates all receivables that are over 60 days old and will reserve specifically on a 90 -day basis.
897077_14_ITEM15_P76_S0	The Company has a secured or insured interest on most of its wholegoods that each customer purchases.
897077_14_ITEM15_P76_S1	This allows the Company, in times of a difficult economy when the customer is unable to pay or has filed for bankruptcy, to repossess its inventory.
897077_14_ITEM15_P76_S2	This also allows Alamo Group to maintain only a reserve over its cost, which usually represents the margin on the original sales price.

897077_14_ITEM15_P77_S1	The decrease was mainly from the Company s Industrial Division.

897077_14_ITEM15_P81_S0	The Company had a reserve of $ 8,596,000 on December 31, 2013 and $ 9,099,000 on December 31, 2012 to cover obsolete and slow moving inventory.
897077_14_ITEM15_P81_S1	The decrease in the reserve was mainly from the Industrial Division and to a lesser extent the Company's Agricultural Division.
897077_14_ITEM15_P82_S0	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three -year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent ; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three -year supply.
897077_14_ITEM15_P82_S1	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_14_ITEM15_P82_S2	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_14_ITEM15_P82_S3	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three -year history has been established.
897077_14_ITEM15_P83_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood units and 90 days on parts though some components can have warranty for longer terms.
897077_14_ITEM15_P84_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety -day to six -month lag period.
897077_14_ITEM15_P84_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the unit to file a warranty claim.
897077_14_ITEM15_P84_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_14_ITEM15_P84_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.
897077_14_ITEM15_P85_S0	The current liability warranty reserve balance was $ 4,994,000 on December 31, 2013 and $ 5,007,000 on December 31, 2012 .
897077_14_ITEM15_P86_S0	Inventories valued at LIFO represented 55% and 56% of total inventory for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
897077_14_ITEM15_P86_S1	The excess of current costs over LIFO-valued inventories was $ 9,483,000 and $ 8,975,000 on December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012 , respectively.
897077_14_ITEM15_P86_S2	(The $ 508,000 increase in LIFO reserve during 2013 came from reductions in inventory levels within U.S. operations.

897077_14_ITEM15_P96_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS Fair value is defined as the exchange price that would be received for an asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit price) in the principal or most advantageous market for the asset or liability in an orderly transaction between market participants.
897077_14_ITEM15_P97_S0	There is a three-tier fair value hierarchy based upon the observability of inputs used in valuation techniques.
897077_14_ITEM15_P98_S0	while unobservable inputs (lowest level) reflect internally developed market assumptions.
897077_14_ITEM15_P98_S1	In fair value measurements are classified under the following hierarchy:
897077_14_ITEM15_P99_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices for identical instruments in active markets.
897077_14_ITEM15_P99_S1	Level 2 Quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets; quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active; and model-derived valuations in which all significant inputs or significant value-drivers are observable in active markets.
897077_14_ITEM15_P100_S0	The Company uses quoted market prices, when available, to determine fair value, and the Company classifies such measurements within Level 1.
897077_14_ITEM15_P100_S1	In some cases where market prices are not available, the Company makes use of observable market-based inputs to calculate fair value, in which case the measurements are classified with Level 2.
897077_14_ITEM15_P101_S0	If quoted or observable market prices are not available, fair value is based upon internally developed models that use, where possible, current market-based parameters such as interest rates, yield curves, currency rates, etc.
897077_14_ITEM15_P101_S1	These measurements are classified within Level 3.
897077_14_ITEM15_P102_S0	Fair value measurements are classified to the lowest level input or value-driver that is significant to the valuation.
897077_14_ITEM15_P102_S1	A measurement may therefore be classified within Level 3 even though there may be significant inputs that are readily observable.

897077_14_ITEM15_P138_S0	The Company employs a building block approach in determining the expected long-term rate on return on plan assets.
897077_14_ITEM15_P138_S1	Historical markets are studied and long-term historical relationships between equities and fixed income are preserved consistent with the widely accepted capital market principle that assets with higher volatility generate a greater return over the long run.
897077_14_ITEM15_P138_S2	Current market factors such as inflation and interest rates are evaluated before long-term market assumptions are determined.
897077_14_ITEM15_P138_S3	The long-term portfolio return is established via a building block approach with proper consideration of diversification and rebalancing.
897077_14_ITEM15_P138_S4	Peer data and historical returns are reviewed to check for reasonability and appropriateness.

897077_14_ITEM15_P141_S1	Risk tolerance is established through careful consideration of plan liabilities, plan funded status, and corporate financial condition.
897077_14_ITEM15_P142_S0	The investment portfolio contains a diversified blend of equity and fixed income investments.
897077_14_ITEM15_P142_S1	Furthermore, equity investments are diversified across U.S. and non-U.S. stocks, as well as growth, value, and small and large capitalizations.
897077_14_ITEM15_P142_S2	Other assets such as real estate, private equity, and hedge funds are used judiciously to enhance long-term returns while improving portfolio diversification.
897077_14_ITEM15_P142_S3	Derivatives may be used to gain market exposure in an efficient and timely manner; however, derivatives may not be used to leverage the portfolio beyond the market value of the underlying investments.

897077_14_ITEM15_P151_S0	The Board of Directors of the Company adopted the Alamo Group Inc. Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (the SERP ), effective as of January 3, 2011.
897077_14_ITEM15_P151_S1	The SERP will benefit certain key management or other highly compensated employees of the Company and/or certain subsidiaries who are selected by the Compensation Committee and approved by the Board to participate.
897077_14_ITEM15_P152_S0	The SERP is intended to provide a benefit from the Company upon retirement, death or disability, or a change in control of the Company.
897077_14_ITEM15_P152_S1	Accordingly, the SERP obligates the Company to pay to a participant a Retirement Benefit (as defined in the SERP) upon the occurrence of certain payment events to the extent a participant has a vested right thereto.
897077_14_ITEM15_P152_S2	A participant s right to his or her Retirement Benefit becomes vested in the Company s contributions upon 10 years of Credited Service (as defined in the SERP) or a change in control of the Company.
897077_14_ITEM15_P152_S3	The Retirement Benefit is based on 20% of the final three -year average salary of each participant on or after his or her normal retirement age ( 65 years of age).
897077_14_ITEM15_P152_S4	In the event of the participant s death or a change in control, the participant s vested retirement benefit will be paid in a lump sum to the participant or his or her estate, as applicable, within 90 days after the participant s death or a change in control, as applicable.
897077_14_ITEM15_P152_S5	In the event the participant is entitled to a benefit from the SERP due to disability, retirement or other termination of employment, the benefit will be paid in monthly installments over a period of fifteen years.
897077_14_ITEM15_P153_S0	The Company records amounts relating to the SERP based on calculations that incorporate various actuarial and other assumptions, including discount rates, rate of compensation increases, retirement dates and life expectancies.
897077_14_ITEM15_P153_S1	The net periodic costs are recognized as employees render the services necessary to earn the SERP benefits.

897077_14_ITEM15_P174_S0	Like other manufacturers, the Company is subject to a broad range of federal, state, local and foreign laws and requirements, including those concerning air emissions, discharges into waterways, and the generation, handling, storage, transportation, treatment and disposal of hazardous substances and waste materials, as well as the remediation of contamination associated with releases of hazardous substances at the Company s facilities and offsite disposal locations, workplace safety and equal employment opportunities.

897077_14_ITEM15_P176_S0	The Company knows that its Indianola, Iowa property is contaminated with chromium which most likely resulted from chrome plating operations which were discontinued before the Company purchased the property.
897077_14_ITEM15_P176_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.
897077_14_ITEM15_P176_S2	The Company voluntarily worked with an environmental consultant and the state of Iowa with respect to these issues and believes it completed its remediation program in June 2006.
897077_14_ITEM15_P176_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_14_ITEM15_P176_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_14_ITEM15_P176_S5	We received a conditional no further action letter in January of 2009.
897077_14_ITEM15_P176_S6	When we demonstrate stable or improving conditions below residential standards for a certain period of time by monitoring existing wells, we will request an unconditional no further action letter.
897077_14_ITEM15_P177_S0	The Company knows that Bush Hog s main manufacturing property in Selma, Alabama was contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic compounds which most likely resulted from painting and cleaning operations during the 1960s and 1970s.
897077_14_ITEM15_P177_S1	The contaminated areas were primarily in the location of underground storage tanks and underneath the former waste storage area.
897077_14_ITEM15_P177_S2	Under the Asset Purchase Agreement, Bush Hog s prior owner agreed to and has removed the underground storage tanks at its cost and has remediated the identified contamination in accordance with the regulations of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management.
897077_14_ITEM15_P177_S3	An environmental consulting firm was retained by the prior owner to administer the cleanup and monitor the site on an ongoing basis until the remediation program is complete and approved by the applicable authorities.
897077_14_ITEM15_P178_S0	In December of 2012, a federal district court jury in Louisiana found that Gradall was unjustly enriched in the amount of $1,000,000 plus interest when it sold several telescopic fire apparatuses after properly terminating what the jury determined to be an enforceable contract with the plaintiff, a fire truck manufacturer.
897077_14_ITEM15_P178_S1	Gradall is appealing the decision and has reserved the full amount.
897077_14_ITEM15_P179_S0	Alamo Group Inc. and Bush Hog, Inc. were added as defendants in 2013 to ongoing litigation by Deere Company as plaintiff against Bush Hog, LLC (now Duroc, LLC) and Great Plains Manufacturing Incorporated, in which Deere alleged infringement of a mower-related patent.
897077_14_ITEM15_P179_S1	The jury concluded that not only did the defendants not infringe the patent but that the patent was invalid as well.
897077_14_ITEM15_P179_S2	The Company expensed $2,100,000 in legal fees related to this lawsuit in 2013.

897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S0	ARTICLE II MEETINGS OF STOCKHOLDERS Section 1. Time and Place of Meetings .
897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S1	All meetings of the stockholders for the election of directors shall be held at such time and place, either within or without the State of Delaware, as shall be designated from time to time by the Board of Directors and stated in the notice of the meeting.
897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S2	Meetings of stockholders for any other purpose may be held at such time and place, within or without the State of Delaware, as shall be stated in the notice of the meeting or in a duly executed waiver of notice thereof.
897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S3	Annual meetings of stockholders, commencing with the year 1988, shall be held on such date and at such time as shall be designated from time to time by the Board of Directors and stated in the notice of the meeting, at which meeting the stockholders shall elect new members of the Board of Directors in accordance with the Certificate of Incorporation and transact such other business as may properly be brought before the meeting.
897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S4	The Board of Directors may postpone, reschedule or cancel any annual meeting of stockholders previously scheduled by the Board of Directors.
897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S5	Written notice of the annual meeting, stating the place, date, and hour of the meeting, shall be given to each stockholder of record entitled to vote at such meeting not less than 10 or more than 60 days before the date of the meeting.
897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S6	Special meetings of the stockholders for any purpose or purposes, unless otherwise prescribed by statute or by the Certificate of Incorporation, may be called at any time by order of the Board of Directors and shall be called by the Chairman of the Board, the President, or the Secretary at the request in writing of a majority of the Board of Directors.
897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S7	Such request shall state the purpose or purposes of the proposed special meeting.
897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S8	Business transacted at any special meeting of stockholders shall be limited to the purposes stated in the notice.
897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S9	The ability of the stockholders of the Corporation to call a special meeting of stockholders is hereby specifically denied.
897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S10	The Board of Directors may postpone, reschedule or cancel any special meeting of stockholders previously scheduled by the Board of Directors.
897077_14_ITEM15_P192_S11	Written notice of a special meeting, stating the place, date and hour of the meeting and the purpose or purposes for which the meeting is called, shall be given to each stockholder of record entitled to vote at such meeting not less than 10 or more than 60 days before the date of the meeting.

897077_14_ITEM15_P194_S3	The Board of Directors may adopt such rules and regulations for the conduct of any meeting of stockholders as it shall deem appropriate.
897077_14_ITEM15_P194_S4	Except to the extent inconsistent with such rules and regulations as adopted by the Board of Directors, the chairman of any meeting of stockholders shall have the right and authority to convene and (for any or no reason) to recess or adjourn the meeting and to prescribe such rules, regulations and procedures and to do all such acts as, in the judgment of such chairman, are appropriate for the proper conduct of the meeting.
897077_14_ITEM15_P194_S5	Such rules, regulations or procedures, whether adopted by the Board of Directors or prescribed by the chairman of the meeting, may include, without limitation, the following: (i) the establishment of an agenda or order of business for the meeting; (ii) the determination of when the polls shall open and close for any given matter to be voted on at the meeting; (iii) rules and procedures for maintaining order at the meeting and the safety of those present; (iv) limitations on attendance at or participation in the meeting to stockholders of record of the Corporation, their duly authorized and constituted proxies or such other persons as the chairman of the meeting shall determine; (v) restrictions on entry to the meeting after the time fixed for the commencement thereof; and (vi) limitations on the time allotted to questions or comments by participants.
897077_14_ITEM15_P194_S6	Except to the extent determined by the Board of Directors or the person presiding over the meeting, meetings of stockholders shall not be required to be held in accordance with the rules of parliamentary procedure.

897077_14_ITEM15_P195_S3	(b) (i) Except as otherwise provided in this Section 9(b) of Article II, each director shall be elected by the vote of the majority of the votes cast with respect to that director s election at any meeting for the election of directors at which a quorum is present, provided that if, as of the tenth day preceding the date the Corporation first mails its notice of meeting for such meeting to the stockholders of the Corporation, the number of nominees exceeds the number of directors to be elected (a Contested Election ), the directors shall be elected by the vote of a plurality of the votes cast.
897077_14_ITEM15_P195_S4	For purposes of this Section 9(b) of Article II, a majority of votes cast shall mean that the number of votes cast for a director s election exceeds the number of votes cast against that director s election (with abstentions and broker non-votes not counted as a vote cast either for or against that director s election).
897077_14_ITEM15_P195_S5	(ii) Subject to Section 14 of Article II of these By-Laws, in order for any incumbent director to become a nominee of the Board of Directors for further service on the Board of Directors, such person must submit an irrevocable resignation, provided that such resignation shall be effective if (A) that person shall not receive a majority of the votes cast in an election that is not a Contested Election and (B) the Board of Directors shall accept that resignation in accordance with the policies and procedures adopted by the Board of Directors for such purpose.
897077_14_ITEM15_P195_S6	In the event an incumbent director fails to receive a majority of the votes cast in an election that is not a Contested Election, the nominating/corporate governance committee of the Board of Directors, or such other committee designated by the Board of Directors pursuant to Article III of these By-Laws, shall make a recommendation to the Board of Directors as to whether to accept or reject the resignation of such incumbent director, or whether other action should be taken.
897077_14_ITEM15_P195_S7	The Board of Directors shall act on the resignation, taking into account the committee s recommendation, and publicly disclose (by a press release and filing an appropriate disclosure with the Securities and Exchange Commission) its decision regarding the resignation and, if such resignation is rejected, the rationale behind the decision within 90 days following certification of the election results.
897077_14_ITEM15_P195_S8	(iii) If the Board of Directors accepts a director s resignation pursuant to this Section 9(b) of Article II, or if a nominee for director is not elected and the nominee is not an incumbent director, then the Board of Directors may fill the resulting vacancy pursuant to Section 5 of Article III of these By-Laws or may decrease the size of the Board of Directors pursuant to the provisions of Section 2 of Article III of these By-Laws.
897077_14_ITEM15_P195_S9	(c) Unless demanded by a stockholder of the Corporation present in person or by proxy at any meeting of the stockholders and entitled to vote thereat, or so directed by the chairman of the meeting, the vote thereat on any question other than the election or removal of directors need not be by written ballot.
897077_14_ITEM15_P195_S10	Upon a demand of any such stockholder for a vote by written ballot on any question or at the direction of such chairman that a vote by written ballot be taken on any question, such vote shall be taken by written ballot.

897077_14_ITEM15_P197_S0	It shall be the duty of the Secretary or other officer of the Corporation who shall have charge of its stock ledger, either directly or through another officer of the Corporation designated by him or through a transfer agent appointed by the Board of Directors, to prepare and make, at least 10 days before every meeting of the stockholders, a complete list of the stockholders entitled to vote thereat, arranged in alphabetical order, and showing the address of each stockholder and the number of shares registered in the name of each stockholder.
897077_14_ITEM15_P197_S1	Such list shall be open to the examination of any stockholder, for any purpose germane to the meeting, during ordinary business hours, for a period of at least 10 days before said meeting, either at a place within the city where said meeting is to be held, which place shall be specified in the notice of said meeting, or, if not so specified, at the place where said meeting is to be held.
897077_14_ITEM15_P197_S2	The list shall also be produced and kept at the time and place of said meeting during the whole time thereof, and may be inspected by any stockholder of record who shall be present thereat.

897077_14_ITEM15_P198_S1	Such Inspectors of Votes, if any, shall take charge of the ballots, if any, at such meeting and, after the balloting thereat on any question, shall count the ballots cast thereon and shall make a report in writing to the secretary of such meeting of the results thereof.
897077_14_ITEM15_P198_S2	An Inspector of Votes need not be a stockholder of the Corporation, and any officer of the Corporation may be an Inspector of Votes on any question other than a vote for or against his election to any position with the Corporation or on any other question in which he may be directly interested.
