897077_15_ITEM1A_P49_S0	The Company knows that its Indianola, Iowa property is contaminated with chromium which most likely resulted from chrome plating operations which were discontinued before the Company purchased the property.
897077_15_ITEM1A_P49_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.
897077_15_ITEM1A_P49_S2	The Company voluntarily worked with an environmental consultant and the state of Iowa with respect to these issues and believes it completed its remediation program in June 2006.
897077_15_ITEM1A_P49_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_15_ITEM1A_P49_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_15_ITEM1A_P49_S5	We received a conditional no further action letter in January of 2009.
897077_15_ITEM1A_P49_S6	When we demonstrate stable or improving conditions below residential standards for a certain period of time by monitoring existing wells, we will request an unconditional no further action letter.
897077_15_ITEM1A_P50_S0	The Company knows that Bush Hog s main manufacturing property in Selma, Alabama was contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic compounds which most likely resulted from painting and cleaning operations during the 1960s and 1970s.
897077_15_ITEM1A_P50_S1	The contaminated areas were primarily in the location of underground storage tanks and underneath the former waste storage area.
897077_15_ITEM1A_P50_S2	Under the Asset Purchase Agreement, Bush Hog s prior owner agreed to and has removed the underground storage tanks at its cost and has remediated the identified contamination in accordance with the regulations of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management.
897077_15_ITEM1A_P50_S3	An environmental consulting firm was retained by the prior owner to administer the cleanup and monitor the site on an ongoing basis until the remediation program is complete and approved by the applicable authorities.
897077_15_ITEM1A_P51_S0	Certain properties of the Company contain asbestos that may have to be remediated over time and it could be additional expense to the Company.

897077_15_ITEM3_P0_S0	Like other manufacturers, the Company is subject to a broad range of federal, state, local and foreign laws and requirements, including those concerning air emissions, discharges into waterways, and the generation, handling, storage, transportation, treatment and disposal of hazardous substances and waste materials, as well as the remediation of contamination associated with releases of hazardous substances at the Company s facilities and off-site disposal locations, workplace safety and equal employment opportunities.
897077_15_ITEM3_P0_S1	These laws and regulations are constantly changing, and it is impossible to predict with accuracy the effect that changes to such laws and regulations may have on the Company in the future.
897077_15_ITEM3_P1_S0	Like other industrial concerns, the Company s manufacturing operations entail the risk of noncompliance, and there can be no assurance that the Company will not incur material costs or other liabilities as a result thereof.
897077_15_ITEM3_P2_S0	The Company knows that its Indianola, Iowa property is contaminated with chromium which most likely resulted from chrome plating operations which were discontinued before the Company purchased the property.
897077_15_ITEM3_P2_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.
897077_15_ITEM3_P2_S2	The Company voluntarily worked with an environmental consultant and the state of Iowa with respect to these issues and believes it completed its remediation program in June 2006.
897077_15_ITEM3_P2_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_15_ITEM3_P2_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_15_ITEM3_P2_S5	We received a conditional no further action letter in January of 2009.
897077_15_ITEM3_P2_S6	When we demonstrate stable or improving conditions below residential standards for a certain period of time by monitoring existing wells, we will request an unconditional no further action letter.
897077_15_ITEM3_P3_S0	The Company knows that Bush Hog s main manufacturing property in Selma, Alabama was contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic compounds which most likely resulted from painting and cleaning operations during the 1960s and 1970s.
897077_15_ITEM3_P3_S1	The contaminated areas were primarily in the location of underground storage tanks and underneath the former waste storage area.
897077_15_ITEM3_P3_S2	Under the Asset Purchase Agreement, Bush Hog s prior owner agreed to and has removed the underground storage tanks at its cost and has remediated the identified contamination in accordance with the regulations of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management.
897077_15_ITEM3_P3_S3	An environmental consulting firm was retained by the prior owner to administer the cleanup and monitor the site on an ongoing basis until the remediation program is complete and approved by the applicable authorities.
897077_15_ITEM3_P4_S0	In December of 2012, a federal district court jury in Louisiana found that Gradall was unjustly enriched in the amount of $1,000,000 plus interest when it sold several telescopic fire apparatuses after properly terminating what the jury determined to be an enforceable contract with the plaintiff, a fire truck manufacturer.
897077_15_ITEM3_P4_S1	Gradall appealed the decision and reserved the full amount.
897077_15_ITEM3_P4_S2	In September of 2014, the case was overturned by the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals which found in Gradall's favor.
897077_15_ITEM3_P4_S3	The plaintiff's final option was to appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court which it did not, affirming the Court of Appeals decision in favor of Gradall .
897077_15_ITEM3_P4_S4	During the fourth quarter of 2014, the Company released the $1,250,000 it had previously reserved for this matter.
897077_15_ITEM3_P5_S0	Alamo Group Inc. and Bush Hog , Inc. were added as defendants in 2013 to ongoing litigation by Deere Company as plaintiff against Bush Hog , LLC (now Duroc, LLC) and Great Plains Manufacturing Incorporated, in which Deere alleged infringement of a mower-related patent.
897077_15_ITEM3_P5_S1	The jury concluded that not only did the defendants not infringe the patent but that the patent was invalid as well.
897077_15_ITEM3_P5_S2	The Company expensed $2,100,000 in legal fees related to this lawsuit in 2013.
897077_15_ITEM3_P5_S3	Deere Company has appealed and is requesting a new trial.
897077_15_ITEM3_P6_S0	Certain properties of the Company contain asbestos that may have to be remediated over time.
897077_15_ITEM3_P6_S1	The Company believes that any subsequent change in the liability associated with the asbestos removal will not have a material adverse effect on the Company s consolidated financial position or results of operations.
897077_15_ITEM3_P7_S0	The Company is subject to various other federal, state, and local laws affecting its business, as well as a variety of regulations relating to such matters as working conditions, equal employment opportunities, and product safety.
897077_15_ITEM3_P7_S1	A variety of state laws regulate the Company s contractual relationships with its dealers, some of which impose restrictive standards on the relationship between the Company and its dealers, including events of default, grounds for termination, non-renewal of dealer contracts, and equipment repurchase requirements.

897077_15_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company s net sales in the fiscal year ended December 31, 2014 ( 2014 ) were $ 839,055,000 , an increase of $ 156,965,000 or 23.0% compared to $ 682,090,000 for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2013 ( 2013 ).
897077_15_ITEM7_P2_S1	The increase was mainly from the acquisitions of the Specialized business units contributing $107,370,000, Kellands contributing $8,201,000, Fieldquip contributing $2,178,000 and Superior contributing $1,941,000.
897077_15_ITEM7_P2_S2	Also, improved sales in the Company's North American Industrial Division, which was up 10.3%, excluding the impact of the acquisition of the Specialized business units, was a contributing factor.
897077_15_ITEM7_P2_S3	Agricultural Division sales excluding the acquisitions of Fieldquip and Superior were down 4.2% for 2014 mainly from declining crop prices, a weak overall agricultural market and adverse weather conditions throughout 2014.
897077_15_ITEM7_P2_S4	Sales in the European Division were up 9.5% in 2014 compared to 2013 as sales of UK products remained strong along with favorable exchange rates.
897077_15_ITEM7_P2_S5	Overall conditions in the European economy remain weak but showed some signs of improvement during 2014.
897077_15_ITEM7_P3_S0	North American Industrial sales (net) were $ 436,018,000 in 2014 compared to $ 297,857,000 in 2013 , an increase of $ 138,161,000 or 46.4% .
897077_15_ITEM7_P3_S1	The increase came primarily from the acquisition of the Specialized business units contributing $107,370,000.
897077_15_ITEM7_P3_S2	Also, favorably affecting sales were increases from mower, sweeper, excavator, vacuum trucks and snow equipment product lines.
897077_15_ITEM7_P4_S0	North American Agricultural sales (net) were $ 214,326,000 in 2014 compared to $ 219,354,000 in 2013 , representing a decrease of $ 5,028,000 or 2.3% .
897077_15_ITEM7_P4_S1	The decrease in sales compared to 2013 was from lower commodity prices and higher farm input costs that resulted in softer market conditions in the agricultural market.
897077_15_ITEM7_P4_S2	Also affecting this Division were the prolonged winter weather conditions during the first quarter of 2014 along with other pockets of adverse weather conditions through out the year.
897077_15_ITEM7_P4_S3	Excluding the impact of the acquisitions of Fieldquip and Superior , sales were down 4.2%.
897077_15_ITEM7_P5_S0	European sales (net) increased $ 23,832,000 or 14.5% to $ 188,711,000 in 2014 compared to $ 164,879,000 in 2013 .
897077_15_ITEM7_P5_S1	The increase in 2014 was partially due to the Kellands acquisition in the amount of $8,201,000 and improved sales in the UK operations as well as at Rivard in France.
897077_15_ITEM7_P5_S2	Also affecting sales favorably were changes in currency exchange rates.
897077_15_ITEM7_P5_S3	The European Division continued to be faced with challenging market conditions and both our governmental and agricultural markets were constrained by Europe's overall economic uncertainty.
897077_15_ITEM7_P6_S0	Gross margins for 2014 were $ 189,228,000 ( 22.6% of net sales) compared to $ 158,510,000 ( 23.2% of net sales) in 2013 , an increase of $ 30,718,000 .
897077_15_ITEM7_P6_S1	The increase in margin dollars was mainly due to the acquisitions of the Specialized business units, Fieldquip and Kellands contributing $27,677,000, and favorable performance in the Industrial and European Divisions.
897077_15_ITEM7_P6_S2	Negatively affecting both the gross margin and margin percentage during 2014 were inefficiencies from lower absorption on reduced sales volumes in the Agricultural Division as well as $2,578,000 in higher cost of goods sold related to the step-up in fair value of inventories acquired in the Specialized transaction.
897077_15_ITEM7_P7_S0	Selling, general and administrative expenses ( SG A ) were $ 126,564,000 ( 15.1% of net sales) in 2014 compared to $ 107,773,000 ( 15.8% of net sales) in 2013 .
897077_15_ITEM7_P7_S1	The increase of $ 18,791,000 in SG A in 2014 was primarily due to the acquisitions of the Specialized business units contributing $15,454,000 and Kellands and Fieldquip contributing $1,187,000.
897077_15_ITEM7_P7_S2	Also, there were $2,079,000 of acquisition expenses, $668,000 of costs related to the repurchase agreement with a long term major shareholder and the subsequent follow on offering of their remaining shares and $1,015,000 of additional stock option expense related to the accelerated vesting options to retirement eligible recipients.
897077_15_ITEM7_P7_S3	The Company also had increased trades show and advertising expenses, recruiting and relocation expenses and increased costs related to IT projects.

897077_15_ITEM7_P38_S0	The SEC adopted the conflict mineral rules under Section 1502 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act on August 22, 2012.
897077_15_ITEM7_P38_S1	The rules require public companies to disclose information about their use of specific minerals originating from and financing armed groups in the Democratic Republic of the Congo or adjoining countries.
897077_15_ITEM7_P38_S2	The conflict mineral rules cover minerals frequently used to manufacture a wide array of electronic and industrial products including semiconductor devices.
897077_15_ITEM7_P38_S3	The rules do not ban the use of minerals from conflict sources, but require SEC filings and public disclosure covering the calendar year 2014, though the public disclosure provision is being challenged in court.
897077_15_ITEM7_P38_S4	We have determined that we are subject to the rules and are evaluating our supply chain, developed processes to assess the impacts and file the required document before the May 2015 deadline.

897077_15_ITEM7_P39_S1	The guidance allows companies to have significant continuing involvement and continuing cash flows with the disposed component.
897077_15_ITEM7_P39_S2	The guidance is effective for annual and interim periods beginning on or after December 15, 2014 and is to be applied on a prospective basis.

897077_15_ITEM7_P40_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606), which supersedes the revenue recognition requirements in ASC Topic 605, Revenue Recognition, and most industry-specific guidance.
897077_15_ITEM7_P40_S1	This ASU is based on the principle that revenue is recognized to depict the transfer of goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
897077_15_ITEM7_P40_S2	The ASU also requires additional disclosure about the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from customer contracts, including significant judgments and changes in judgments, and assets recognized from costs incurred to obtain or fulfill a contract.
897077_15_ITEM7_P40_S3	The amendments in the ASU must be applied using either the retrospective or cumulative effect transition method and are effective for annual and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
897077_15_ITEM7_P40_S4	We will evaluate the effects, if any, that adoption of this guidance will have on our consolidated financial statements.

897077_15_ITEM7_P48_S0	An accounting policy is deemed to be critical if it requires an accounting estimate to be made based on assumptions about matters that are highly uncertain at the time the estimate is made, and if different estimates that reasonably could have been used, or changes in the accounting estimates that are reasonably likely to occur periodically, could materially impact the financial statements.
897077_15_ITEM7_P48_S1	Management believes the following critical accounting policies reflect its more significant estimates and assumptions used in the preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements.

897077_15_ITEM7_P49_S0	In the last ten years, we have acquired 14 businesses.
897077_15_ITEM7_P49_S1	The purchase prices of acquired businesses have been allocated to the tangible and intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed, based upon their estimated fair value at the date of purchase.
897077_15_ITEM7_P49_S2	The difference between the purchase price and the fair value of the net assets acquired is recorded as goodwill.
897077_15_ITEM7_P50_S0	Most of the businesses we have acquired did not have a significant amount of intangible assets.
897077_15_ITEM7_P50_S1	With the 2014 acquisition of Specialized we acquired a significant amount of intangible assets.
897077_15_ITEM7_P51_S0	intangible assets in the acquisition: trade name and trademarks, customer and dealer relationships, and patents, technology and drawings.
897077_15_ITEM7_P51_S1	We completed the fair value analysis of the acquired assets in the fourth quarter of 2014.
897077_15_ITEM7_P51_S2	In valuing certain acquired intangible assets, we used an excess earnings and relief from royalty methodologies, which are forms of discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_15_ITEM7_P52_S0	Tangible assets are typically valued using a replacement or reproduction cost approach, considering factors such as current prices of the same or similar equipment, the age of the equipment, and economic obsolescence.
897077_15_ITEM7_P53_S0	In making other assumptions on valuation and useful lives, we considered the unique nature of the acquisition and we utilized a third-party valuation firm to assist us in the valuation of the acquired intangibles and the resulting allocation of purchase price for the acquisition.

897077_15_ITEM7_P54_S0	The Company evaluates the collectability of its accounts receivable based on a combination of factors.
897077_15_ITEM7_P54_S1	In circumstances where it is aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the Company records a specific reserve to reduce the amounts recorded to what it believes will be collected.
897077_15_ITEM7_P55_S0	The Company evaluates all receivables that are over 60 days old and will reserve specifically on a 90-day basis.
897077_15_ITEM7_P56_S0	The Company has a secured or insured interest on most of its wholegoods that each customer purchases.
897077_15_ITEM7_P56_S1	This allows the Company, in times of a difficult economy when the customer is unable to pay or has filed for bankruptcy, to repossess its inventory.
897077_15_ITEM7_P56_S2	This also allows Alamo Group in certain instances, to maintain only a reserve over its cost, which usually represents the margin on the original sales price.

897077_15_ITEM7_P58_S0	On December 31, 2014 , the Company had $ 15,999,000 in reserves for sales discounts compared to $ 16,724,000 on December 31, 2013 on product shipped to our customers under various promotional programs.
897077_15_ITEM7_P58_S1	The decrease was due primarily to lower sales volume of the Company s agricultural products during the 2014 pre-season, which runs during the third and fourth quarters of each year with orders shipped through the second quarter of 2015.
897077_15_ITEM7_P59_S0	The Company reviews the reserve quarterly based on analysis made on each program outstanding at the time.
897077_15_ITEM7_P60_S0	The Company bases its reserves on historical data relating to discounts taken by the customer under each program.
897077_15_ITEM7_P60_S1	Historically, between 85% and 95% of the Company s customers who qualify for each program actually take the discount that is available.
897077_15_ITEM7_P61_S0	The Company had a reserve of $ 7,601,000 on December 31, 2014 and $ 8,596,000 on December 31, 2013 to cover obsolete and slow moving inventory.
897077_15_ITEM7_P61_S1	The decrease in the reserve was mainly from the Company's Agricultural Division.
897077_15_ITEM7_P62_S0	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three-year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three-year supply.
897077_15_ITEM7_P62_S1	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_15_ITEM7_P62_S2	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_15_ITEM7_P62_S3	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three-year history has been established.
897077_15_ITEM7_P63_S0	The reserve is reviewed and, if necessary, adjustments are made on a quarterly basis.
897077_15_ITEM7_P63_S1	The Company relies on historical information when available to support its reserve.
897077_15_ITEM7_P63_S2	The Company does not adjust the reserve balance until the inventory is liquidated.
897077_15_ITEM7_P64_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood units and 90 days on parts, though some components can have warranty for longer terms.
897077_15_ITEM7_P65_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety-day to six-month lag period.
897077_15_ITEM7_P65_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the unit to file a warranty claim.
897077_15_ITEM7_P65_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_15_ITEM7_P65_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.
897077_15_ITEM7_P66_S0	The current liability warranty reserve balance was $ 5,913,000 on December 31, 2014 and $ 4,994,000 on December 31, 2013 .
897077_15_ITEM7_P66_S1	The increase was primarily from the acquisition of Specialized in the amount of $1,006,000.
897077_15_ITEM7_P67_S0	We test goodwill for impairment annually, at the reporting unit level, and whenever events or circumstances make it likely that an impairment may have occurred, such as a significant adverse change in the business climate or a decision to sell all or a portion of a reporting unit.
897077_15_ITEM7_P67_S1	We perform our annual goodwill impairment test as of December 31 and monitor for interim triggering events on an ongoing basis.
897077_15_ITEM7_P68_S0	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment utilizing a qualitative assessment or a two-step process.
897077_15_ITEM7_P68_S1	We have an option to make a qualitative assessment of a reporting unit's goodwill for impairment.
897077_15_ITEM7_P68_S2	If we choose to perform a qualitative assessment and determine the fair value more likely than not exceeds the carrying value, no further evaluation is necessary.
897077_15_ITEM7_P69_S0	For reporting units where we perform the two-step process, the first step requires us to compare the fair value of each reporting unit, which we primarily determine using an income approach based on the present value of discounted cash flows, to the respective carrying value, which includes goodwill.
897077_15_ITEM7_P69_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying value, the goodwill is not considered impaired.
897077_15_ITEM7_P69_S2	If the carrying value is higher than the fair value, there is an indication that an impairment may exist and the second step is required.
897077_15_ITEM7_P70_S0	In step two, the implied fair value of goodwill is calculated as the excess of the fair value of a reporting unit over the fair values assigned to its assets and liabilities.
897077_15_ITEM7_P70_S1	If the implied fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value of the reporting unit's goodwill, the difference is recognized as an impairment loss.
897077_15_ITEM7_P71_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_15_ITEM7_P71_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_15_ITEM7_P71_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_15_ITEM7_P71_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.
897077_15_ITEM7_P72_S0	As of December 31, 2014 , goodwill was $ 72,407,000 , which represents 12% of total assets.
897077_15_ITEM7_P73_S0	The Company recognized no goodwill impairment in 2014 or 2013.
897077_15_ITEM7_P73_S1	The Company recognized goodwill impairment at one of its French operations, Faucheux , of $ 656,000 in 2012.
897077_15_ITEM7_P73_S2	The primary reason for the goodwill impairment in 2012 was the general economic downturn that affected the Company's European operations.
897077_15_ITEM7_P73_S3	This caused the Company to revise its expectations about future revenue, which is a significant factor in the discounted cash flow analysis used to estimate the fair value of the Company's reporting units.
897077_15_ITEM7_P73_S4	During the 2014 impairment analysis review, we performed a sensitivity analysis for goodwill impairment with respect to each of our reporting units and determined that a hypothetical 15% decline in the fair value of each reporting unit as of December 31, 2014 would not result in an impairment of goodwill for any of the reporting units.
897077_15_ITEM7_P74_S0	Management believes that the estimated valuations it arrived at are reasonable and consistent with what other marketplace participants would use in valuing the Company's components.
897077_15_ITEM7_P74_S1	However, management cannot give any assurance that these market values will not change in the future.
897077_15_ITEM7_P74_S2	For example, if discount rates demanded by the market increase, this could lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_15_ITEM7_P74_S3	If the Company's projections are not achieved in the future, this could lead management to reassess their assumptions and lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_15_ITEM7_P74_S4	If the market price of the Company's stock decreases, this could cause the Company to reassess the reasonableness of the implied control premium, which might cause management to assume a higher discount rate under the income approach which could lead to reduced valuations.
897077_15_ITEM7_P74_S5	If future similar transactions exhibit lower multiples than those observed in the past, this could lead to reduced valuations under the similar transactions approach.
897077_15_ITEM7_P75_S0	companies selected as comparable to the Company's components, this could lead to reduced valuations under the public company market multiple approach.
897077_15_ITEM7_P76_S0	The Company's annual impairment test is performed during the fourth quarter of each fiscal year.
897077_15_ITEM7_P76_S1	Given the current market conditions and continued economic uncertainty, the fair value of the Company's components could deteriorate, which could result in the need to record impairment charges in future periods.
897077_15_ITEM7_P76_S2	The Company also monitors potential triggering events including changes in the business climate in which it operates, attrition of key personnel, volatility in the capital markets, the Company's market capitalization compared to its book value, the Company's recent operating performance, and the Company's financial projections.
897077_15_ITEM7_P76_S3	The occurrence of one or more triggering events could require additional impairment testing, which could result in future impairment charges.
897077_15_ITEM7_P77_S0	See Note 7 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for more information regarding goodwill.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The Company is exposed to various financial market risks.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market prices and rates.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The Company does not enter into derivative or other financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P2_S0	A portion of the Company s operations consists of manufacturing and sales activities in international jurisdictions.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The Company manufactures its products primarily in the United States, the U.K., France, Canada and Australia.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P2_S2	The Company sells its products primarily within the markets where the products are produced, but certain of the Company s sales from its U.K. and Canadian operations are denominated in other currencies.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P2_S3	As a result, the Company s financials, specifically the value of its foreign assets, could be affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency exchange rates or weak economic conditions in the other markets in which the subsidiaries of the Company distribute their products.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P3_S0	To mitigate the short-term effect of changes in currency exchange rates on the Company s functional currency-based sales, the Company s U.K. and Canadian subsidiaries regularly enter into foreign exchange contracts to hedge over 90% of their future net foreign currency cash receipts over a period of six months.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P3_S1	As of December 31, 2014 , the Company had a notional amount of $ 2,527,000 in outstanding forward exchange contracts related to accounts receivable.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P3_S2	A 15% fluctuation in exchange rates for these currencies would change the fair value by approximately $ 379,000 .
897077_15_ITEM7A_P3_S3	However, since these contracts hedge foreign currency denominated transactions, any change in the fair value of the contracts should be offset by changes in the underlying value of the transaction being hedged.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P4_S0	On December 31, 2014 , the fair value of these agreements was in an unfavorable position; therefore, the derivative financial instruments were recorded as a loss of $43,000 , which has been recognized in other income (expense), net.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The Company s earnings are affected by fluctuations in the value of the U.S. dollar as compared to foreign currencies, predominantly in European countries, Canada and Australia, as a result of the sale of its products in international markets.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Foreign currency forward exchange contracts in the U.K. are used to hedge against the earnings effects of such fluctuations.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P5_S2	On December 31, 2014 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have been a decrease in gross profit of $ 5,906,000 .
897077_15_ITEM7A_P5_S3	Comparatively, on December 31, 2013 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have been a decrease in gross profit of approximately $ 5,475,000 .
897077_15_ITEM7A_P6_S0	This calculation assumes that each exchange rate would change in the same direction relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P6_S1	In addition to the direct effects of changes in exchange rates, which are a changed dollar value of the resulting sales, changes in exchange rates may also affect the volume of sales or the foreign currency sales price as competitors products become more or less attractive.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P6_S2	The Company s sensitivity analysis of the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates does not factor in a potential change in sales levels or local currency prices.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P7_S0	was a loss of $16,331,000 .
897077_15_ITEM7A_P7_S1	On December 31, 2014 , the British pound closed at 0.6419 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.8265 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P7_S2	By comparison, on December 31, 2013 , the British pound closed at 0.6040 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.7275 relative to the U.S. dollar.

897077_15_ITEM7A_P8_S0	Interest Rate Risk The majority of the Company s long-term debt bears interest at variable rates.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P8_S1	Accordingly, the Company s net income is affected by changes in interest rates.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P8_S2	Assuming the average level of borrowings at variable rates and a two hundred basis point change in the 2014 average interest rate under these borrowings, the Company s 2014 interest expense would have changed by approximately $ 3,407,000 .
897077_15_ITEM7A_P9_S0	In the event of an adverse change in interest rates, management could take actions to mitigate its exposure.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P9_S1	Further, this analysis does not consider the effects of the change in the level of overall economic activity that could exist in such an environment.
897077_15_ITEM7A_P9_S2	However, challenges affecting the banking industry and credit markets in general can potentially cause changes to credit availability and cost of borrowing, which creates a level of uncertainty.

897077_15_ITEM15_P12_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
897077_15_ITEM15_P12_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
897077_15_ITEM15_P13_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
897077_15_ITEM15_P13_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
897077_15_ITEM15_P14_S0	In our opinion, Alamo Group Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2014, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (1992) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.

897077_15_ITEM15_P36_S0	Goodwill consists of the excess of the purchase price over the fair value of identifiable net assets of businesses acquired.
897077_15_ITEM15_P36_S1	We perform our annual goodwill impairment test as of December 31 and monitor for interim triggering events on an ongoing basis.
897077_15_ITEM15_P37_S0	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment utilizing a qualitative assessment or a two-step process.
897077_15_ITEM15_P37_S1	We have an option to make a qualitative assessment of a reporting unit's goodwill for impairment.
897077_15_ITEM15_P37_S2	If we choose to perform a qualitative assessment and determine the fair value more likely than not exceeds the carrying value, no further evaluation is necessary.
897077_15_ITEM15_P38_S0	For reporting units where we perform the two-step process, the first step requires us to compare the fair value of each reporting unit, which we primarily determine using an income approach based on the present value of discounted cash flows, to the respective carrying value, which includes goodwill.
897077_15_ITEM15_P38_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying value, the goodwill is not considered impaired.
897077_15_ITEM15_P38_S2	If the carrying value is higher than the fair value, there is an indication that an impairment may exist and the second step is required.
897077_15_ITEM15_P39_S0	In step two, the implied fair value of goodwill is calculated as the excess of the fair value of a reporting unit over the fair values assigned to its assets and liabilities.
897077_15_ITEM15_P39_S1	If the implied fair value of goodwill is less than the carrying value of the reporting unit's goodwill, the difference is recognized as an impairment loss.
897077_15_ITEM15_P40_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_15_ITEM15_P40_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_15_ITEM15_P40_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_15_ITEM15_P40_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.

897077_15_ITEM15_P43_S2	For example, if discount rates demanded by the market increase, this could lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_15_ITEM15_P43_S3	If the Company's projections are not achieved in the future, this could lead management to reassess their assumptions and lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_15_ITEM15_P44_S0	assume a higher discount rate under the income approach which could lead to reduced valuations.
897077_15_ITEM15_P44_S1	If future similar transactions exhibit lower multiples than those observed in the past, this could lead to reduced valuations under the similar transactions approach.
897077_15_ITEM15_P44_S2	And finally, if there is a general decline in the stock market and particularly in those companies selected as comparable to the Company's components, this could lead to reduced valuations under the public company market multiple approach.

897077_15_ITEM15_P107_S0	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three -year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent ; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three -year supply.
897077_15_ITEM15_P107_S1	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_15_ITEM15_P107_S2	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_15_ITEM15_P107_S3	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three -year history has been established.
897077_15_ITEM15_P108_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood units and 90 days on parts, though some components can have warranty for longer terms.
897077_15_ITEM15_P109_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety -day to six -month lag period.
897077_15_ITEM15_P109_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the unit to file a warranty claim.
897077_15_ITEM15_P109_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_15_ITEM15_P109_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.

897077_15_ITEM15_P125_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS Fair value is defined as the exchange price that would be received for an asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit price) in the principal or most advantageous market for the asset or liability in an orderly transaction between market participants.
897077_15_ITEM15_P126_S0	There is a three-tier fair value hierarchy based upon the observability of inputs used in valuation techniques.
897077_15_ITEM15_P126_S1	Observable inputs (highest level) reflect market data obtained from independent sources, while unobservable inputs (lowest level) reflect internally developed market assumptions.
897077_15_ITEM15_P126_S2	In fair value, measurements are classified under the following hierarchy:
897077_15_ITEM15_P127_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
897077_15_ITEM15_P127_S1	Level 2 Quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets; quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active; and model-derived valuations in which all significant inputs or significant value-drivers are observable in active markets.
897077_15_ITEM15_P127_S2	Level 3 Model-derived valuations in which one or more significant inputs or significant value-drivers are unobservable.
897077_15_ITEM15_P128_S0	The Company uses quoted market prices, when available, to determine fair value, and the Company classifies such measurements within Level 1.
897077_15_ITEM15_P128_S1	In some cases where market prices are not available, the Company makes use of observable market-based inputs to calculate fair value, in which case the measurements are classified with Level 2.
897077_15_ITEM15_P129_S0	If quoted or observable market prices are not available, fair value is based upon internally developed models that use, where possible, current market-based parameters such as interest rates, yield curves, currency rates, etc.
897077_15_ITEM15_P129_S1	These measurements are classified within Level 3.
897077_15_ITEM15_P130_S0	Fair value measurements are classified to the lowest level input or value-driver that is significant to the valuation.
897077_15_ITEM15_P130_S1	A measurement may therefore be classified within Level 3 even though there may be significant inputs that are readily observable.
897077_15_ITEM15_P131_S0	The Company does not currently have any assets or liabilities recorded at fair value on a recurring basis.
897077_15_ITEM15_P131_S1	Fair value measurements are also used in connection with nonrecurring valuations performed in connection with impairment assessments and acquisition accounting.
897077_15_ITEM15_P132_S0	In completing the analysis of the fair values of certain of the acquired assets in the current year acquisitions, discounted cash flow models were used, which were principally based upon internal assumptions.
897077_15_ITEM15_P132_S1	In valuing certain of the acquired intangible assets we used an excess earnings methodology, which is a form of a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_15_ITEM15_P133_S0	Tangible assets were valued using a replacement or reproduction cost approach, considering factors such as current prices of the same or similar equipment, the age of the equipment and economic obsolescence.
897077_15_ITEM15_P134_S0	The implied value of goodwill is determined by allocating the acquisition cost to all of the assets and liabilities of the acquired entity, with the residual amount allocated to goodwill.
897077_15_ITEM15_P135_S0	All of our nonrecurring valuations use significant unobservable inputs and therefore fall under Level 3 of the fair value hierarchy.

897077_15_ITEM15_P171_S0	The Company employs a building block approach in determining the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
897077_15_ITEM15_P171_S1	Historical markets are studied and long-term historical relationships between equities and fixed income are preserved consistent with the widely accepted capital market principle that assets with higher volatility generate a greater return over the long run.
897077_15_ITEM15_P171_S2	Current market factors such as inflation and interest rates are evaluated before long-term market assumptions are determined.
897077_15_ITEM15_P171_S3	The long-term portfolio return is established via a building block approach with proper consideration of diversification and rebalancing.
897077_15_ITEM15_P171_S4	Peer data and historical returns are reviewed to check for reasonability and appropriateness.

897077_15_ITEM15_P174_S0	The Company employs a total return investment approach whereby a mix of equities and fixed income investments are used to maximize the long-term return of plan assets for a prudent level of risk.
897077_15_ITEM15_P174_S1	Risk tolerance is established through careful consideration of plan liabilities, plan funded status, and corporate financial condition.
897077_15_ITEM15_P175_S0	The investment portfolio contains a diversified blend of equity and fixed income investments.
897077_15_ITEM15_P175_S1	Furthermore, equity investments are diversified across U.S. and non-U.S. stocks, as well as growth, value, and small and large capitalizations.
897077_15_ITEM15_P175_S2	Other assets such as real estate, private equity, and hedge funds are used judiciously to enhance long-term returns while improving portfolio diversification.
897077_15_ITEM15_P175_S3	Derivatives may be used to gain market exposure in an efficient and timely manner; however, derivatives may not be used to leverage the portfolio beyond the market value of the underlying investments.
897077_15_ITEM15_P176_S0	Investment risk is measured and monitored on an ongoing basis through quarterly investment portfolio reviews, annual liability measurements, and periodic asset/liability studies.
897077_15_ITEM15_P177_S0	Our current asset allocations are consistent with our targeted allocations.

897077_15_ITEM15_P185_S0	The Board of Directors of the Company adopted the Alamo Group Inc. Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (the SERP ), effective as of January 3, 2011.
897077_15_ITEM15_P185_S1	The SERP will benefit certain key management or other highly compensated employees of the Company and/or certain subsidiaries who are selected by the Compensation Committee and approved by the Board to participate.
897077_15_ITEM15_P186_S0	The SERP is intended to provide a benefit from the Company upon retirement, death or disability, or a change in control of the Company.
897077_15_ITEM15_P186_S1	Accordingly, the SERP obligates the Company to pay to a participant a Retirement Benefit (as defined in the SERP) upon the occurrence of certain payment events to the extent a participant has a vested right thereto.
897077_15_ITEM15_P186_S2	A participant s right to his or her Retirement Benefit becomes vested in the Company s contributions upon 10 years of Credited Service (as defined in the SERP) or a change in control of the Company.
897077_15_ITEM15_P186_S3	The Retirement Benefit is based on 20% of the final three -year average salary of each participant on or after his or her normal retirement age ( 65 years of age).
897077_15_ITEM15_P186_S4	In the event of the participant s death or a change in control, the participant s vested retirement benefit will be paid in a lump sum to the participant or his or her estate, as applicable, within 90 days after the participant s death or a change in control, as applicable.
897077_15_ITEM15_P186_S5	In the event the participant is entitled to a benefit from the SERP due to disability, retirement or other termination of employment, the benefit will be paid in monthly installments over a period of fifteen years.
897077_15_ITEM15_P187_S0	The Company records amounts relating to the SERP based on calculations that incorporate various actuarial and other assumptions, including discount rates, rate of compensation increases, retirement dates and life expectancies.
897077_15_ITEM15_P187_S1	The net periodic costs are recognized as employees render the services necessary to earn the SERP benefits.
897077_15_ITEM15_P188_S0	In connection with the initiation of the SERP, the Company had an unfunded long-term liability of $1,964,301 , a deferred tax asset of $746,000 , and $1,218,301 in accumulated other comprehensive income.

897077_15_ITEM15_P211_S0	The Company knows that its Indianola, Iowa property is contaminated with chromium which most likely resulted from chrome plating operations which were discontinued before the Company purchased the property.
897077_15_ITEM15_P211_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.
897077_15_ITEM15_P211_S2	The Company voluntarily worked with an environmental consultant and the state of Iowa with respect to these issues and believes it completed its remediation program in June 2006.
897077_15_ITEM15_P211_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_15_ITEM15_P211_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_15_ITEM15_P211_S5	We received a conditional no further action letter in January of 2009.
897077_15_ITEM15_P211_S6	When we demonstrate stable or improving conditions below residential standards for a certain period of time by monitoring existing wells, we will request an unconditional no further action letter.
897077_15_ITEM15_P212_S0	The Company knows that Bush Hog s main manufacturing property in Selma, Alabama was contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic compounds which most likely resulted from painting and cleaning operations during the 1960s and 1970s.
897077_15_ITEM15_P212_S1	The contaminated areas were primarily in the location of underground storage tanks and underneath the former waste storage area.
897077_15_ITEM15_P212_S2	Under the Asset Purchase Agreement, Bush Hog s prior owner agreed to and has removed the underground storage tanks at its cost and has remediated the identified contamination in accordance with the regulations of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management.
897077_15_ITEM15_P213_S0	consulting firm was retained by the prior owner to administer the cleanup and monitor the site on an ongoing basis until the remediation program is complete and approved by the applicable authorities.
897077_15_ITEM15_P214_S0	In December of 2012, a federal district court jury in Louisiana found that Gradall was unjustly enriched in the amount of $1,000,000 plus interest when it sold several telescopic fire apparatuses after properly terminating what the jury determined to be an enforceable contract with the plaintiff, a fire truck manufacturer.
897077_15_ITEM15_P214_S1	Gradall appealed the decision and reserved the full amount.
897077_15_ITEM15_P214_S2	In September of 2014, the case was overturned by the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals which found in Gradall's favor.
897077_15_ITEM15_P214_S3	The plaintiff's final option was to appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court which it did not, affirming the Court of Appeals decision in favor of Gradall.
897077_15_ITEM15_P215_S0	During the fourth quarter of 2014, the Company returned $1,250,000 it had previously reserved to the income statement.

897077_16_ITEM1_P0_S0	Unless the context otherwise requires, the terms the Company, we, our and us refer to Alamo Group Inc. and its subsidiaries on a consolidated basis.
897077_16_ITEM1_P1_S0	The Company is a leader in the design and manufacture of high quality agricultural equipment and infrastructure maintenance equipment for governmental and industrial use.
897077_16_ITEM1_P1_S1	The Company s products include tractor-mounted mowing and other vegetation maintenance equipment, street sweepers, excavators, vacuum trucks, snow removal equipment, pothole patchers, zero turn radius mowers, agricultural implements and related aftermarket parts.
897077_16_ITEM1_P1_S2	The Company emphasizes high quality, cost-effective products for its customers and strives to develop and market innovative products while constantly monitoring and seeking to contain its manufacturing and overhead costs.
897077_16_ITEM1_P1_S3	The Company has a long-standing strategy of supplementing its internal growth through acquisitions of businesses or product lines that currently complement, command, or have the potential to achieve a meaningful share of their niche markets.
897077_16_ITEM1_P1_S4	The Company has approximately 3,030 employees and operates a total of twenty-five plants in North America, Europe, Australia and Brazil.
897077_16_ITEM1_P1_S5	The Company sells its products primarily through a network of independent dealers and distributors to governmental end-users, related independent contractors, as well as to the agricultural and commercial turf markets.
897077_16_ITEM1_P1_S6	The primary markets for our products are North America and Western Europe.
897077_16_ITEM1_P2_S0	The predecessor corporation to Alamo Group Inc. was incorporated in the State of Texas in 1969, as a successor to a business that began selling mowing equipment in 1955, and Alamo Group Inc. was reincorporated in the State of Delaware in 1987.
897077_16_ITEM1_P3_S0	Since its founding in 1969, the Company has focused on satisfying customer needs through geographic market expansion, product development and refinement, and selected acquisitions.
897077_16_ITEM1_P4_S0	The Company s first products were based on rotary cutting technology.
897077_16_ITEM1_P4_S1	Through acquisitions, the Company added flail cutting technology in 1983 and sickle-bar cutting technology in 1984.
897077_16_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Company added to its presence in the industrial and governmental vegetation markets with the acquisition of Tiger Corporation ( Tiger ) in late 1994.
897077_16_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Company entered the agricultural mowing markets in 1986 with the acquisition of Rhino Products Inc. ( Rhino ) , a leading manufacturer in this field.
897077_16_ITEM1_P6_S1	With this acquisition, the Company embarked on a strategy to increase the Rhino dealer distribution network during a period of industry contraction.
897077_16_ITEM1_P6_S2	The addition of M W Gear Company ( M W ) in early 1995 allowed the Company to enter into the manufacturing and distribution of tillage equipment, which complements the Rhino distribution network.
897077_16_ITEM1_P6_S3	M W has been integrated into the agricultural marketing group.
897077_16_ITEM1_P7_S0	In 1991, the Company began its international expansion with the acquisition of McConnel Ltd .
897077_16_ITEM1_P7_S1	( McConnel ) , a United Kingdom ( U.K. ) manufacturer of vegetation maintenance equipment, principally hydraulic boom-mounted hedge and grass cutters and related parts.
897077_16_ITEM1_P7_S2	( Bomford ) , also a U.K. company, was acquired in 1993.
897077_16_ITEM1_P8_S0	Bomford is a manufacturer of heavy-duty, tractor-mounted grass and hedge mowing equipment.
897077_16_ITEM1_P8_S1	McConnel and Bomford sell their products to dealers and distributors through their respective sales forces.
897077_16_ITEM1_P9_S0	In 1994, the Company acquired Signalisation Moderne Autoroutiere S.A .
897077_16_ITEM1_P9_S1	( SMA ) located in Orleans, France.
897077_16_ITEM1_P9_S2	SMA manufactures and sells principally a line of heavy-duty, tractor-mounted grass and hedge mowing equipment and associated replacement parts primarily to departments of the French government.
897077_16_ITEM1_P9_S3	This acquisition, along with the acquisitions of Forges Gorce, a flail blade manufacturer in France, in 1996 and Rousseau Holdings S.A. ( Rousseau ), a leading French manufacturer of hedge and verge mowers, in 2004, when combined with McConnel and Bomford, has made the Company one of the largest manufacturers in the European market for the kind of equipment sold by the Company.
897077_16_ITEM1_P10_S0	In 1995, the Company expanded its business in the agricultural market with the acquisition of Herschel Corporation ( Herschel ) , a manufacturer and distributor of aftermarket farm equipment replacement and wear parts.
897077_16_ITEM1_P11_S0	In 2000, the Company acquired Schwarze Industries, Inc .
897077_16_ITEM1_P11_S1	Schwarze is a manufacturer of a broad range of street sweeping equipment which is sold to governmental agencies and contractors.
897077_16_ITEM1_P11_S2	The Company believes the Schwarze sweeper products fit the Company s strategy of identifying product offerings with brand recognition in the industrial markets the Company serves.
897077_16_ITEM1_P12_S0	In 2004, the Company purchased the pothole patcher product line from Wildcat Manufacturing, Inc.
897077_16_ITEM1_P12_S1	The product line was merged into the Schwarze operation and is complementary to its current product offerings.
897077_16_ITEM1_P13_S0	In 2000, the Company purchased the product line and associated assets of Twose of Tiverton Ltd.
897077_16_ITEM1_P13_S1	( Twose ) in the U.K. and incorporated its production into the existing facilities at McConnel and Bomford while maintaining its own sales force and dealer distribution network.
897077_16_ITEM1_P13_S2	Twose was a small regional manufacturer of power arm flail mowers and parts, as well as harrows and rollers, which strengthened the Company s market leadership position in the U.K.
897077_16_ITEM1_P14_S0	In 2000, the Company acquired Schulte Industries Ltd. and its related entities ( Schulte ) .
897077_16_ITEM1_P14_S1	Schulte is a Canadian manufacturer of mechanical rotary mowers, snow blowers, and rock removal equipment.
897077_16_ITEM1_P14_S2	Schulte strengthened the Company s Canadian presence in both marketing and manufacturing.
897077_16_ITEM1_P14_S3	It also expanded the Company s range of large, heavy-duty rotary mowers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P15_S0	In 2001, the Company acquired all of the assets of SMC Corporation ( SMC ).
897077_16_ITEM1_P15_S1	SMC manufactures front-end loaders and backhoes principally for Original Equipment Manufacturer ( OEM ) customers and its own SMC brand.
897077_16_ITEM1_P15_S2	This acquisition expanded the product range of our agricultural division and has since been consolidated into the Company's Gibson City, Illinois location.
897077_16_ITEM1_P16_S0	In 2002, the Company purchased inventory, fixed assets and certain other assets of Valu-Bilt Tractor Parts ( Valu-Bilt ) , a subsidiary of Quality Stores, Inc., located in Des Moines, Iowa.
897077_16_ITEM1_P16_S1	Valu-Bilt is a distributor of new, used and rebuilt tractor parts and other agricultural spare and wear parts sold directly to customers through its catalog and the internet and on a wholesale basis to dealers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P16_S2	Subsequent to the purchase, the operations of Valu-Bilt in Des Moines, Iowa, were consolidated into the Company s Herschel facility in Indianola, Iowa.
897077_16_ITEM1_P17_S0	In 2002, the Company purchased substantially all of the assets of Faucheux Industries S.A. ( Faucheux ) , a French manufacturer of front-end loaders and attachments.
897077_16_ITEM1_P17_S1	The Company acquired Faucheux out of administration, a form of bankruptcy in France.
897077_16_ITEM1_P17_S2	This acquisition broadened the range of our agricultural implements offered in the French market and is currently being restructured and consolidated into the Company's Neuville, France location.
897077_16_ITEM1_P18_S0	In 2005, the Company, through its European subsidiary Alamo Group (EUR) Ltd., acquired 100% of the issued and outstanding stock of Spearhead Machinery Limited ( Spearhead ) and subsequently merged its manufacturing operations into Bomford s facility.
897077_16_ITEM1_P19_S0	Spearhead manufactures a range of tractor-mounted vegetation maintenance equipment, including reach mowers, flail mowers and rotary cutters.
897077_16_ITEM1_P19_S1	This acquisition extended our product lines and market coverage in Europe.
897077_16_ITEM1_P20_S0	In early 2006, the Company purchased substantially all of the assets of the Gradall excavator business ( Gradall ) of JLG Industries, Inc., including their manufacturing plant in New Philadelphia, Ohio.
897077_16_ITEM1_P20_S1	Gradall is a leading manufacturer of both wheeled and crawler telescopic excavators in North America.
897077_16_ITEM1_P20_S2	This acquisition enhanced our Industrial Division product offering sold to governmental buyers and related contractors for maintenance along right-of-ways.
897077_16_ITEM1_P21_S0	In 2006, the Company purchased the vacuum truck and sweeper lines of Clean Earth Environmental Group, LLC and Clean Earth Kentucky, LLC (collectively referred to as VacAll ) .
897077_16_ITEM1_P21_S1	This included the product lines, inventory and certain other assets that relate to this business.
897077_16_ITEM1_P21_S2	The production of the vacuum truck and sweeper lines were moved to the Gradall facility in New Philadelphia, Ohio.
897077_16_ITEM1_P22_S0	In 2006, the Company acquired 100% of the ownership interests in Nite-Hawk Sweepers LLC ( Nite-Hawk ) , a manufacturer of truck mounted sweeping equipment primarily for the contract sweeping market, which expanded its presence in that market and complements our Schwarze sweeper line.
897077_16_ITEM1_P23_S0	In 2007, the Company purchased Henke Manufacturing Corporation ( Henke ) , a manufacturer of specialty snow removal attachments.
897077_16_ITEM1_P24_S0	The primary end-users are governmental agencies, related contractors and other industrial users.
897077_16_ITEM1_P25_S0	In 2008, the Company acquired Rivard Developpement S.A.S. ( Rivard ) , a leading French manufacturer of vacuum trucks, high pressure cleaning systems and trenchers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P25_S1	The acquisition broadened the Company s product offering to its customers in Europe and other markets we serve.
897077_16_ITEM1_P26_S0	In 2009, the Company acquired substantially all the assets of Bush Hog, LLC ( Bush Hog ) , a leading agricultural equipment manufacturer of rotary cutters, finishing mowers, zero turn radius mowers, front-end loaders, backhoes, landscape equipment and a variety of other implements.
897077_16_ITEM1_P26_S1	This acquisition, combined with the Company s existing range of agricultural mowers, created one of the largest manufacturers of agricultural mowers in the world.
897077_16_ITEM1_P27_S0	In 2011, the Company acquired substantially all of the assets and assumed certain specified liabilities of Tenco Group, Inc. ( "Tenco" ) and its subsidiaries.
897077_16_ITEM1_P28_S0	Tenco is a Canadian-based manufacturer of snow removal equipment including snow blades, blowers, dump bodies, spreaders and associated parts and service.
897077_16_ITEM1_P28_S1	Tenco has operations in Quebec as well as New York and Vermont.
897077_16_ITEM1_P28_S2	The equipment is sold primarily through dealers to governmental end-users as well as contractors.
897077_16_ITEM1_P29_S0	In 2013, the Company acquired substantially all of the assets and assumed certain specified liabilities of Superior Equipment Australia PTY.
897077_16_ITEM1_P30_S0	Superior is a small Australian-based manufacturer of agricultural mowing equipment and other attachments, parts, and services.
897077_16_ITEM1_P30_S1	The equipment is sold through dealers primarily to agricultural end-users with some sold to governmental entities in Australia.
897077_16_ITEM1_P31_S0	Superior has been combined into the Company's Fieldquip location.
897077_16_ITEM1_P32_S0	On April 2, 2014, the Company acquired Kellands Agricultural Ltd. and its subsidiary Multidrive Tractors Ltd. ( "Kellands" ).
897077_16_ITEM1_P32_S1	Kellands is a U.K.-based manufacturer of self-propelled sprayers and a range of multi-purpose load-carrying tractor vehicles.
897077_16_ITEM1_P32_S2	This acquisition enhanced our manufacture and distribution of agricultural machinery in our European operations and allowed the Company to enter into the self-propelled sprayer market.
897077_16_ITEM1_P33_S0	On April 7, 2014, the Company acquired Fieldquip Australia PTY LTD ( "Fieldquip" ), a manufacturer of rotary cutters as well as a distributor of various agricultural products.
897077_16_ITEM1_P33_S1	This acquisition allowed the Company to broaden its presence in both the manufacturing and distribution of agricultural machinery in Australia.
897077_16_ITEM1_P34_S0	On May 13, 2014, the Company acquired all of the operating units of Specialized Industries LP.
897077_16_ITEM1_P34_S1	Howard P. Fairfield LLC (" H.P. Fairfield ") as well as several related entities ( "Specialized" ), including all brand names and related product names and trademarks.
897077_16_ITEM1_P34_S2	The primary reason for the Specialized acquisition was to broaden the Company's existing equipment lines.
897077_16_ITEM1_P34_S3	This acquisition increased our product offering and enhanced our market position both in vacuum trucks and snow removal equipment primarily in North America.
897077_16_ITEM1_P35_S0	On March 10, 2015, the Company acquired Herder Implementos e Maquinas Agricolas Ltda.
897077_16_ITEM1_P36_S0	Herder is a manufacturer of flail mowers and other agricultural implements which are sold direct and through dealers to the sugar cane, orchard and other agricultural markets as well as the roadside maintenance market.
897077_16_ITEM1_P36_S1	This acquisition allowed the Company to establish a presence in Brazil, one of the largest agricultural markets in the world.
897077_16_ITEM1_P37_S0	The Company believes that within the U.S. it is a leading supplier to governmental markets, a leading supplier in the U.S. agricultural market, and one of the largest suppliers in the European market for its key niche product offerings.
897077_16_ITEM1_P37_S1	The Company s products are sold through the Company s various marketing organizations and extensive worldwide dealer and distributor networks under the Alamo Industrial , Terrain King , Tiger , Gradall , VacAll , Schwarze , Nite-Hawk , Henke , Tenco , Super Products , Wausau-Everest , H.P. Fairfield , Bush Hog , Rhino , Earthmaster , Herschel , Valu-Bilt , Schulte , Superior , Fieldquip , Herder , McConnel , Bomford , Spearhead , Twose , Kellands , SMA , Forges Gorce , Faucheux , Rousseau and Rivard trademarks (some with related designs) as well as other trademarks and trade names.
897077_16_ITEM1_P38_S0	Alamo Industrial equipment is principally sold through independent dealers to governmental end-users, related independent contractors and, to a lesser extent, utility and other dealers serving infrastructure maintenance operators and other applications in the U.S. and other countries.
897077_16_ITEM1_P38_S1	Governmental agencies and contractors that perform services for such agencies purchase primarily hydraulically-powered, tractor-mounted mowers, including boom-mounted mowers, other types of cutters and replacement parts for heavy-duty, intensive use applications, including maintenance around highway, airport, recreational and other public areas.
897077_16_ITEM1_P39_S0	A portion of Alamo Industrial s sales includes tractors, which are not manufactured by Alamo Industrial.
897077_16_ITEM1_P40_S0	Tiger equipment includes heavy duty, tractor- and truck-mounted mowing and vegetation maintenance equipment and replacement parts.
897077_16_ITEM1_P41_S0	Tiger sells to state, county and local governmental entities and related contractors, primarily through a network of independent dealers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P41_S1	Tiger s dealer distribution network is independent of Alamo Industrial s dealer distribution network.
897077_16_ITEM1_P42_S0	A portion of Tiger s sales includes tractors, which are not manufactured by Tiger.
897077_16_ITEM1_P43_S0	Schwarze equipment includes truck-mounted air, mechanical broom, and regenerative air sweepers, pothole patchers and replacement parts.
897077_16_ITEM1_P44_S0	Schwarze sells its products primarily to governmental agencies and independent contractors, either directly or through its independent dealer network.
897077_16_ITEM1_P44_S1	A portion of Schwarze s sales includes truck chassis which are not manufactured by Schwarze .
897077_16_ITEM1_P44_S2	The Company believes that Schwarze complements Alamo Industrial because the dealer and/or end-user for both products in many cases are the same .
897077_16_ITEM1_P45_S0	Nite-Hawk manufactures parking lot sweepers with unique and innovative hydraulic designs.
897077_16_ITEM1_P45_S1	By eliminating the auxiliary engine, Nite-Hawk sweepers have proven to be fuel-efficient, environmentally conscious, and cost-effective to operate.
897077_16_ITEM1_P46_S0	Nite-Hawk focuses mainly on and sells direct to parking lot contractors.
897077_16_ITEM1_P46_S1	A portion of Nite-Hawk s sales includes truck chassis which are not manufactured by Nite-Hawk .
897077_16_ITEM1_P47_S0	Gradall produces a range of excavators based on high-pressure hydraulic telescoping booms which are sold through dealers primarily to governmental agencies and related contractors, and to a lesser extent the mining industry, steel mills and other specialty applications in the U.S. and other countries.
897077_16_ITEM1_P47_S1	Many of these products are designed for excavation, grading, shaping and similar tasks involved in land clearing, road building or maintenance.
897077_16_ITEM1_P47_S2	These products are available mounted on various types of undercarriages: wheels for full-speed highway travel, wheels for on/off road use, and crawlers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P48_S0	VacAll produces catch basin cleaners and roadway debris vacuum systems.
897077_16_ITEM1_P48_S1	These units are powerful and versatile with uses including, but not limited to, removal of wet and dry debris, spill elimination, and cleaning of sludge beds.
897077_16_ITEM1_P48_S2	VacAll also offers a line of sewer cleaners.
897077_16_ITEM1_P48_S3	Its products are primarily sold through dealers to industrial and commercial contractors as well as governmental agencies.
897077_16_ITEM1_P48_S4	A portion of VacAll s sales includes truck chassis which are not manufactured by the Company.
897077_16_ITEM1_P49_S0	Super Products produces truck-mounted vacuum trucks, combination sewer cleaners and hydro excavators.
897077_16_ITEM1_P49_S1	Its products are sold to municipalities, utilities and contractors through a nationwide distributor network.
897077_16_ITEM1_P49_S2	Super Products also operates a network of five rental stores that provide short and long-term rental contracts for its products.
897077_16_ITEM1_P49_S3	Rental customers are primarily contractors serving the petrochemical, petroleum production and refining industries.
897077_16_ITEM1_P50_S0	A portion of the sales of Super Products includes truck chassis which are not manufactured by the Company.
897077_16_ITEM1_P51_S0	Wausau-Everest designs and manufactures a broad range of municipal snow removal and ice control products that it delivers to customers through a comprehensive dealer network.
897077_16_ITEM1_P51_S1	Wausau-Everest also manufactures a range of high-capacity snow-blowers, plows, brooms, brine sprayers and prime movers that it sells directly to airports and fixed-base operators.
897077_16_ITEM1_P52_S0	In addition to its core snow removal and ice control products, its Everest unit manufactures custom-engineered underground construction forms for vehicular, water/sewage and hydro-electric tunnels.
897077_16_ITEM1_P53_S0	Wausau-Everest markets its products under various brands that are familiar to the industry.
897077_16_ITEM1_P54_S0	Henke designs and manufactures snow plows and heavy duty snow removal equipment, hitches and attachments for trucks, loaders and graders sold primarily through independent truck and industrial equipment dealers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P55_S0	Henke s primary end-users are governmental agencies, related contractors and other industrial users.
897077_16_ITEM1_P56_S0	Tenco designs and manufactures a heavy-duty line of snow removal equipment, including truck-mounted snow plows, snow blowers, dump bodies and spreaders.
897077_16_ITEM1_P56_S1	Its products are primarily sold through independent dealers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P57_S0	End-users are governmental agencies, contractors and other industrial users.
897077_16_ITEM1_P58_S0	H. P. Fairfield is a full-service distributor of public works and runway maintenance products, parts and service, whose sales and service outlets are located in the northeast part of the U.S. H.P. Fairfield s offerings include custom municipal snow and ice removal equipment, a range of salt spreaders and truck bodies, street sweepers, a line of industrial rotary, flail and boom mowers, solid waste and recycling equipment, water and sewer maintenance equipment, municipal tractors and attachments, and asphalt maintenance patchers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P59_S0	Bush Hog, Rhino and Earthmaster equipment is generally sold to farmers, ranchers and other end users to clear brush, mow grass, maintain pastures and unused farmland, shred crops, till fields, haymaking and other applications.
897077_16_ITEM1_P59_S1	Bush Hog and Rhino equipment consists principally of a comprehensive line of tractor-powered equipment, including rotary mowers, finishing mowers, flail mowers, disc mowers, zero turn radius mowers, front-end loaders, backhoes, rotary tillers, posthole diggers, scraper blades and replacement parts.
897077_16_ITEM1_P60_S0	Herschel/Valu-Bilt aftermarket replacement parts are sold for many types of farm equipment and tractors and certain types of mowing and construction equipment.
897077_16_ITEM1_P60_S1	Herschel products include a wide range of cutting parts, plain and hard-faced replacement tillage tools, disc blades and fertilizer application components.
897077_16_ITEM1_P60_S2	Herschel replacement tools and parts are sold throughout the United States, Canada and Mexico to five major customer groups: farm equipment dealers; fleet stores; wholesale distributors; OEMs; and construction equipment dealers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P60_S3	Valu-Bilt complements the Herschel product lines while also expanding the Company s offering of aftermarket agricultural parts and added catalog and internet sales direct to end-users.
897077_16_ITEM1_P61_S0	Schulte equipment includes heavy-duty mechanical rotary mowers, snow blowers, rock removal equipment and related replacement parts.
897077_16_ITEM1_P61_S1	Schulte serves both the agricultural and governmental markets primarily in Canada and the U.S.
897077_16_ITEM1_P61_S2	It also sells some of the Company s other product lines in their markets and some of its products through independent distributors throughout the world.
897077_16_ITEM1_P62_S0	Fieldquip and Superior together broaden the Company's presence in manufacturing and distribution in Australia.
897077_16_ITEM1_P62_S1	Both companies sell a variety of agricultural equipment specifically, rotary mowers and tractor attachments.
897077_16_ITEM1_P63_S0	Fieldquip sells to customers ranging from large agricultural and commercial operators to small farm hobbyist and residential users.
897077_16_ITEM1_P63_S1	Superior's customers are generally agricultural dealers who service owners and operators in the turf, golf, park and airport industries and growers with orchards, vineyards and plantations in Australia and the South Pacific.
897077_16_ITEM1_P64_S0	Herder gives the Company a presence in the Brazilian agricultural market, one of the largest in the world.
897077_16_ITEM1_P64_S1	It is also the first step in establishing a position in the market and allows us to purse organic growth and further acquisitions.
897077_16_ITEM1_P65_S0	Herder manufacturers and distributes flail mowers and various other agricultural equipment direct and through dealers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P65_S1	Its products are used in sugar cane, orchards and other agricultural markets.
897077_16_ITEM1_P66_S0	McConnel equipment principally includes a broad line of hydraulic, boom-mounted hedge and grass cutters, as well as other tractor attachments and implements such as hydraulic backhoes, cultivators, subsoilers, buckets and other digger implements and related replacement parts.
897077_16_ITEM1_P66_S1	McConnel equipment is sold primarily in the U.K., Ireland and France and in other parts of Europe and, to a lesser extent, throughout the world, through independent dealers and distributors.
897077_16_ITEM1_P67_S0	Bomford equipment includes hydraulic, boom-mounted hedge and hedgerow cutters, industrial grass mowers, agricultural seedbed preparation cultivators and related replacement parts.
897077_16_ITEM1_P68_S0	extent, other countries in Europe, North America, Australia and Asia.
897077_16_ITEM1_P68_S1	Bomford s sales network is similar to that of McConnel in the U.K. Rhino sells some of Bomford s product line in the U.S.
897077_16_ITEM1_P69_S0	Twose equipment includes light-duty power arm mowers, agricultural implements and related replacement parts.
897077_16_ITEM1_P69_S1	Twose products are manufactured at the Company s U.K. facilities.
897077_16_ITEM1_P69_S2	These products are sold through Twose s dealer distribution network in the U.K. and through Faucheux s and other independent distributors internationally.

897077_16_ITEM1_P75_S1	In addition, Faucheux also markets certain agricultural related products from other company units and third party suppliers.
