897077_16_ITEM1_P77_S1	These products have also been introduced into other markets outside of France.
897077_16_ITEM1_P78_S0	Rivard manufactures vacuum trucks, high pressure cleaning systems and trenchers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P78_S1	Rivard s equipment is primarily sold in France and certain other markets, mainly in Europe and North Africa, and to governmental entities and related contractors.
897077_16_ITEM1_P78_S2	It also complements our product offerings in North America.
897077_16_ITEM1_P79_S0	The majority of Rivard's customers provide their own truck chassis.
897077_16_ITEM1_P80_S0	Replacement Parts The Company derives a significant portion of its revenues from sales of replacement parts for each of its wholegoods lines.
897077_16_ITEM1_P80_S1	Replacement parts represented approximately 18% , 20% and 21% of the Company s total sales for the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
897077_16_ITEM1_P80_S2	The majority of the decline in percentage sales of spare parts relates to the 2014 acquisition of the units of Specialized which has a lower mix of parts as a percentage of sales.
897077_16_ITEM1_P81_S0	Proprietary replacement parts generally are more profitable and less cyclical than wholegoods.
897077_16_ITEM1_P82_S0	The Company s ability to provide innovative responses to customer needs, to develop and manufacture new products, and to enhance existing product lines is important to its success.
897077_16_ITEM1_P83_S0	The Company continually conducts research and development activities in an effort to improve existing products and develop new products.
897077_16_ITEM1_P83_S1	As of December 31, 2015 , the Company employed 163 people in its various engineering departments, 96 of whom are degreed engineers and the balance of whom are support staff.
897077_16_ITEM1_P83_S2	Amounts expended on research and development activities were approximately $ 8,590,000 in 2015 , $ 8,427,000 in 2014 and $ 7,164,000 in 2013 .
897077_16_ITEM1_P83_S3	As a percentage of sales, research and development was approximately 1.0% in 2015 , 1.0% in 2014 and 1.1% in 2013 , and is expected to continue at similar levels in 2016 .
897077_16_ITEM1_P84_S0	The Company s sales, for both product and replacement parts, are generally higher in the second and third quarters of the year, because a substantial number of the Company s products are used for maintenance activities such as vegetation maintenance, highway right-of-way maintenance, construction, and street and parking lot sweeping.
897077_16_ITEM1_P84_S1	Usage of this equipment is typically lower in harsh weather.
897077_16_ITEM1_P85_S0	The Company utilizes an annual twelve-month sales forecast provided by the Company s marketing departments which is updated quarterly in order to develop a production plan for its manufacturing facilities.
897077_16_ITEM1_P85_S1	In addition, many of the Company s marketing departments attempt to equalize demand for products throughout the calendar year by offering seasonal sales programs which may provide additional incentives, including discounts and extended payment terms.
897077_16_ITEM1_P86_S0	The Company s products are sold in highly competitive markets throughout the world.
897077_16_ITEM1_P86_S1	The principal competitive factors are price, quality, availability, service and reputation.
897077_16_ITEM1_P86_S2	The Company competes with several large national and international companies that offer a broad range of equipment and replacement parts, as well as with numerous small, privately-held manufacturers and suppliers of a limited number of products, mainly on a regional basis.
897077_16_ITEM1_P86_S3	Some of the Company s competitors are significantly larger than the Company and have substantially greater financial and other resources at their disposal.
897077_16_ITEM1_P86_S4	The Company believes that it is able to compete successfully in its markets by effectively managing its manufacturing costs, offering high quality products, developing and designing innovative products and, to some extent, avoiding direct competition with significantly larger potential competitors.
897077_16_ITEM1_P86_S5	There can be no assurance that the Company s competitors will not substantially increase the resources devoted to the development and marketing of products competitive with the Company s products or that new competitors with greater resources will not enter the Company s markets.
897077_16_ITEM1_P87_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , the Company had unfilled customer orders of $ 162,959,000 compared to $ 160,910,000 at December 31, 2014 .
897077_16_ITEM1_P87_S1	Management expects that substantially all of the Company s backlog as of December 31, 2015 will be shipped during fiscal year 2016 .
897077_16_ITEM1_P88_S0	The amount of unfilled orders at a particular time is affected by a number of factors, including manufacturing and shipping schedules which, in most instances, are dependent on the Company s seasonal sales programs and the requirements of its customers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P88_S1	Certain of the Company s orders are subject to cancellation at any time before shipment; therefore, a comparison of unfilled orders from period to period is not necessarily meaningful and may not be indicative of future actual shipments.
897077_16_ITEM1_P89_S0	No single customer is responsible for 10% or more of the aggregate revenue of the Company.
897077_16_ITEM1_P90_S0	The principal raw materials used by the Company include steel, other metal components, hydraulic hoses, paint and tires.
897077_16_ITEM1_P90_S1	During 2015 , the raw materials needed by the Company were available from a variety of sources in adequate quantities and at prevailing market prices.
897077_16_ITEM1_P90_S2	No one supplier is responsible for supplying more than 10% of the principal raw materials used by the Company.
897077_16_ITEM1_P91_S0	While the Company manufactures many of the parts for its products, a significant percentage of parts, including most drivelines, gearboxes, industrial engines, and hydraulic components, are purchased from outside suppliers which manufacture to the Company s specifications.
897077_16_ITEM1_P91_S1	In addition, the Company, through its subsidiaries, purchases tractors and truck chassis as a number of the Company s products are mounted and shipped with a tractor or truck chassis.
897077_16_ITEM1_P91_S2	Tractors and truck chassis are generally available, but some delays in receiving tractors or truck chassis can occur throughout the year.
897077_16_ITEM1_P92_S0	The Company sources its purchased goods from international and domestic suppliers.
897077_16_ITEM1_P92_S1	No single supplier is responsible for supplying more than 10% of the purchased goods used by the Company.

897077_16_ITEM1_P97_S0	The Company knows that its Indianola, Iowa property is contaminated with chromium which most likely resulted from chrome plating operations which were discontinued before the Company purchased the property.
897077_16_ITEM1_P97_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.
897077_16_ITEM1_P97_S2	The Company voluntarily worked with an environmental consultant and the state of Iowa with respect to these issues and believes it completed its remediation program in June 2006.
897077_16_ITEM1_P97_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_16_ITEM1_P97_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_16_ITEM1_P97_S5	We received a conditional no further action letter in January of 2009.
897077_16_ITEM1_P97_S6	When we demonstrate stable or improving conditions below residential standards for a certain period of time by monitoring existing wells, we will request an unconditional no further action letter.
897077_16_ITEM1_P98_S0	The Company knows that Bush Hog s main manufacturing property in Selma, Alabama was contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic compounds which most likely resulted from painting and cleaning operations during the 1960s and 1970s.
897077_16_ITEM1_P98_S1	The contaminated areas were primarily in the location of underground storage tanks and underneath the former waste storage area.
897077_16_ITEM1_P98_S2	Under the Asset Purchase Agreement, Bush Hog s prior owner agreed to and has removed the underground storage tanks at its cost and has remediated the identified contamination in accordance with the regulations of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management.
897077_16_ITEM1_P98_S3	An environmental consulting firm was retained by the prior owner to administer the cleanup and monitor the site on an ongoing basis until the remediation program is complete and approved by the applicable authorities.
897077_16_ITEM1_P98_S4	The remediation process has been completed.
897077_16_ITEM1_P98_S5	On August 6, 2015, Bush Hog received a letter of concurrence from the Alabama Department of Environmental Management concluding that Bush Hog had successfully remediated that property and that the site was eligible for liability protection under the Land Recycling and Economic Redevelopment Act for contamination discovered and addressed under Bush Hog's voluntary cleanup plan.
897077_16_ITEM1_P99_S0	Certain assets of the Company contain asbestos that may have to be remediated over time.
897077_16_ITEM1_P99_S1	The Company believes that any subsequent change in the liability associated with the asbestos removal will not have a material adverse effect on the Company s consolidated financial position or results of operations.
897077_16_ITEM1_P100_S0	The Company is subject to various other federal, state, and local laws affecting its business, as well as a variety of regulations relating to such matters as working conditions, equal employment opportunities, and product safety.
897077_16_ITEM1_P100_S1	A variety of state laws regulate the Company s contractual relationships with its dealers, some of which impose restrictive standards on the relationship between the Company and its dealers, including events of default, grounds for termination, non-renewal of dealer contracts, and equipment repurchase requirements.
897077_16_ITEM1_P100_S2	The Company believes it is currently in material compliance with all such applicable laws and regulations.

897077_16_ITEM1A_P0_S0	You should carefully consider each of the risks described below, together with all of the other information contained in this Annual Report on Form 10-K, before making an investment decision with respect to the Company s securities.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P0_S1	If any of the following risks develop into actual events, the Company s business, financial condition or results from operations could be materially and adversely affected and you could lose all or part of your investment.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Deterioration of industry conditions could harm our business, results of operations and financial condition.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our business depends to a large extent upon the prospects for the mowing, right-of-way maintenance and agricultural markets in general.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Future prospects of the industry depend largely on factors outside of our control.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Any of those factors could adversely impact demand for our products, which could adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P3_S0	increase in unfunded pension plan liability due to financial market deterioration.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P4_S0	In addition, our business is susceptible to a number of factors that specifically affect agricultural customer spending patterns, including the following:
897077_16_ITEM1A_P5_S0	A downturn in general economic conditions and outlook in the United States and around the world could adversely affect our net sales and earnings.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The strength and profitability of our business depends on the overall demand for our products and upon economic conditions and outlook, including but not limited to economic growth rates; consumer spending levels; financing availability, pricing and terms for our dealers and end-users; employment rates; interest rates; inflation; consumer confidence and general economic and political conditions and expectations in the United States and the other economies in which we conduct business.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P7_S0	outlook could cause consumers to continue to reduce spending, which may cause them to delay or forgo purchases of our products and could have an adverse effect on our net sales and earnings.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P8_S0	We depend on governmental sales and a decrease in such sales could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P9_S0	A substantial portion of our revenues is derived from sales to federal, state and local governmental entities and related contractors, both in the U.S. and in other countries in which we sell our products.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P9_S1	These sales depend primarily on the levels of budgeted and appropriated expenditures for highway, airport, roadside and parks maintenance by various governmental entities and are affected by changes in local and national economic conditions.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our dependence on, and the price and availability of, raw materials as well as purchased components may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We are subject to fluctuations in market prices for raw materials such as steel and energy.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P11_S1	In addition, although most of the raw materials and purchase components we use are commercially available from a number of sources, we could experience disruptions in the availability of such materials.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P11_S2	If we are unable to purchase materials we require or are unable to pass on price increases to our customers or otherwise reduce our cost of goods sold, our business, results of operations and financial condition may be adversely affected.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P11_S3	In addition, higher energy costs could negatively affect spending by farmers, including their purchases of our products.
897077_16_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Impairment in the carrying value of goodwill could negatively impact our consolidated results of operations and net worth.

897077_16_ITEM3_P2_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.
897077_16_ITEM3_P2_S2	The Company voluntarily worked with an environmental consultant and the state of Iowa with respect to these issues and believes it completed its remediation program in June 2006.
897077_16_ITEM3_P2_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_16_ITEM3_P2_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_16_ITEM3_P2_S5	We received a conditional no further action letter in January of 2009.
897077_16_ITEM3_P2_S6	When we demonstrate stable or improving conditions below residential standards for a certain period of time by monitoring existing wells, we will request an unconditional no further action letter.
897077_16_ITEM3_P3_S0	The Company knows that Bush Hog s main manufacturing property in Selma, Alabama was contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic compounds which most likely resulted from painting and cleaning operations during the 1960s and 1970s.
897077_16_ITEM3_P3_S1	The contaminated areas were primarily in the location of underground storage tanks and underneath the former waste storage area.
897077_16_ITEM3_P3_S2	Under the Asset Purchase Agreement, Bush Hog s prior owner agreed to and has removed the underground storage tanks at its cost and has remediated the identified contamination in accordance with the regulations of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management.
897077_16_ITEM3_P3_S3	An environmental consulting firm was retained by the prior owner to administer the cleanup and monitor the site on an ongoing basis until the remediation program is complete and approved by the applicable authorities.
897077_16_ITEM3_P3_S4	The remediation process has been completed.
897077_16_ITEM3_P3_S5	On August 6, 2015, Bush Hog received a letter of concurrence from the Alabama Department of Environmental Management concluding that Bush Hog had successfully remediated that property and that the site was eligible for liability protection under the Land Recycling and Economic Redevelopment Act for contamination discovered and addressed under Bush Hog's voluntary cleanup plan.

897077_16_ITEM3_P4_S1	The jury concluded that not only did the defendants not infringe the patent, but that the patent was invalid as well.
897077_16_ITEM3_P4_S2	The Company expensed $2,100,000 in legal fees related to this lawsuit in 2013.

897077_16_ITEM7_P39_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606), which supersedes the revenue recognition requirements in ASC Topic 605, Revenue Recognition, and most industry-specific guidance.
897077_16_ITEM7_P39_S1	This ASU is based on the principle that revenue is recognized to depict the transfer of goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
897077_16_ITEM7_P39_S2	The ASU also requires additional disclosure about the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from customer contracts, including significant judgments and changes in judgments, and assets recognized from costs incurred to obtain or fulfill a contract.
897077_16_ITEM7_P39_S3	The amendments in the ASU must be applied using either the retrospective or cumulative effect transition method and are effective for annual and interim periods beginning after December 15, 2016.
897077_16_ITEM7_P39_S4	In April 2015, the FASB voted to propose a delay in the effective date of this ASU for reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, with early adoption permitted as of the original effective date.
897077_16_ITEM7_P39_S5	As a result, the proposed new effective date for the Company will be January 1, 2018.
897077_16_ITEM7_P39_S6	This update could impact the timing and amounts of revenue recognized.
897077_16_ITEM7_P39_S7	We are evaluating the effects, if any, that adoption of this guidance will have on our consolidated financial statements and have not yet selected a transition approach to implement the standard.
897077_16_ITEM7_P40_S0	In April 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU) No. 2015-03, Simplifying the Presentation of Debt Issuance Costs, as part of its simplification initiative.
897077_16_ITEM7_P40_S1	ASU 2015-03 changes the presentation of debt issuance costs in financial statements.
897077_16_ITEM7_P40_S2	Under the ASU, an entity presents such costs in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the related debt liability rather than as an asset.
897077_16_ITEM7_P40_S3	Amortization of the costs is reported as interest expense.
897077_16_ITEM7_P41_S0	In August 2015, the FASB issued an update to these changes based on an announcement of the staff of the SEC.
897077_16_ITEM7_P41_S1	This change provides an exception to the April 2015 FASB changes allowing debt issuance costs related to line-of-credit arrangements to continue to be presented as an asset regardless of whether there are any outstanding borrowings under such arrangement.
897077_16_ITEM7_P41_S2	These provisions are to be applied retrospectively and are effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2015.
897077_16_ITEM7_P42_S0	Early adoption is permitted, including adoption in an interim period.
897077_16_ITEM7_P42_S1	The adoption of the changes will not materially affect our financial position or results of our operations.
897077_16_ITEM7_P43_S0	In July 2015, the FASB has issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU) No. 2015-11, Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory, as part of its simplification initiative.
897077_16_ITEM7_P43_S1	ASU 2015-11 amends existing guidance for measuring inventories.
897077_16_ITEM7_P43_S2	This amendment will require the Company to measure inventories recorded using the first-in, first-out method at the lower of cost and net realizable value.
897077_16_ITEM7_P43_S3	This amendment does not change the methodology for measuring inventories recorded using the last-in, first-out method.
897077_16_ITEM7_P43_S4	This amendment will be effective prospectively for the Company on January 1, 2017, with early adoption permitted.
897077_16_ITEM7_P43_S5	We are evaluating the effect this guidance will have on our consolidated financial statements and have not yet selected a transition approach to implement the standard.
897077_16_ITEM7_P44_S0	In September 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU) No. 2015-16, Simplifying the Accounting for Measurement-Period Adjustments from Acquisitions to simplify the accounting for adjustments made to provisional amounts recognized in a business combination.
897077_16_ITEM7_P44_S1	Adjustments that are identified during the measurement period are now required to be recorded in the reporting period in which the adjustment amounts are determined, rather than retrospectively.
897077_16_ITEM7_P44_S2	The Company adopted this amendment in the third quarter of 2015.
897077_16_ITEM7_P44_S3	The adoption did not have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements.
897077_16_ITEM7_P45_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-17 to simplify the balance sheet presentation of deferred taxes.

897077_16_ITEM7_P45_S2	The Company adopted this amendment in the fourth quarter of 2015.

897077_16_ITEM7_P51_S0	Critical Accounting Estimates Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations are based upon our Consolidated Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ).
897077_16_ITEM7_P51_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
897077_16_ITEM7_P51_S2	Management bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
897077_16_ITEM7_P51_S3	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
897077_16_ITEM7_P52_S0	An accounting policy is deemed to be critical if it requires an accounting estimate to be made based on assumptions about matters that are highly uncertain at the time the estimate is made, and if different estimates that reasonably could have been used, or changes in the accounting estimates that are reasonably likely to occur periodically, could materially impact the financial statements.
897077_16_ITEM7_P52_S1	Management believes the following critical accounting policies reflect its more significant estimates and assumptions used in the preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements.
897077_16_ITEM7_P52_S2	For further information on the critical accounting policies, see Note 1 of our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
897077_16_ITEM7_P53_S0	In the last ten years, we have acquired twelve businesses.
897077_16_ITEM7_P53_S1	The purchase prices of acquired businesses have been allocated to the tangible and intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed, based upon their estimated fair value at the date of purchase.
897077_16_ITEM7_P53_S2	The difference between the purchase price and the fair value of the net assets acquired is recorded as goodwill.
897077_16_ITEM7_P54_S0	Tangible assets are typically valued using a replacement or reproduction cost approach, considering factors such as current prices of the same or similar equipment, the age of the equipment, and economic obsolescence.
897077_16_ITEM7_P55_S0	In making other assumptions on valuation and useful lives, we considered the unique nature of the acquisition and we utilized a third-party valuation firm to assist us in the valuation of the acquired intangibles and the resulting allocation of purchase price for the acquisition.
897077_16_ITEM7_P56_S0	The Company evaluates the collectability of its accounts receivable based on a combination of factors.
897077_16_ITEM7_P56_S1	In circumstances where it is aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the Company records a specific reserve to reduce the amounts recorded to what it believes will be collected.
897077_16_ITEM7_P57_S0	The Company evaluates all receivables that are over 60 days old and will reserve specifically on a 90-day basis.
897077_16_ITEM7_P58_S0	The Company has a secured or insured interest on most of its wholegoods that each customer purchases.
897077_16_ITEM7_P58_S1	This allows the Company, in times of a difficult economy when the customer is unable to pay or has filed for bankruptcy, to repossess its inventory.
897077_16_ITEM7_P58_S2	This also allows Alamo Group in certain instances, to maintain only a reserve over its cost, which usually represents the margin on the original sales price.
897077_16_ITEM7_P59_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts balance was $ 3,484,000 on December 31, 2015 , and $ 2,853,000 on December 31, 2014 .
897077_16_ITEM7_P59_S1	The increase was primarily from the Company's U.S. operations.
897077_16_ITEM7_P60_S0	On December 31, 2015 , the Company had $ 15,094,000 in reserves for sales discounts compared to $ 15,999,000 on December 31, 2014 on product shipped to our customers under various promotional programs.
897077_16_ITEM7_P60_S1	The Company reviews the reserve quarterly based on analysis made on each program outstanding at the time.
897077_16_ITEM7_P61_S0	The Company bases its reserves on historical data relating to discounts taken by the customer under each program.
897077_16_ITEM7_P61_S1	Historically, between 85% and 95% of the Company s customers who qualify for each program actually take the discount that is available.
897077_16_ITEM7_P62_S0	The Company had a reserve of $ 9,675,000 on December 31, 2015 and $ 7,601,000 on December 31, 2014 to cover obsolete and slow moving inventory.
897077_16_ITEM7_P62_S1	The increase in the reserve was mainly from the Company's Industrial Division.
897077_16_ITEM7_P63_S0	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three-year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three-year supply.
897077_16_ITEM7_P63_S1	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_16_ITEM7_P63_S2	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_16_ITEM7_P63_S3	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three-year history has been established.
897077_16_ITEM7_P64_S0	The reserve is reviewed and, if necessary, adjustments are made on a quarterly basis.
897077_16_ITEM7_P64_S1	The Company relies on historical information when available to support its reserve.
897077_16_ITEM7_P64_S2	The Company does not adjust the reserve balance until the inventory is liquidated.
897077_16_ITEM7_P65_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood units and 90 days on parts, though some components can have warranty for longer terms.
897077_16_ITEM7_P66_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety-day to six-month lag period.
897077_16_ITEM7_P66_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the unit to file a warranty claim.
897077_16_ITEM7_P66_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_16_ITEM7_P66_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.
897077_16_ITEM7_P67_S0	The current liability warranty reserve balance was $ 5,566,000 on December 31, 2015 and $ 5,913,000 on December 31, 2014 .
897077_16_ITEM7_P67_S1	The decrease was primarily in the Company's U.S. operations.
897077_16_ITEM7_P68_S0	We test goodwill and definite lived intangible assets for impairment annually, at the reporting unit level, and whenever events or circumstances make it likely that an impairment may have occurred, such as a significant adverse change in the business climate or a decision to sell all or a portion of a reporting unit.
897077_16_ITEM7_P68_S1	During the third quarter of 2015, the Company changed its annual goodwill and intangible assets impairment testing date from December 31 to October 1.
897077_16_ITEM7_P68_S2	Management considers this accounting change preferable because it allows the Company additional time to complete the annual goodwill test.
897077_16_ITEM7_P68_S3	This change does not accelerate, delay, avoid, or cause an impairment charge, nor does this change result in adjustments to previously issued financial statements.
897077_16_ITEM7_P69_S0	We perform our annual goodwill and intangible assets impairment test and monitor for interim triggering events on an ongoing basis.
897077_16_ITEM7_P70_S0	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment utilizing a qualitative assessment or a two-step process.
897077_16_ITEM7_P70_S1	We have an option to make a qualitative assessment of a reporting unit's goodwill and intangible assets for impairment.
897077_16_ITEM7_P70_S2	If we choose to perform a qualitative assessment and determine the fair value more likely than not exceeds the carrying value, no further evaluation is necessary.
897077_16_ITEM7_P71_S0	For reporting units where we perform the two-step process, the first step requires us to compare the fair value of each reporting unit, which we primarily determine using an income approach based on the present value of discounted cash flows, to the respective carrying value, which includes goodwill and intangible assets.
897077_16_ITEM7_P71_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying value, the goodwill and intangible assets are not considered impaired.
897077_16_ITEM7_P71_S2	If the carrying value is higher than the fair value, there is an indication that an impairment may exist and the second step is required.
897077_16_ITEM7_P72_S0	In step two, the implied fair value of goodwill and intangible assets are calculated as the excess of the fair value of a reporting unit over the fair values assigned to its assets and liabilities.
897077_16_ITEM7_P72_S1	If the implied fair value of goodwill and intangible assets are less than the carrying value of the reporting unit's goodwill, the difference is recognized as an impairment loss.
897077_16_ITEM7_P73_S0	The Company has indefinite-lived assets that consist of trade names and are not subject to amortization.
897077_16_ITEM7_P73_S1	The Company tests its indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment on an annual basis at year-end, or more frequently if an event occurs or circumstances change that indicate that the fair value of an indefinite-lived intangible asset could be below its carrying amount.
897077_16_ITEM7_P73_S2	The impairment test consists of comparing the fair value of the indefinite-lived intangible asset, determined using the relief from royalty method, with its carrying amount.
897077_16_ITEM7_P73_S3	An impairment loss would be recognized for the carrying amount in excess of its fair value.
897077_16_ITEM7_P74_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_16_ITEM7_P74_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_16_ITEM7_P74_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_16_ITEM7_P74_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.
897077_16_ITEM7_P75_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , goodwill was $ 75,509,000 , which represents 13% of total assets.
897077_16_ITEM7_P76_S0	The Company recognized no goodwill impairment in 2015 , 2014 or 2013 .
897077_16_ITEM7_P76_S1	During the 2015 impairment analysis review, we performed a sensitivity analysis for goodwill impairment with respect to each of our reporting units and determined that a hypothetical 15% decline in the fair value of each reporting unit as of October 1, 2015 would not result in an impairment of goodwill for any of the reporting units.
897077_16_ITEM7_P77_S0	Management believes that the estimated valuations it arrived at are reasonable and consistent with what other marketplace participants would use in valuing the Company's components.
897077_16_ITEM7_P78_S0	assurance that these market values will not change in the future.
897077_16_ITEM7_P78_S1	For example, if discount rates demanded by the market increase, this could lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_16_ITEM7_P78_S2	If the Company's projections are not achieved in the future, this could lead management to reassess their assumptions and lead to reduced valuations under the income approach.
897077_16_ITEM7_P78_S3	If the market price of the Company's stock decreases, this could cause the Company to reassess the reasonableness of the implied control premium, which might cause management to assume a higher discount rate under the income approach which could lead to reduced valuations.
897077_16_ITEM7_P78_S4	If future similar transactions exhibit lower multiples than those observed in the past, this could lead to reduced valuations under the similar transactions approach.
897077_16_ITEM7_P78_S5	And finally, if there is a general decline in the stock market and particularly in those companies selected as comparable to the Company's components, this could lead to reduced valuations under the public company market multiple approach.

897077_16_ITEM7_P79_S1	Given the current market conditions and continued economic uncertainty, the fair value of the Company's components could deteriorate, which could result in the need to record impairment charges in future periods.

897077_16_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The Company is exposed to various financial market risks.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market prices and rates.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The Company does not enter into derivative or other financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P2_S0	A portion of the Company s operations consists of manufacturing and sales activities in international jurisdictions.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The Company manufactures its products primarily in the United States, the U.K., France, Canada and Australia.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P2_S2	The Company sells its products primarily within the markets where the products are produced, but certain of the Company s sales from its U.K. and Canadian operations are denominated in other currencies.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P2_S3	As a result, the Company s financials, specifically the value of its foreign assets, could be affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency exchange rates or weak economic conditions in the other markets in which the subsidiaries of the Company distribute their products.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P3_S0	To mitigate the short-term effect of changes in currency exchange rates on the Company s functional currency-based sales, the Company s U.K. and Canadian subsidiaries regularly enter into foreign exchange contracts for over 90% of their future net foreign currency cash receipts over a period of six months.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P3_S1	As of December 31, 2015 , the Company had a notional amount of $ 4,309,000 in outstanding forward exchange contracts related to accounts receivable.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P3_S2	A 15% fluctuation in exchange rates for these currencies would change the fair value by approximately $ 646,000 .
897077_16_ITEM7A_P3_S3	However, since these contracts offset foreign currency denominated transactions, any change in the fair value of the contracts should be offset by changes in the underlying value of the transaction.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The Company s earnings are affected by fluctuations in the value of the U.S. dollar as compared to foreign currencies, predominantly in European countries, and Canada, to a lesser extent, Australia and Brazil, as a result of the sale of its products in international markets.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P4_S1	Foreign currency forward exchange contracts in the U.K. are used to offset the earnings effects of such fluctuations.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P4_S2	On December 31, 2015 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have been a decrease in gross profit of $ 5,424,000 .
897077_16_ITEM7A_P4_S3	Comparatively, on December 31, 2014 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have been a decrease in gross profit of approximately $ 5,906,000 .
897077_16_ITEM7A_P5_S0	This calculation assumes that each exchange rate would change in the same direction relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P6_S0	may also affect the volume of sales or the foreign currency sales price as competitors products become more or less attractive.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P6_S1	The Company s sensitivity analysis of the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates does not factor in a potential change in sales levels or local currency prices.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P6_S2	The translation adjustment during 2015 was a loss of $20,112,000 .
897077_16_ITEM7A_P6_S3	On December 31, 2015 , the British pound closed at 0.6786 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.9207 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P6_S4	By comparison, on December 31, 2014 , the British pound closed at 0.6419 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.8265 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P7_S0	No assurance can be given as to future valuation of the British pound or Euro or how further movements in those or other currencies could affect future earnings or the financial position of the Company.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P8_S0	Interest Rate Risk The majority of the Company s long-term debt bears interest at variable rates.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P8_S1	Accordingly, the Company s net income is affected by changes in interest rates.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P8_S2	Assuming the average level of borrowings at variable rates and a two hundred basis point change in the 2015 average interest rate under these borrowings, the Company s 2015 interest expense would have changed by approximately $ 3,890,000 .
897077_16_ITEM7A_P9_S0	In the event of an adverse change in interest rates, management could take actions to mitigate its exposure.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P9_S1	Further, this analysis does not consider the effects of the change in the level of overall economic activity that could exist in such an environment.
897077_16_ITEM7A_P9_S2	However, challenges affecting the banking industry and credit markets in general can potentially cause changes to credit availability and cost of borrowing, which creates a level of uncertainty.

897077_16_ITEM15_P4_S0	The Company s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting, as such term is defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
897077_16_ITEM15_P4_S1	The Company s internal control over financial reporting is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles.
897077_16_ITEM15_P5_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal controls over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
897077_16_ITEM15_P5_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
897077_16_ITEM15_P6_S0	The Company s management assessed the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015 using the criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
897077_16_ITEM15_P6_S1	Based on this assessment, the Company s management concludes that, as of December 31, 2015 , the Company s internal controls over financial reporting were effective based on these criteria.

897077_16_ITEM15_P8_S0	The Board of Directors and Stockholders Alamo Group Inc:
897077_16_ITEM15_P9_S0	We have audited Alamo Group Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
897077_16_ITEM15_P9_S1	Alamo Group Inc. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Report of Management on Internal Control over Financial Reporting.
897077_16_ITEM15_P9_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
897077_16_ITEM15_P10_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
897077_16_ITEM15_P10_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
897077_16_ITEM15_P10_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
897077_16_ITEM15_P10_S3	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
897077_16_ITEM15_P10_S4	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
897077_16_ITEM15_P11_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
897077_16_ITEM15_P11_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
897077_16_ITEM15_P12_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.

897077_16_ITEM15_P35_S0	We perform our annual goodwill and intangible assets impairment test and monitor for interim triggering events on an ongoing basis.
897077_16_ITEM15_P36_S0	Goodwill is reviewed for impairment utilizing a qualitative assessment or a two-step process.
897077_16_ITEM15_P36_S1	We have an option to make a qualitative assessment of a reporting unit's goodwill and intangible assets for impairment.
897077_16_ITEM15_P36_S2	If we choose to perform a qualitative assessment and determine the fair value more likely than not exceeds the carrying value, no further evaluation is necessary.
897077_16_ITEM15_P37_S0	For reporting units where we perform the two-step process, the first step requires us to compare the fair value of each reporting unit, which we primarily determine using an income approach based on the present value of discounted cash flows, to the respective carrying value, which includes goodwill and intangible assets.
897077_16_ITEM15_P37_S1	If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying value, the goodwill and intangible assets are not considered impaired.
897077_16_ITEM15_P37_S2	If the carrying value is higher than the fair value, there is an indication that an impairment may exist and the second step is required.
897077_16_ITEM15_P38_S0	In step two, the implied fair value of goodwill and intangible assets are calculated as the excess of the fair value of a reporting unit over the fair values assigned to its assets and liabilities.
897077_16_ITEM15_P38_S1	If the implied fair value of goodwill and intangible assets are less than the carrying value of the reporting unit's goodwill, the difference is recognized as an impairment loss.
897077_16_ITEM15_P39_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_16_ITEM15_P39_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_16_ITEM15_P39_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_16_ITEM15_P39_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.

897077_16_ITEM15_P72_S0	Fair value is defined as the exchange price that would be received for an asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit price) in the principal or most advantageous market for the asset or liability in an orderly transaction between market participants.
897077_16_ITEM15_P73_S0	There is a three-tier fair value hierarchy based upon the observability of inputs used in valuation techniques.
897077_16_ITEM15_P73_S1	Observable inputs (highest level) reflect market data obtained from independent sources, while unobservable inputs (lowest level) reflect internally developed market assumptions.
897077_16_ITEM15_P73_S2	In fair value, measurements are classified under the following hierarchy:
897077_16_ITEM15_P74_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
897077_16_ITEM15_P74_S1	Level 2 Quoted prices for similar instruments in active markets; quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active; and model-derived valuations in which all significant inputs or significant value-drivers are observable in active markets.
897077_16_ITEM15_P74_S2	Level 3 Model-derived valuations in which one or more significant inputs or significant value-drivers are unobservable.
897077_16_ITEM15_P75_S0	The Company uses quoted market prices, when available, to determine fair value, and the Company classifies such measurements within Level 1.
897077_16_ITEM15_P75_S1	In some cases where market prices are not available, the Company makes use of observable market-based inputs to calculate fair value, in which case the measurements are classified with Level 2.
897077_16_ITEM15_P76_S0	If quoted or observable market prices are not available, fair value is based upon internally developed models that use, where possible, current market-based parameters such as interest rates, yield curves, currency rates, etc.
897077_16_ITEM15_P76_S1	These measurements are classified within Level 3.
897077_16_ITEM15_P77_S0	The carrying values of certain financial instruments, including cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, accounts payable, and accrued expenses, approximate fair value because of the short-term nature of these items.
897077_16_ITEM15_P77_S1	The carrying value of our debt approximates the fair value as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 , as the floating rates on our outstanding balances approximate current market rates.
897077_16_ITEM15_P78_S0	This conclusion was made based on Level 2 inputs.

897077_16_ITEM15_P95_S0	4. VALUATION AND QUALIFYING ACCOUNTS Valuation and qualifying accounts included the following:
897077_16_ITEM15_P96_S0	The Company evaluates the collectability of its accounts receivable based on a combination of factors.
897077_16_ITEM15_P96_S1	In circumstances where it is aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the Company records a specific reserve to reduce the amounts recorded to what it believes will be collected.
897077_16_ITEM15_P97_S0	The Company evaluates all receivables that are over 60 days old and will reserve specifically on a 90 -day basis.
897077_16_ITEM15_P98_S0	The Company has a secured or insured interest on most of its wholegoods that each customer purchases.
897077_16_ITEM15_P98_S1	This allows the Company, in times of a difficult economy when the customer is unable to pay or has filed for bankruptcy, to repossess its inventory.
897077_16_ITEM15_P98_S2	This also allows Alamo Group in certain instances, to maintain only a reserve over its cost, which usually represents the margin on the original sales price.
897077_16_ITEM15_P99_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts balance was $ 3,484,000 on December 31, 2015 , and $ 2,853,000 on December 31, 2014 .
897077_16_ITEM15_P99_S1	The increase was primarily from the Company's U.S. operations.
897077_16_ITEM15_P100_S0	On December 31, 2015 , the Company had $ 15,094,000 in reserves for sales discounts compared to $ 15,999,000 on December 31, 2014 on product shipped to our customers under various promotional programs.
897077_16_ITEM15_P100_S1	The decrease was due primarily to lower sales volume of the Company s agricultural products during the 2014 pre-season, which runs during the third and fourth quarters of each year with orders shipped through the second quarter of 2015.
897077_16_ITEM15_P101_S0	The Company reviews the reserve quarterly based on analysis made on each program outstanding at the time.
897077_16_ITEM15_P102_S0	The Company bases its reserves on historical data relating to discounts taken by the customer under each program.
897077_16_ITEM15_P102_S1	Historically, between 90% and 95% of the Company s customers who qualify for each program actually take the discount that is available.
897077_16_ITEM15_P103_S0	The Company had a reserve of $ 9,675,000 on December 31, 2015 and $ 7,601,000 on December 31, 2014 to cover obsolete and slow moving inventory.
897077_16_ITEM15_P103_S1	The increase in the reserve was mainly from the Company's Industrial Division.
897077_16_ITEM15_P104_S0	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three -year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent ; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three -year supply.
897077_16_ITEM15_P104_S1	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_16_ITEM15_P104_S2	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_16_ITEM15_P104_S3	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three -year history has been established.
897077_16_ITEM15_P105_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood units and 90 days on parts, though some components can have warranty for longer terms.
897077_16_ITEM15_P106_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety -day to six -month lag period.
897077_16_ITEM15_P106_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the unit to file a warranty claim.
897077_16_ITEM15_P106_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_16_ITEM15_P106_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.
897077_16_ITEM15_P107_S0	The current liability warranty reserve balance was $ 5,566,000 on December 31, 2015 and $ 5,913,000 on December 31, 2014 and are included in Note 9.
897077_16_ITEM15_P107_S1	The decrease was primarily in the Company's U.S. operations.

897077_16_ITEM15_P108_S1	The excess of current costs over LIFO-valued inventories was $ 8,712,000 and $ 10,230,000 on December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014 , respectively.

897077_16_ITEM15_P121_S1	A measurement may therefore be classified within Level 3 even though there may be significant inputs that are readily observable.

897077_16_ITEM15_P125_S0	The implied value of goodwill is determined by allocating the acquisition cost to all of the assets and liabilities of the acquired entity, with the residual amount allocated to goodwill.
897077_16_ITEM15_P126_S0	All of our nonrecurring valuations use significant unobservable inputs and therefore fall under Level 3 of the fair value hierarchy.

897077_16_ITEM15_P163_S0	The Company employs a building block approach in determining the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
897077_16_ITEM15_P163_S1	Historical markets are studied and long-term historical relationships between equities and fixed income are preserved consistent with the widely accepted capital market principle that assets with higher volatility generate a greater return over the long run.
897077_16_ITEM15_P163_S2	Current market factors such as inflation and interest rates are evaluated before long-term market assumptions are determined.
897077_16_ITEM15_P163_S3	The long-term portfolio return is established via a building block approach with proper consideration of diversification and rebalancing.
897077_16_ITEM15_P163_S4	Peer data and historical returns are reviewed to check for reasonability and appropriateness.

897077_16_ITEM15_P166_S0	The Company employs a total return investment approach whereby a mix of equities and fixed income investments are used to maximize the long-term return of plan assets for a prudent level of risk.
897077_16_ITEM15_P166_S1	Risk tolerance is established through careful consideration of plan liabilities, plan funded status, and corporate financial condition.
897077_16_ITEM15_P167_S0	The investment portfolio contains a diversified blend of equity and fixed income investments.
897077_16_ITEM15_P167_S1	Furthermore, equity investments are diversified across U.S. and non-U.S. stocks, as well as growth, value, and small and large capitalizations.
897077_16_ITEM15_P167_S2	Other assets such as real estate, private equity, and hedge funds are used judiciously to enhance long-term returns while improving portfolio diversification.
897077_16_ITEM15_P167_S3	Derivatives may be used to gain market exposure in an efficient and timely manner; however, derivatives may not be used to leverage the portfolio beyond the market value of the underlying investments.
897077_16_ITEM15_P168_S0	Investment risk is measured and monitored on an ongoing basis through quarterly investment portfolio reviews, annual liability measurements, and periodic asset/liability studies.
897077_16_ITEM15_P169_S0	Our current asset allocations are consistent with our targeted allocations.

897077_16_ITEM15_P177_S0	The Board of Directors of the Company adopted the Alamo Group Inc. Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (the SERP ), effective as of January 3, 2011.
897077_16_ITEM15_P177_S1	The SERP will benefit certain key management or other highly compensated employees of the Company and/or certain subsidiaries who are selected by the Compensation Committee and approved by the Board to participate.
897077_16_ITEM15_P178_S0	The SERP is intended to provide a benefit from the Company upon retirement, death or disability, or a change in control of the Company.
897077_16_ITEM15_P178_S1	Accordingly, the SERP obligates the Company to pay to a participant a Retirement Benefit (as defined in the SERP) upon the occurrence of certain payment events to the extent a participant has a vested right thereto.
897077_16_ITEM15_P178_S2	A participant s right to his or her Retirement Benefit becomes vested in the Company s contributions upon 10 years of Credited Service (as defined in the SERP) or a change in control of the Company.
897077_16_ITEM15_P178_S3	The Retirement Benefit is based on 20% of the final three -year average salary of each participant on or after his or her normal retirement age ( 65 years of age).
897077_16_ITEM15_P178_S4	In the event of the participant s death or a change in control, the participant s vested retirement benefit will be paid in a lump sum to the participant or his or her estate, as applicable, within 90 days after the participant s death or a change in control, as applicable.
897077_16_ITEM15_P178_S5	In the event the participant is entitled to a benefit from the SERP due to disability, retirement or other termination of employment, the benefit will be paid in monthly installments over a period of fifteen years.
897077_16_ITEM15_P179_S0	The Company records amounts relating to the SERP based on calculations that incorporate various actuarial and other assumptions, including discount rates, rate of compensation increases, retirement dates and life expectancies.
897077_16_ITEM15_P179_S1	The net periodic costs are recognized as employees render the services necessary to earn the SERP benefits.
897077_16_ITEM15_P180_S0	In connection with the initiation of the SERP, the Company had an unfunded long-term liability of $1,964,301 , a deferred tax asset of $746,000 , and $1,218,301 in accumulated other comprehensive income.
897077_16_ITEM15_P180_S1	The $1,964,301 includes prior service cost which will be amortized over the average remaining service periods of the employees.
897077_16_ITEM15_P180_S2	The prior service cost is included as a component of net periodic pension cost.

897077_16_ITEM15_P200_S0	Like other manufacturers, the Company is subject to a broad range of federal, state, local and foreign laws and requirements, including those concerning air emissions, discharges into waterways, and the generation, handling, storage, transportation, treatment and disposal of hazardous substances and waste materials, as well as the remediation of contamination associated with releases of hazardous substances at the Company s facilities and off-site disposal locations, workplace safety and equal employment opportunities.
897077_16_ITEM15_P200_S1	These laws and regulations are constantly changing, and it is impossible to predict with accuracy the effect that changes to such laws and regulations may have on the Company in the future.
897077_16_ITEM15_P201_S0	Like other industrial concerns, the Company s manufacturing operations entail the risk of noncompliance, and there can be no assurance that the Company will not incur material costs or other liabilities as a result thereof.
897077_16_ITEM15_P202_S0	The Company knows that its Indianola, Iowa property is contaminated with chromium which most likely resulted from chrome plating operations which were discontinued before the Company purchased the property.
897077_16_ITEM15_P202_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.
897077_16_ITEM15_P202_S2	The Company voluntarily worked with an environmental consultant and the state of Iowa with respect to these issues and believes it completed its remediation program in June 2006.
897077_16_ITEM15_P202_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_16_ITEM15_P202_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_16_ITEM15_P202_S5	We received a conditional no further action letter in January of 2009.
897077_16_ITEM15_P202_S6	When we demonstrate stable or improving conditions below residential standards for a certain period of time by monitoring existing wells, we will request an unconditional no further action letter.
897077_16_ITEM15_P203_S0	The Company knows that Bush Hog s main manufacturing property in Selma, Alabama was contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic compounds which most likely resulted from painting and cleaning operations during the 1960s and 1970s.
897077_16_ITEM15_P203_S1	The contaminated areas were primarily in the location of underground storage tanks and underneath the former waste storage area.
897077_16_ITEM15_P203_S2	Under the Asset Purchase Agreement, Bush Hog s prior owner agreed to and has removed the underground storage tanks at its cost and has remediated the identified contamination in accordance with the regulations of the Alabama Department of Environmental Management.
897077_16_ITEM15_P204_S0	consulting firm was retained by the prior owner to administer the cleanup and monitor the site on an ongoing basis until the remediation program is complete and approved by the applicable authorities.
897077_16_ITEM15_P204_S1	The remediation process has been completed.
897077_16_ITEM15_P204_S2	On August 6, 2015, Bush Hog received a letter of concurrence from the Alabama Department of Environmental Management concluding that Bush Hog had successfully remediated that property and that the site was eligible for liability protection under the Land Recycling and Economic Redevelopment Act for contamination discovered and addressed under Bush Hog's voluntary cleanup plan.
897077_16_ITEM15_P205_S0	Alamo Group Inc. and Bush Hog, Inc. were added as defendants in 2013 to ongoing litigation by Deere Company as plaintiff against Bush Hog, LLC (now Duroc, LLC) and Great Plains Manufacturing Incorporated, in which Deere alleged infringement of a mower-related patent.
897077_16_ITEM15_P205_S1	The jury concluded that not only did the defendants not infringe the patent, but that the patent was invalid as well.
897077_16_ITEM15_P205_S2	The Company expensed $2,100,000 in legal fees related to this lawsuit in 2013.
897077_16_ITEM15_P205_S3	Deere Company has appealed and requested a new trial.
897077_16_ITEM15_P205_S4	A hearing on the appeal was held on October 8, 2015.
897077_16_ITEM15_P205_S5	A final ruling on the appeal is expected in 2016.
897077_16_ITEM15_P206_S0	Certain assets of the Company contain asbestos that may have to be remediated over time.
897077_16_ITEM15_P206_S1	The Company believes that any subsequent change in the liability associated with the asbestos removal will not have a material adverse effect on the Company s consolidated financial position or results of operations.
897077_16_ITEM15_P207_S0	The Company is subject to various other federal, state, and local laws affecting its business, as well as a variety of regulations relating to such matters as working conditions, equal employment opportunities, and product safety.
897077_16_ITEM15_P207_S1	A variety of state laws regulate the Company s contractual relationships with its dealers, some of which impose restrictive standards on the relationship between the Company and its dealers, including events of default, grounds for termination, non-renewal of dealer contracts, and equipment repurchase requirements.

897077_17_ITEM1_P0_S0	Unless the context otherwise requires, the terms the Company, we, our and us refer to Alamo Group Inc. and its subsidiaries on a consolidated basis.
897077_17_ITEM1_P1_S0	The Company is a leader in the design and manufacture of high quality agricultural equipment and infrastructure maintenance equipment for governmental and industrial use.
897077_17_ITEM1_P1_S1	The Company s products include tractor-mounted mowing and other vegetation maintenance equipment, street sweepers, excavators, vacuum trucks, snow removal equipment, pothole patchers, zero turn radius mowers, agricultural implements and related aftermarket parts.
897077_17_ITEM1_P1_S2	The Company emphasizes high quality, cost-effective products for its customers and strives to develop and market innovative products while constantly monitoring and seeking to contain its manufacturing and overhead costs.
897077_17_ITEM1_P1_S3	The Company has a long-standing strategy of supplementing its internal growth through acquisitions of businesses or product lines that currently complement, command, or have the potential to achieve a meaningful share of their niche markets.
897077_17_ITEM1_P1_S4	The Company has approximately 2,900 employees and operates a total of twenty-four plants in North America, Europe, Australia and Brazil.
897077_17_ITEM1_P1_S5	The Company sells its products primarily through a network of independent dealers and distributors to governmental end-users, related independent contractors, as well as to the agricultural and commercial turf markets.
897077_17_ITEM1_P1_S6	The primary markets for our products are North America and Western Europe.
897077_17_ITEM1_P2_S0	The predecessor corporation to Alamo Group Inc. was incorporated in the State of Texas in 1969, as a successor to a business that began selling mowing equipment in 1955, and Alamo Group Inc. was reincorporated in the State of Delaware in 1987.
897077_17_ITEM1_P3_S0	Since its founding in 1969, the Company has focused on satisfying customer needs through geographic market expansion, product development and refinement, and selected acquisitions.
897077_17_ITEM1_P4_S0	The Company s first products were based on rotary cutting technology.
897077_17_ITEM1_P4_S1	Through acquisitions, the Company added flail cutting technology in 1983 and sickle-bar cutting technology in 1984.
897077_17_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Company added to its presence in the industrial and governmental vegetation markets with the acquisition of Tiger Corporation ( Tiger ) in late 1994.
897077_17_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Company entered the agricultural mowing markets in 1986 with the acquisition of Rhino Products Inc. ( Rhino ) , a leading manufacturer in this field.
897077_17_ITEM1_P6_S1	With this acquisition, the Company embarked on a strategy to increase the Rhino dealer distribution network during a period of industry contraction.
897077_17_ITEM1_P6_S2	The addition of M W Gear Company ( M W ) in early 1995 allowed the Company to enter into the manufacturing and distribution of tillage equipment, which complements the Rhino distribution network.
897077_17_ITEM1_P6_S3	M W has been integrated into the agricultural marketing group.
897077_17_ITEM1_P7_S0	In 1991, the Company began its international expansion with the acquisition of McConnel Ltd .
897077_17_ITEM1_P7_S1	( McConnel ) , a United Kingdom ( U.K. ) manufacturer of vegetation maintenance equipment, principally hydraulic boom-mounted hedge and grass cutters and related parts.
897077_17_ITEM1_P7_S2	( Bomford ) , also a U.K. company, was acquired in 1993.
897077_17_ITEM1_P8_S0	Bomford is a manufacturer of heavy-duty, tractor-mounted grass and hedge mowing equipment.
897077_17_ITEM1_P8_S1	McConnel and Bomford sell their products to dealers and distributors through their respective sales forces.
897077_17_ITEM1_P9_S0	In 1994, the Company acquired Signalisation Moderne Autoroutiere S.A .
897077_17_ITEM1_P9_S1	( SMA ) located in Orleans, France.
897077_17_ITEM1_P9_S2	SMA manufactures and sells principally a line of heavy-duty, tractor-mounted grass and hedge mowing equipment and associated replacement parts primarily to departments of the French government.
897077_17_ITEM1_P9_S3	This acquisition, along with the acquisitions of Forges Gorce, a flail blade manufacturer in France, in 1996 and Rousseau Holdings S.A. ( Rousseau ), a leading French manufacturer of hedge and verge mowers, in 2004, when combined with McConnel and Bomford, has made the Company one of the largest manufacturers in the European market for the kind of equipment sold by the Company.
897077_17_ITEM1_P10_S0	In 1995, the Company expanded its business in the agricultural market with the acquisition of Herschel Corporation ( Herschel ) , a manufacturer and distributor of aftermarket farm equipment replacement and wear parts.
897077_17_ITEM1_P11_S0	In 2000, the Company acquired Schwarze Industries, Inc .
897077_17_ITEM1_P11_S1	Schwarze is a manufacturer of a broad range of street sweeping equipment which is sold to governmental agencies and contractors.
897077_17_ITEM1_P11_S2	The Company believes the Schwarze sweeper products fit the Company s strategy of identifying product offerings with brand recognition in the industrial markets the Company serves.
897077_17_ITEM1_P12_S0	In 2004, the Company purchased the pothole patcher product line from Wildcat Manufacturing, Inc.
897077_17_ITEM1_P12_S1	The product line was merged into the Schwarze operation and is complementary to its current product offerings.
897077_17_ITEM1_P13_S0	In 2000, the Company purchased the product line and associated assets of Twose of Tiverton Ltd.
897077_17_ITEM1_P13_S1	( Twose ) a small regional manufacturer of power arm flail mowers and parts, as well as harrows and rollers in the U.K.
897077_17_ITEM1_P13_S2	They consolidated their operations into the existing facilities at McConnel and Bomford .
897077_17_ITEM1_P14_S0	In 2000, the Company acquired Schulte Industries Ltd. and its related entities ( Schulte ) .
897077_17_ITEM1_P14_S1	Schulte is a Canadian manufacturer of mechanical rotary mowers, snow blowers, and rock removal equipment.
897077_17_ITEM1_P14_S2	Schulte strengthened the Company s Canadian presence in both marketing and manufacturing.
897077_17_ITEM1_P14_S3	It also expanded the Company s range of large, heavy-duty rotary mowers.
897077_17_ITEM1_P15_S0	In 2001, the Company acquired all of the assets of SMC Corporation ( SMC ).
897077_17_ITEM1_P15_S1	SMC manufactures front-end loaders and backhoes principally for Original Equipment Manufacturer ( OEM ) customers and its own SMC brand.
897077_17_ITEM1_P15_S2	This acquisition expanded the product range of our agricultural division and has since been consolidated into the Company's Gibson City, Illinois location.
897077_17_ITEM1_P16_S0	In 2002, the Company purchased inventory, fixed assets and certain other assets of Valu-Bilt Tractor Parts ( Valu-Bilt ) , a subsidiary of Quality Stores, Inc., located in Des Moines, Iowa.
897077_17_ITEM1_P16_S1	Valu-Bilt is a distributor of new, used and rebuilt tractor parts and other agricultural spare and wear parts sold directly to customers through its catalog and the internet and on a wholesale basis to dealers.
897077_17_ITEM1_P16_S2	Subsequent to the purchase, the operations of Valu-Bilt in Des Moines, Iowa, were consolidated into the Company s Herschel facility in Indianola, Iowa.

897077_17_ITEM1_P17_S1	The Company acquired Faucheux out of administration, a form of bankruptcy in France.
897077_17_ITEM1_P17_S2	This acquisition broadened the range of our agricultural implements offered in the French market.
897077_17_ITEM1_P17_S3	During 2016, the Company restructured and consolidated the Faucheux operations into the Company's facility near Lyon, France.

897077_17_ITEM1_P19_S0	Spearhead manufactures a range of tractor-mounted vegetation maintenance equipment, including reach mowers, flail mowers and rotary cutters.

897077_17_ITEM1_P84_S4	The Company believes that it is able to compete successfully in its markets by effectively managing its manufacturing costs, offering high quality products, developing and designing innovative products and, to some extent, avoiding direct competition with significantly larger potential competitors.

897077_17_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Any of these developments, or the perception that any of these developments are likely to occur, could negatively affect economic growth or business activity in the U.K., the European Union and elsewhere, and could materially and adversely affect our business and results of operations.

897077_17_ITEM1A_P31_S0	In addition, we may be adversely affected if businesses that we have acquired, or that we acquire in the future, do not perform as expected.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P31_S1	An acquired business could perform below our expectations for a number of reasons, including legislative or regulatory changes that affect the areas in which the acquired business specializes, the loss of customers and dealers, general economic factors that directly affect the acquired business, and the cultural incompatibility of its management team.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P31_S2	Any or all of these reasons could adversely affect our business, results of operation and financial condition.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P32_S0	The agricultural industry and the infrastructure maintenance industry are seasonal and are affected by the weather, and seasonal fluctuations may cause our results of operations and working capital to fluctuate from quarter to quarter.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P33_S0	In general, agricultural and governmental end-users typically purchase new equipment during the first and second calendar quarters.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P33_S1	Other products such as street sweepers, excavators, snow removal equipment, front-end loaders and pothole patchers have different seasonal patterns, as do replacement parts in general.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P33_S2	In attempting to achieve efficient utilization of manpower and facilities throughout the year, we estimate seasonal demand months in advance and manufacturing capacity is scheduled in anticipation of such demand.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P33_S3	We utilize an annual plan with updated quarterly sales forecasts provided by our marketing divisions and order backlog in order to develop a production plan for our manufacturing facilities.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P33_S4	In addition, many of our marketing departments attempt to equalize demand for their products throughout the calendar year by offering seasonal sales programs which may provide additional incentives, including discounts and extended payment terms, on equipment that is ordered during off-season periods.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P33_S5	Because we spread our production and wholesale shipments throughout the year to take into account the factors described above, sales in any given period may not reflect the timing of dealer orders and retail demand.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P34_S0	Weather conditions and general economic conditions may affect the timing of purchases and actual industry conditions might differ from our forecasts.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P34_S1	Consequently, sudden or significant declines in industry demand could adversely affect our working capital or results of operations.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P35_S0	If we do not retain key personnel and attract and retain other highly skilled employees, our business may suffer.

897077_17_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Increasingly stringent engine emission regulations could impact our ability to sell certain of our products into the market and appropriately price certain of our products, which could negatively affect our competitive position and financial results.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P42_S0	The products we manufacture or sell, particularly engines, are subject to increasingly stringent environmental emissions regulations.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P42_S1	For instance, the EPA has adopted increasingly stringent engine emissions regulations, including Tier 4 emission requirements applicable to diesel engines in specified horsepower ranges that are used in some of our products.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P42_S2	As of January 1, 2012, such requirements expanded to additional horsepower categories and, accordingly, apply to more of the products we sell.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P42_S3	While we have developed and implemented plans to achieve full and timely compliance with these requirements, our ability to meet the Tier 4 requirements is subject to many variables, some of which are beyond our direct control.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P42_S4	If we fail to meet the Tier 4 requirements and any other EPA emission standards that are currently in place or that may be introduced in the future, our ability to sell our products into the market may be limited, which could have a material adverse effect on our competitive position and financial results.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P43_S0	We are subject on an ongoing basis to the risk of product liability claims and other litigation arising in the ordinary course of business.
897077_17_ITEM1A_P44_S0	Like other manufacturers, we are subject to various claims, including product liability claims, arising in the ordinary course of business, and we are a party to various legal proceedings that constitute routine litigation incidental to our business.
