897077_17_ITEM3_P2_S0	The Company knows that its Indianola, Iowa property is contaminated with chromium which most likely resulted from chrome plating operations which were discontinued before the Company purchased the property.
897077_17_ITEM3_P2_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.
897077_17_ITEM3_P2_S2	The Company voluntarily worked with an environmental consultant and the state of Iowa with respect to these issues and believes it completed its remediation program in June 2006.
897077_17_ITEM3_P2_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_17_ITEM3_P2_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_17_ITEM3_P2_S5	We received a conditional no further action letter in January of 2009.
897077_17_ITEM3_P2_S6	When we demonstrate stable or improving conditions below residential standards for a certain period of time by monitoring existing wells, we will request an unconditional no further action letter.
897077_17_ITEM3_P3_S0	Alamo Group Inc. and Bush Hog, Inc. were added as defendants in 2013 to litigation by Deere Company as plaintiff against Bush Hog, LLC (now Duroc, LLC) and Great Plains Manufacturing Incorporated, in which Deere alleged infringement of a mower-related patent.
897077_17_ITEM3_P3_S1	The jury concluded that not only did the defendants not infringe the patent, but that the patent was invalid as well.
897077_17_ITEM3_P3_S2	The Company expensed $2,100,000 in legal fees related to this lawsuit in 2013.
897077_17_ITEM3_P3_S3	Deere Company appealed and requested a new trial.
897077_17_ITEM3_P3_S4	A hearing on the appeal was held on October 8, 2015.
897077_17_ITEM3_P3_S5	On May 26, 2016 the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the lower court ruling and validating the jury s finding that the defendants did not infringe the patent, and that the Deere Company patent was invalid.
897077_17_ITEM3_P3_S6	This matter has been finally adjudicated and is no longer subject to further appeal by Deere Company or any other parties.

897077_17_ITEM7_P1_S0	The Company s net sales in the fiscal year ended December 31, 2016 ( 2016 ) were $ 844,748,000 , a decrease of $ 34,829,000 or 4.0% compared to $ 879,577,000 for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2015 ( 2015 ).
897077_17_ITEM7_P1_S1	The Industrial Division was down 2.9% which was affected by soft market conditions mainly from lower sales of vacuum trucks specifically to non-governmental end users.
897077_17_ITEM7_P1_S2	Sales of excavators, sweepers, mowing equipment and to a lesser extent, snow removal products were up in 2016 compared to 2015.
897077_17_ITEM7_P1_S3	Agricultural Division sales were down 1.2% for 2016 due to a continued weak agricultural market compared to the same period in 2015.
897077_17_ITEM7_P1_S4	Sales in the European Division were down 10.3% as sales of products manufactured in the U.K. were negatively affected by soft market conditions and currency translation rates which the Company believed was due, in part, to the uncertainty created by the recent Brexit vote in the U.K.
897077_17_ITEM7_P2_S0	Net Industrial sales were $ 484,088,000 in 2016 compared to $ 498,761,000 in 2015 , a decrease of $ 14,673,000 or 2.9% .
897077_17_ITEM7_P2_S1	The decrease came from lower vacuum trucks sales to non-governmental end users.
897077_17_ITEM7_P2_S2	Increased sales from sweeper, excavator, mowing equipment and snow removal equipment product lines were not enough to offset the decline in sales of vacuum truck products.
897077_17_ITEM7_P3_S0	Net Agricultural sales were $ 205,834,000 in 2016 compared to $ 208,257,000 in 2015 , representing a decrease of $ 2,423,000 or 1.2% .
897077_17_ITEM7_P3_S1	The decrease in sales for 2016 compared to 2015 was from the continued softness in the overall agricultural market.
897077_17_ITEM7_P4_S0	Net European sales decreased $ 17,733,000 or 10.3% to $ 154,826,000 in 2016 compared to $ 172,559,000 in 2015 .
897077_17_ITEM7_P4_S1	The decrease in 2016 was primarily due to the negative effect on sales from changes in currency translation rates.
897077_17_ITEM7_P4_S2	The European Division continued to be faced with challenging market conditions in the U.K. Rivard vacuum equipment and the French agricultural products had increased sales in 2016 compared to 2015 from improvements in operational execution.

897077_17_ITEM7_P5_S1	Despite lower sales volume, the gross profit increase was due to continuous improvement in production efficiencies as well as lower material costs.
897077_17_ITEM7_P5_S2	Negatively affecting both the gross profit and margin percent during 2015 was $2,740,000 in higher cost of goods sold related to the initial step-up in fair value of inventory in the Specialized business divisions acquired in 2014.

897077_17_ITEM7_P33_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606), which supersedes the revenue recognition requirements in Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") Topic 605, Revenue Recognition, and most industry-specific guidance.
897077_17_ITEM7_P33_S1	This ASU is based on the principle that revenue is recognized to depict the transfer of goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
897077_17_ITEM7_P33_S2	The ASU also requires additional disclosure about the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from customer contracts, including significant judgments and changes in judgments, and assets recognized from costs incurred to obtain or fulfill a contract.
897077_17_ITEM7_P33_S3	This update is effective as of January 1, 2018, with early adoption permitted as of January 1, 2017.
897077_17_ITEM7_P33_S4	This update could impact the timing and amounts of revenue recognized.
897077_17_ITEM7_P33_S5	We are evaluating the effects, if any, that adoption of this guidance will have on our consolidated financial statements and have not yet selected a transition approach to implement the standard.
897077_17_ITEM7_P34_S0	In July 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-11, Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory, as part of its simplification initiative.
897077_17_ITEM7_P34_S1	ASU 2015-11 amends existing guidance for measuring inventories.
897077_17_ITEM7_P34_S2	This amendment will require the Company to measure inventories recorded using the first-in, first-out method at the lower of cost and net realizable value.
897077_17_ITEM7_P34_S3	This amendment does not change the methodology for measuring inventories recorded using the last-in, first-out method.
897077_17_ITEM7_P34_S4	This amendment will be effective prospectively for the Company on January 1, 2017, with early adoption permitted.
897077_17_ITEM7_P34_S5	The adoption of the changes will not materially affect our financial position or results of our operations.
897077_17_ITEM7_P35_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02, Leases.
897077_17_ITEM7_P35_S1	This update requires that a lessee recognize in the statement of financial position a liability to make lease payments and a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset for the lease term.
897077_17_ITEM7_P35_S2	For leases with a term of 12 months or less, a lessee is permitted to make an accounting policy election by class of underlying asset not to recognize lease assets and lease liabilities.
897077_17_ITEM7_P35_S3	Similar to current guidance, the update continues to differentiate between finance leases and operating leases, however this distinction now primarily relates to differences in the manner of expense recognition over time and in the classification of lease payments in the statement of cash flows.
897077_17_ITEM7_P35_S4	The updated guidance leaves the accounting for leases by lessors largely unchanged from existing GAAP.
897077_17_ITEM7_P36_S0	Entities are required to use a modified retrospective adoption, with certain relief provisions, for leases that exist or are entered into after the beginning of the earliest comparative period in the financial statements when adopted.
897077_17_ITEM7_P36_S1	The guidance will become effective for us on January 1, 2019.
897077_17_ITEM7_P37_S0	The impacts that adoption of the ASU is expected to have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures are being evaluated.
897077_17_ITEM7_P37_S1	Additionally, we have not determined the effect of the ASU on our internal control over financial reporting or other changes in business practices and processes.
897077_17_ITEM7_P38_S0	In March 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-09, Compensation-Stock Compensation, to simplify the accounting and reporting for employee share-based payments.
897077_17_ITEM7_P38_S1	This amendment involves several aspects of the accounting for share-based payment transactions, including accounting for income taxes as it pertains to the timing of when excess tax benefits are recognized and to the recognition of excess tax benefits and tax deficiencies in the statements of income, forfeitures, minimum statutory tax withholding requirements, as well as classification of 8 excess tax benefits and employee taxes paid in the statement of cash flows.
897077_17_ITEM7_P38_S2	This amendment will be effective for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods, with early adoption permitted.
897077_17_ITEM7_P38_S3	An entity that elects early adoption must adopt all of the amendments in the same period.
897077_17_ITEM7_P38_S4	The amendments provide specific transition and disclosure guidance for each provision.
897077_17_ITEM7_P38_S5	The adoption of the changes will not materially affect our financial position or results of our operations.

897077_17_ITEM7_P39_S1	The ASU replaces the current incurred loss impairment methodology with a methodology that reflects expected credit losses.

897077_17_ITEM7_P45_S0	Critical Accounting Estimates Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations are based upon our Consolidated Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ).
897077_17_ITEM7_P45_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
897077_17_ITEM7_P45_S2	Management bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
897077_17_ITEM7_P45_S3	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
897077_17_ITEM7_P46_S0	An accounting policy is deemed to be critical if it requires an accounting estimate to be made based on assumptions about matters that are highly uncertain at the time the estimate is made, and if different estimates that reasonably could have been used, or changes in the accounting estimates that are reasonably likely to occur periodically, could materially impact the financial statements.
897077_17_ITEM7_P46_S1	Management believes the following critical accounting policies reflect its more significant estimates and assumptions used in the preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements.
897077_17_ITEM7_P46_S2	For further information on the critical accounting policies, see Note 1 of our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
897077_17_ITEM7_P47_S0	Business acquisitions are accounted for by the acquisition method of accounting.
897077_17_ITEM7_P47_S1	Under this method, the purchase price is allocated to the assets acquired and the liabilities assumed based on the fair value at the time of the acquisition.
897077_17_ITEM7_P47_S2	Any excess purchase price over the fair value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed is recorded as goodwill.
897077_17_ITEM7_P48_S0	We believe the fair values assigned to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed are based on reasonable assumptions; however, these assumptions may be incomplete or inaccurate, and unanticipated events and circumstances may occur.
897077_17_ITEM7_P49_S0	Tangible assets are typically valued using a replacement or reproduction cost approach, considering factors such as current prices of the same or similar equipment, the age of the equipment, and economic obsolescence.
897077_17_ITEM7_P50_S0	utilized a third-party valuation firm to assist us in the valuation of the acquired intangibles and the resulting allocation of purchase price for the acquisition.
897077_17_ITEM7_P51_S0	The Company evaluates the collectability of its accounts receivable based on a combination of factors.
897077_17_ITEM7_P51_S1	In circumstances where it is aware of a specific customer s inability to meet its financial obligations, the Company records a specific reserve to reduce the amounts recorded to what it believes will be collected.
897077_17_ITEM7_P52_S0	The Company evaluates all receivables that are over 60 days old and will reserve specifically on a 90-day basis.
897077_17_ITEM7_P53_S0	The Company has a secured or insured interest on most of its wholegoods that each customer purchases.
897077_17_ITEM7_P53_S1	This allows the Company, in times of a difficult economy when the customer is unable to pay or has filed for bankruptcy, to repossess its inventory.
897077_17_ITEM7_P53_S2	This also allows Alamo Group, in certain instances, to maintain only a reserve over its cost, which usually represents the margin on the original sales price.
897077_17_ITEM7_P54_S0	The allowance for doubtful accounts balance was $ 2,501,000 on December 31, 2016 , and $ 3,484,000 on December 31, 2015 .
897077_17_ITEM7_P54_S1	The decrease was primarily in the Company's U.S. operations.
897077_17_ITEM7_P55_S0	On December 31, 2016 , the Company had $ 13,488,000 in reserves for sales discounts compared to $ 15,094,000 on December 31, 2015 on product shipped to our customers under various promotional programs.
897077_17_ITEM7_P55_S1	The Company reviews the reserve quarterly based on analysis made on each program outstanding at the time.
897077_17_ITEM7_P56_S0	The Company bases its reserves on historical data relating to discounts taken by the customer under each program.
897077_17_ITEM7_P56_S1	Historically, between 85% and 95% of the Company s customers who qualify for each program actually take the discount that is available.
897077_17_ITEM7_P57_S0	The Company had a reserve of $ 7,262,000 on December 31, 2016 and $ 9,675,000 on December 31, 2015 to cover obsolete and slow moving inventory.
897077_17_ITEM7_P57_S1	The decrease in the reserve was mainly from the Company's Industrial Division.
897077_17_ITEM7_P58_S0	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three-year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three-year supply.
897077_17_ITEM7_P58_S1	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_17_ITEM7_P58_S2	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_17_ITEM7_P58_S3	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three-year history has been established.
897077_17_ITEM7_P59_S0	The reserve is reviewed and, if necessary, adjustments are made on a quarterly basis.
897077_17_ITEM7_P59_S1	The Company relies on historical information when available to support its reserve.
897077_17_ITEM7_P59_S2	The Company does not adjust the reserve balance until the inventory is liquidated.
897077_17_ITEM7_P60_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood divisions and 90 days on parts, though some components can have warranty for longer terms.
897077_17_ITEM7_P61_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety-day to six-month lag period.
897077_17_ITEM7_P61_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the division to file a warranty claim.
897077_17_ITEM7_P61_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_17_ITEM7_P61_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.
897077_17_ITEM7_P62_S0	The current liability warranty reserve balance was $ 5,262,000 on December 31, 2016 and $ 5,566,000 on December 31, 2015 .
897077_17_ITEM7_P62_S1	The decrease was primarily in the Company's U.S. operations.
897077_17_ITEM7_P63_S0	Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price of acquired businesses over the estimated fair value of the identifiable net assets acquired.
897077_17_ITEM7_P63_S1	Goodwill is not amortized but is tested at least annually for impairment at the reporting unit level.
897077_17_ITEM7_P63_S2	Definite-lived intangible assets are also tested for impairment at the reporting unit level whenever events or circumstances make it likely that an impairment may have occurred.
897077_17_ITEM7_P64_S0	Reporting units are operating segments or components of operating segments for which discrete financial information is available.
897077_17_ITEM7_P64_S1	To evaluate goodwill, the fair value of each reporting unit is compared to its carrying value.
897077_17_ITEM7_P64_S2	Where the carrying value is greater than the fair value, the implied fair value of the reporting unit goodwill is determined by allocating the fair value of the reporting unit to all the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit with any remainder being allocated to goodwill.
897077_17_ITEM7_P64_S3	The implied fair value of the reporting unit goodwill is then compared to the carrying value of that goodwill to determine whether an impairment loss exists.
897077_17_ITEM7_P64_S4	Any impairment loss is recognized in earnings.
897077_17_ITEM7_P65_S0	We typically measure the fair value of each reporting unit using a discounted cash flow analysis (income approach) based on assumptions that market participants would apply.
897077_17_ITEM7_P65_S1	Because the business is assumed to continue in perpetuity, the discounted cash flows include a terminal value.
897077_17_ITEM7_P66_S0	Cash flows to perpetuity are forecasted based on projected revenue growth and our planned business strategies in future periods.
897077_17_ITEM7_P66_S1	Examples of planned strategies would include a plant or line expansion at an existing facility; a reduction of working capital at a specific location; and price increases or cost reductions within a reporting unit.
897077_17_ITEM7_P67_S0	The discount rate is based on a reporting unit s targeted weighted-average cost of capital, which is not necessarily the same as our weighted-average cost of capital.
897077_17_ITEM7_P68_S0	We perform our annual quantitative test for goodwill impairment in the fourth quarter of each fiscal year.
897077_17_ITEM7_P68_S1	Based on the quantitative testing performed during 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , we determined that none of the goodwill associated with our reporting units were impaired in any of those years.
897077_17_ITEM7_P68_S2	These reporting units would be most likely affected by changes in the Company s assumptions and estimates.
897077_17_ITEM7_P68_S3	The calculation of fair value could increase or decrease depending on changes in the inputs and assumptions used, such as changes in the reporting unit s future growth rates, discount rates, etc.
897077_17_ITEM7_P69_S0	Impairment exists for definite-lived intangible assets when the carrying amount of an asset is not recoverable through non-discounted future cash flows and its carrying value exceeds its estimated fair value as typically determined under the income approach.
897077_17_ITEM7_P69_S1	In addition, an intangible asset's expected useful life can increase estimation risk, as longer-lived assets necessarily require longer-term cash flow forecasts.
897077_17_ITEM7_P69_S2	In connection with an impairment evaluation, we also reassess the remaining useful life of the intangible asset and modify it, as appropriate.
897077_17_ITEM7_P70_S0	Impairment exists for indefinite-lived intangible assets that consist of trademarks when the carrying amount of an asset is in excess of its fair value as determined using the royalty relief method.
897077_17_ITEM7_P70_S1	These assumptions and projections underlying the fair value estimates are subject to change and are impacted by our ability to achieve our forecasts and by economic conditions that may impact future results and result in projections not being attained.
897077_17_ITEM7_P70_S2	A change in any of these estimates and assumptions could produce a different fair value, which could have a material impact on our results of operations.
897077_17_ITEM7_P71_S0	Each year we re-evaluate the assumptions used to reflect changes in the business environment.
897077_17_ITEM7_P72_S0	See Note 6 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for more information regarding goodwill.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The Company is exposed to various financial market risks.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market prices and rates.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The Company does not enter into derivative or other financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P2_S0	A portion of the Company s operations consists of manufacturing and sales activities in international jurisdictions.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The Company manufactures its products primarily in the United States, the U.K., France, Canada, Brazil and Australia.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P3_S0	but certain of the Company s sales from its U.K. and Canadian operations are denominated in other currencies.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P3_S1	As a result, the Company s financials, specifically the value of its foreign assets, could be affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency exchange rates in the U.K. and Canada or weak economic conditions in the other markets in which the subsidiaries of the Company distribute their products.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P4_S0	To mitigate the short-term effect of changes in currency exchange rates on the Company s functional currency-based sales, the Company s U.K. and Canadian subsidiaries regularly enter into foreign exchange contracts for over 90% of their future net foreign currency cash receipts over a period of six months.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P4_S1	As of December 31, 2016 , the Company had a notional amount of $ 1,384,000 in outstanding forward exchange contracts related to accounts receivable.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P4_S2	A 15% fluctuation in exchange rates for these currencies would change the fair value by approximately $ 208,000 .
897077_17_ITEM7A_P4_S3	However, since these contracts offset foreign currency denominated transactions, any change in the fair value of the contracts should be offset by changes in the underlying value of the transaction.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The Company s earnings are affected by fluctuations in the value of the U.S. dollar as compared to foreign currencies, predominantly in European countries and Canada and, to a lesser extent, Australia and Brazil, as a result of the sale of its products in international markets.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P5_S1	Foreign currency forward exchange contracts in the U.K. are used to offset the earnings effects of such fluctuations.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P5_S2	On December 31, 2016 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have been a decrease in gross profit of $ 5,755,000 .
897077_17_ITEM7A_P5_S3	Comparatively, on December 31, 2015 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have been a decrease in gross profit of approximately $ 5,424,000 .
897077_17_ITEM7A_P6_S0	This calculation assumes that each exchange rate would change in the same direction relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P6_S1	In addition to the direct effects of changes in exchange rates, which are a changed dollar value of the resulting sales, changes in exchange rates may also affect the volume of sales or the foreign currency sales price as competitors products become more or less attractive.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P6_S2	The Company s sensitivity analysis of the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates does not factor in a potential change in sales levels or local currency prices.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P6_S3	The translation adjustment during 2016 was a loss of $13,156,000 .
897077_17_ITEM7A_P6_S4	On December 31, 2016 , the British pound closed at 0.8100 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.9506 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P6_S5	By comparison, on December 31, 2015 , the British pound closed at 0.6786 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.9207 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P7_S0	No assurance can be given as to future valuation of the British pound or Euro or how further movements in those or other currencies could affect future earnings or the financial position of the Company.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P8_S0	Interest Rate Risk The majority of the Company s long-term debt bears interest at variable rates.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P8_S1	Accordingly, the Company s net income is affected by changes in interest rates.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P8_S2	Assuming the average level of borrowings at variable rates and a two hundred basis point change in the 2016 average interest rate under these borrowings, the Company s 2016 interest expense would have changed by approximately $ 3,033,000 .
897077_17_ITEM7A_P9_S0	In the event of an adverse change in interest rates, management could take actions to mitigate its exposure.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P9_S1	Further, this analysis does not consider the effects of the change in the level of overall economic activity that could exist in such an environment.
897077_17_ITEM7A_P9_S2	However, challenges affecting the banking industry and credit markets in general can potentially cause changes to credit availability and cost of borrowing, which creates a level of uncertainty.

897077_18_ITEM1_P0_S0	Unless the context otherwise requires, the terms the Company, we, our and us refer to Alamo Group Inc. and its subsidiaries on a consolidated basis.
897077_18_ITEM1_P1_S0	The Company is a leader in the design and manufacture of high quality agricultural equipment and infrastructure maintenance equipment for governmental and industrial use.
897077_18_ITEM1_P1_S1	The Company s products include tractor-mounted mowing and other vegetation maintenance equipment, street sweepers, excavators, vacuum trucks, snow removal equipment, leaf collection equipment, pothole patchers, zero turn radius mowers, agricultural implements and related aftermarket parts.
897077_18_ITEM1_P1_S2	The Company emphasizes high quality, cost-effective products for its customers and strives to develop and market innovative products while constantly monitoring and seeking to contain its manufacturing and overhead costs.
897077_18_ITEM1_P1_S3	The Company has a long-standing strategy of supplementing its internal growth through acquisitions of businesses or product lines that currently complement, command, or have the potential to achieve a meaningful share of their niche markets.
897077_18_ITEM1_P1_S4	The Company has approximately 3,280 employees and operates a total of twenty-five plants in North America, Europe, Australia and Brazil.
897077_18_ITEM1_P1_S5	The Company sells its products primarily through a network of independent dealers and distributors to governmental end-users, related independent contractors, as well as to the agricultural and commercial turf markets.
897077_18_ITEM1_P1_S6	The primary markets for our products are North America, Europe, South America and Australia.
897077_18_ITEM1_P2_S0	The predecessor corporation to Alamo Group Inc. was incorporated in the State of Texas in 1969, as a successor to a business that began selling mowing equipment in 1955, and Alamo Group Inc. was reincorporated in the State of Delaware in 1987.
897077_18_ITEM1_P3_S0	Since its founding in 1969, the Company has focused on satisfying customer needs through geographic market expansion, product development and refinement, and selected acquisitions.
897077_18_ITEM1_P4_S0	The Company s first products were based on rotary cutting technology.
897077_18_ITEM1_P4_S1	Through acquisitions, the Company added flail cutting technology in 1983 and sickle-bar cutting technology in 1984.
897077_18_ITEM1_P5_S0	The Company added to its presence in the industrial and governmental vegetation markets with the acquisition of Tiger Corporation ( Tiger ) in late 1994.
897077_18_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Company entered the agricultural mowing markets in 1986 with the acquisition of Rhino Products Inc. ( Rhino ) , a leading manufacturer in this field.
897077_18_ITEM1_P6_S1	With this acquisition, the Company embarked on a strategy to increase the Rhino dealer distribution network during a period of industry contraction.
897077_18_ITEM1_P6_S2	The addition of M W Gear Company ( M W ) in early 1995 allowed the Company to enter into the manufacturing and distribution of tillage equipment, which complements the Rhino distribution network.
897077_18_ITEM1_P6_S3	M W has been integrated into the agricultural marketing group.
897077_18_ITEM1_P7_S0	In 1991, the Company began its international expansion with the acquisition of McConnel Ltd .
897077_18_ITEM1_P7_S1	( McConnel ) , a United Kingdom ( U.K. ) manufacturer of vegetation maintenance equipment, principally hydraulic boom-mounted hedge and grass cutters and related parts.
897077_18_ITEM1_P7_S2	( Bomford ) , also a U.K. company, was acquired in 1993.
897077_18_ITEM1_P8_S0	Bomford is a manufacturer of heavy-duty, tractor-mounted grass and hedge mowing equipment.
897077_18_ITEM1_P8_S1	McConnel and Bomford sell their products to dealers and distributors through their respective sales forces.
897077_18_ITEM1_P9_S0	In 1994, the Company acquired Signalisation Moderne Autoroutiere S.A .
897077_18_ITEM1_P9_S1	( SMA ) located in Orleans, France.
897077_18_ITEM1_P9_S2	SMA manufactures and sells principally a line of heavy-duty, tractor-mounted grass and hedge mowing equipment and associated replacement parts primarily to departments of the French government.
897077_18_ITEM1_P9_S3	This acquisition, along with the acquisitions of Forges Gorce, a flail blade manufacturer in France, in 1996 and Rousseau Holdings S.A. ( Rousseau ), a leading French manufacturer of hedge and verge mowers, in 2004, when combined with McConnel and Bomford, has made the Company one of the largest manufacturers in the European market for the kind of equipment sold by the Company.
897077_18_ITEM1_P10_S0	In 1995, the Company expanded its business in the agricultural market with the acquisition of Herschel Corporation ( Herschel ) , a manufacturer and distributor of aftermarket farm equipment replacement and wear parts.
897077_18_ITEM1_P11_S0	In 2000, the Company acquired Schwarze Industries, Inc .
897077_18_ITEM1_P11_S1	Schwarze is a manufacturer of a broad range of street sweeping equipment which is sold to governmental agencies and contractors.
897077_18_ITEM1_P11_S2	The Company believes the Schwarze sweeper products fit the Company s strategy of identifying product offerings with brand recognition in the industrial markets the Company serves.
897077_18_ITEM1_P12_S0	In 2004, the Company purchased the pothole patcher product line from Wildcat Manufacturing, Inc.
897077_18_ITEM1_P12_S1	The product line was merged into the Schwarze operation and is complementary to its current product offerings.
897077_18_ITEM1_P13_S0	In 2000, the Company purchased the product line and associated assets of Twose of Tiverton Ltd.
897077_18_ITEM1_P13_S1	( Twose ) a small regional manufacturer of power arm flail mowers and parts, as well as harrows and rollers, in the U.K.
897077_18_ITEM1_P13_S2	They consolidated their operations into the existing facilities at McConnel and Bomford .
897077_18_ITEM1_P14_S0	In 2000, the Company acquired Schulte Industries Ltd. and its related entities ( Schulte ) .
897077_18_ITEM1_P14_S1	Schulte is a Canadian manufacturer of mechanical rotary mowers, snow blowers, and rock removal equipment.
897077_18_ITEM1_P14_S2	Schulte strengthened the Company s Canadian presence in both marketing and manufacturing.
897077_18_ITEM1_P14_S3	It also expanded the Company s range of large, heavy-duty rotary mowers.
897077_18_ITEM1_P15_S0	In 2001, the Company acquired all of the assets of SMC Corporation ( SMC ).
897077_18_ITEM1_P15_S1	SMC manufactures front-end loaders and backhoes principally for Original Equipment Manufacturer ( OEM ) customers and its own SMC brand.
897077_18_ITEM1_P15_S2	This acquisition expanded the product range of our agricultural division and has since been consolidated into the Company's Gibson City, Illinois location.
897077_18_ITEM1_P16_S0	In 2002, the Company purchased inventory, fixed assets and certain other assets of Valu-Bilt Tractor Parts ( Valu-Bilt ) , a subsidiary of Quality Stores, Inc., located in Des Moines, Iowa.
897077_18_ITEM1_P16_S1	Valu-Bilt is a distributor of new, used and rebuilt tractor parts and other agricultural spare and wear parts sold directly to customers through its catalog and the internet and on a wholesale basis to dealers.
897077_18_ITEM1_P16_S2	Subsequent to the purchase, the operations of Valu-Bilt in Des Moines, Iowa, were consolidated into the Company s Herschel facility in Indianola, Iowa.
897077_18_ITEM1_P17_S0	In 2005, the Company, through its European subsidiary Alamo Group (EUR) Ltd., acquired 100% of the issued and outstanding stock of Spearhead Machinery Limited ( Spearhead ) and subsequently merged its manufacturing operations into Bomford s facility.
897077_18_ITEM1_P18_S0	Spearhead manufactures a range of tractor-mounted vegetation maintenance equipment, including reach mowers, flail mowers and rotary cutters.
897077_18_ITEM1_P18_S1	This acquisition extended our product lines and market coverage in Europe.
897077_18_ITEM1_P19_S0	In early 2006, the Company purchased substantially all of the assets of the Gradall excavator business ( Gradall ) of JLG Industries, Inc., including their manufacturing plant in New Philadelphia, Ohio.
897077_18_ITEM1_P19_S1	Gradall is a leading manufacturer of both wheeled and crawler telescopic excavators in North America.
897077_18_ITEM1_P19_S2	This acquisition enhanced our Industrial Division product offering sold to governmental buyers and related contractors for maintenance along right-of-ways.
897077_18_ITEM1_P20_S0	In 2006, the Company purchased the vacuum truck and sweeper lines of Clean Earth Environmental Group, LLC and Clean Earth Kentucky, LLC (collectively referred to as VacAll ) .
897077_18_ITEM1_P20_S1	This included the product lines, inventory and certain other assets that relate to this business.
897077_18_ITEM1_P20_S2	The production of the vacuum truck and sweeper lines were moved to the Gradall facility in New Philadelphia, Ohio.
897077_18_ITEM1_P21_S0	In 2006, the Company acquired 100% of the ownership interests in Nite-Hawk Sweepers LLC ( Nite-Hawk ) , a manufacturer of truck mounted sweeping equipment primarily for the contract sweeping market, which expanded our presence in that market and complements our Schwarze sweeper line.
897077_18_ITEM1_P22_S0	In 2007, the Company purchased Henke Manufacturing Corporation ( Henke ) , a manufacturer of specialty snow removal attachments.
897077_18_ITEM1_P22_S1	Henke s products are mounted on both heavy industrial equipment and medium to heavy-duty trucks.
897077_18_ITEM1_P22_S2	The primary end-users are governmental agencies, related contractors and other industrial users.
897077_18_ITEM1_P23_S0	In 2008, the Company acquired Rivard Developpement S.A.S. ( Rivard ) , a leading French manufacturer of vacuum trucks, high pressure cleaning systems and trenchers.
897077_18_ITEM1_P23_S1	The acquisition broadened the Company s product offering to our customers in Europe and other markets we serve.
897077_18_ITEM1_P24_S0	In 2009, the Company acquired substantially all the assets of Bush Hog, LLC ( Bush Hog ) , a leading agricultural equipment manufacturer of rotary cutters, finishing mowers, zero turn radius mowers, front-end loaders, backhoes, landscape equipment and a variety of other implements.
897077_18_ITEM1_P24_S1	This acquisition, combined with the Company s existing range of agricultural mowers, created one of the largest manufacturers of agricultural mowers in the world.
897077_18_ITEM1_P25_S0	In 2011, the Company acquired substantially all of the assets and assumed certain specified liabilities of Tenco Group, Inc. ( "Tenco" ) and its subsidiaries.
897077_18_ITEM1_P26_S0	Tenco is a Canadian-based manufacturer of snow removal equipment including snow blades, blowers, dump bodies, spreaders and associated parts and service.
897077_18_ITEM1_P26_S1	Tenco has operations in Quebec as well as New York and Vermont.
897077_18_ITEM1_P26_S2	The equipment is sold primarily through dealers to governmental end-users as well as snow removal contractors.
897077_18_ITEM1_P27_S0	In 2013, the Company acquired substantially all of the assets and assumed certain specified liabilities of Superior Equipment Australia PTY LTD ( "Superior" ).
897077_18_ITEM1_P28_S0	Superior is a small Australian-based manufacturer of agricultural mowing equipment and other attachments, parts, and services.
897077_18_ITEM1_P28_S1	The equipment is sold through dealers primarily to agricultural end-users with some sold to governmental entities in Australia.
897077_18_ITEM1_P28_S2	The Superior operations have been consolidated with the Company's Fieldquip location.
897077_18_ITEM1_P29_S0	In 2014, the Company acquired Kellands Agricultural Ltd. and its subsidiary Multidrive Tractors Ltd. ( "Kellands" ).
897077_18_ITEM1_P29_S1	Kellands is a U.K.-based manufacturer of self-propelled sprayers and a range of multi-purpose load-carrying tractor vehicles.
897077_18_ITEM1_P29_S2	This acquisition enhanced our manufacture and distribution of agricultural machinery in our European operations and allowed the Company to enter into the self-propelled sprayer market.
897077_18_ITEM1_P30_S0	In 2014, the Company acquired Fieldquip Australia PTY LTD ( "Fieldquip" ), a manufacturer of rotary cutters as well as a distributor of various agricultural products.
897077_18_ITEM1_P30_S1	This acquisition allowed the Company to broaden its presence in both the manufacturing and distribution of agricultural machinery in Australia.
897077_18_ITEM1_P31_S0	In 2014, the Company acquired all of the operating units of Specialized Industries LP.
897077_18_ITEM1_P31_S1	Howard P. Fairfield LLC (" H.P. Fairfield ") as well as several related entities ( "Specialized" ), including all brand names and related product names and trademarks.
897077_18_ITEM1_P31_S2	The primary reason for the Specialized acquisition was to broaden the Company's existing equipment lines.
897077_18_ITEM1_P31_S3	This acquisition increased our product offering and enhanced our market position both in vacuum trucks and snow removal equipment primarily in North America.
897077_18_ITEM1_P32_S0	In 2015, the Company acquired Herder Implementos e Maquinas Agricolas Ltda.
897077_18_ITEM1_P33_S0	Herder is a manufacturer of flail mowers and other agricultural implements which are sold direct and through dealers to a wide variety of agricultural markets as well as the roadside maintenance market.
897077_18_ITEM1_P33_S1	This acquisition allowed the Company to establish a presence in Brazil, one of the largest agricultural markets in the world.
897077_18_ITEM1_P34_S0	On June 6, 2017, the Company acquired 100% of the outstanding shares of Santa Izabel Agro Industria.
897077_18_ITEM1_P35_S0	Santa Izabel designs, manufactures and markets a variety of agricultural implements and trailers sold throughout Brazil.
897077_18_ITEM1_P35_S1	This acquisition along with our existing Herder operation in Brazil, augmented our product portfolio and improved our manufacturing capabilities in one of the world's largest agricultural markets.
897077_18_ITEM1_P36_S0	On June 26, 2017, the Company acquired substantially all of the assets and assumed certain specified liabilities of Old Dominion Brush Company, Inc. ( "ODB" ).
897077_18_ITEM1_P37_S0	ODB manufactures leaf collection equipment as well as replacement brooms for street sweepers, both which are sold to municipalities, contractors and commercial landscape markets in North America.
897077_18_ITEM1_P37_S1	ODB is based in Richmond, Virginia and has an assembly and warehouse operation in Missouri.
897077_18_ITEM1_P37_S2	This acquisition provided new and complementary products to our existing range of infrastructure maintenance equipment and parts.
897077_18_ITEM1_P38_S0	On August 8, 2017, the Company acquired R.P.M. Tech Inc. (" RPM "), a manufacturer of heavy duty snow removal equipment and associated parts.
897077_18_ITEM1_P39_S0	RPM primarily sells to governmental agencies, related contractors, airports and other industrial users.
897077_18_ITEM1_P39_S1	RPM's operations are in Drummondville, Quebec and will work in close proximity to the Company's nearby Tenco operations.
897077_18_ITEM1_P39_S2	This acquisition complements our existing range of snow removal products with RPM's range of heavy duty snow removal equipment including their line of mechanical snow blowers.
897077_18_ITEM1_P40_S0	The Company believes that within the U.S. it is a leading supplier to governmental markets, a leading supplier in the U.S. agricultural market, and one of the largest suppliers in the European market for its key niche product offerings.
897077_18_ITEM1_P40_S1	The Company s products are sold through the Company s various marketing organizations and extensive worldwide dealer and distributor networks under the Alamo Industrial , Terrain King , Tiger , Gradall , VacAll , Schwarze , NiteHawk , Henke , Tenco , Super Products , Wausau-Everest , H.P. Fairfield , ODB , R.P.M. Tech , Bush Hog , Rhino , Earthmaster , RhinoAg , Herschel , Valu-Bilt , CT Farm Country , Schulte , Superior , Fieldquip , Herder , Santa Izabel , McConnel , Bomford , Spearhead , Twose , Kellands , SMA , Forges Gorce , Faucheux , Rousseau and Rivard trademarks (some with related designs) as well as other trademarks and trade names.
897077_18_ITEM1_P41_S0	Alamo Industrial equipment is principally sold through independent dealers to governmental end-users, related independent contractors and, to a lesser extent, utility and other dealers serving infrastructure maintenance operators and other applications in the U.S. and other countries.
897077_18_ITEM1_P41_S1	Governmental agencies and contractors that perform services for such agencies purchase primarily hydraulically-powered, tractor-mounted mowers, including boom-mounted mowers, other types of cutters and replacement parts for heavy-duty, intensive use applications, including maintenance around highway, airport, recreational and other public areas.
897077_18_ITEM1_P42_S0	A portion of Alamo Industrial s sales includes tractors, which are not manufactured by Alamo Industrial.
897077_18_ITEM1_P43_S0	Tiger equipment includes heavy duty, tractor- and truck-mounted mowing and vegetation maintenance equipment and replacement parts.
897077_18_ITEM1_P44_S0	Tiger sells to state, county and local governmental entities and related contractors, primarily through a network of independent dealers.
897077_18_ITEM1_P44_S1	Tiger s dealer distribution network is independent of Alamo Industrial s dealer distribution network.

897077_18_ITEM1_P47_S0	Schwarze sells its products primarily to governmental agencies and independent contractors, either directly or through its independent dealer network.
897077_18_ITEM1_P47_S1	A portion of Schwarze s sales includes truck chassis which are not manufactured by Schwarze .

897077_18_ITEM1_P48_S0	ODB manufactures and sells leaf collection equipment and replacement brooms for street sweepers, both of which are sold to municipalities, contractors and commercial landscape markets in North America.
897077_18_ITEM1_P49_S0	Nite-Hawk manufactures parking lot sweepers with unique and innovative hydraulic designs.
897077_18_ITEM1_P49_S1	By eliminating the auxiliary engine, Nite-Hawk sweepers have proven to be fuel-efficient, environmentally conscious, and cost-effective to operate.

897077_18_ITEM1_P51_S1	Many of these products are designed for excavation, grading, shaping and similar tasks involved in land clearing, road building or maintenance.
897077_18_ITEM1_P51_S2	These products are available mounted on various types of undercarriages: wheels for full-speed highway travel, wheels for on/off road use, and crawlers.

897077_18_ITEM1_P53_S1	These units are powerful and versatile with uses including, but not limited to, removal of wet and dry debris, spill elimination, and cleaning of sludge beds.

Fairfield s offerings include custom municipal snow and ice removal equipment, a range of salt spreaders and truck bodies, street sweepers, a line of industrial rotary, flail and boom mowers, solid waste and recycling equipment, water and sewer maintenance equipment, municipal tractors and attachments, and asphalt maintenance patchers, some of which are sourced from other Alamo Group companies.

897077_18_ITEM1_P67_S1	Superior's customers are generally agricultural dealers who service owners and operators in the turf, golf, park and airport industries and growers with orchards, vineyards and plantations in Australia and the South Pacific.
897077_18_ITEM1_P68_S0	Herder and Santa Izabel give the Company a presence in the Brazilian agricultural market.
897077_18_ITEM1_P68_S1	With our recent acquisition of Santa Izabel, we have strengthened our market position in Brazil which allows us to further pursue organic growth and additional acquisitions.
897077_18_ITEM1_P69_S0	Herder manufactures and distributes flail mowers and various other agricultural equipment, direct and through dealers.
897077_18_ITEM1_P69_S1	Its products are used in a wide variety of agricultural and governmental markets.
897077_18_ITEM1_P70_S0	Santa Izabel designs, manufactures and markets a variety of agricultural implements, including trailers sold throughout Brazil.
897077_18_ITEM1_P71_S0	McConnel equipment principally includes a broad line of hydraulic, boom-mounted hedge and grass cutters, as well as other tractor attachments and implements such as hydraulic backhoes, cultivators, subsoilers, buckets and other digger implements and related replacement parts.
897077_18_ITEM1_P71_S1	McConnel equipment is sold primarily in the U.K., Ireland and France and in other parts of Europe and, to a lesser extent, throughout the world, through independent dealers and distributors.
897077_18_ITEM1_P72_S0	Bomford equipment includes hydraulic, boom-mounted hedge and hedgerow cutters, industrial grass mowers, agricultural seedbed preparation cultivators and related replacement parts.
897077_18_ITEM1_P72_S1	Bomford equipment is sold to governmental agencies, contractors and agricultural end-users in the U.K., Ireland and France and, to a lesser extent, other countries in Europe, North America, Australia and Asia.
897077_18_ITEM1_P72_S2	Bomford s sales network is similar to that of McConnel in the U.K.
897077_18_ITEM1_P73_S0	Spearhead manufactures a range of tractor-mounted vegetation maintenance equipment, including reach mowers, flail mowers and rotary cutters.
897077_18_ITEM1_P73_S1	These products are manufactured in the Company's Bomford facility.
897077_18_ITEM1_P73_S2	Kellands equipment which are being rebranded and sold as McConnel, includes a range of self-propelled sprayers and a variety of multi-drive load-carrying vehicles.
897077_18_ITEM1_P73_S3	These products are sold through an existing dealer network as well as various marketing groups within the European Division.
897077_18_ITEM1_P74_S0	SMA equipment includes hydraulic, boom-mounted hedge and hedgerow cutters and related replacement parts.
897077_18_ITEM1_P75_S0	SMA s principal customers are French local authorities.
897077_18_ITEM1_P76_S0	SMA s product offerings include certain quick-attach boom mowers manufactured by the Company in the U.K. to expand its presence in agricultural dealerships.
897077_18_ITEM1_P76_S1	The Company consolidated its SMA operations located in Orleans, France, and production was relocated to its manufacturing facility near Lyon, France.
897077_18_ITEM1_P77_S0	Forges Gorce manufactures cutting blades which are sold to some of the Company s subsidiaries as well as to other customers.
897077_18_ITEM1_P78_S0	Rousseau sells hydraulic and mechanical boom mowers, primarily in France, through its own sales force and dealer distribution network mainly to agricultural and governmental markets.
897077_18_ITEM1_P78_S1	These products have also been introduced into other markets outside of France.
897077_18_ITEM1_P79_S0	Rivard manufactures vacuum trucks, high pressure cleaning systems and trenchers.
897077_18_ITEM1_P79_S1	Rivard s equipment is sold primarily in France and certain other markets, mainly in Europe, the Middle East and North Africa, and to governmental entities and related contractors.
897077_18_ITEM1_P79_S2	It also complements our product offerings in North America.
897077_18_ITEM1_P80_S0	The majority of Rivard's customers provide their own truck chassis.
897077_18_ITEM1_P81_S0	Replacement Parts The Company derives a significant portion of its revenues from sales of replacement parts for each of its wholegoods lines.
897077_18_ITEM1_P81_S1	Replacement parts represented approximately 19% , 18% and 18% of the Company s total sales for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
897077_18_ITEM1_P81_S2	Proprietary replacement parts generally are more profitable and less cyclical than wholegoods.
897077_18_ITEM1_P82_S0	The Company s ability to provide innovative responses to customer needs, to develop and manufacture new products, and to enhance existing product lines is important to its success.
897077_18_ITEM1_P83_S0	The Company continually conducts research and development activities in an effort to improve existing products and develop new products.
897077_18_ITEM1_P83_S1	As of December 31, 2017 , the Company employed 186 people in its various engineering departments, 102 of whom are degreed engineers and the balance of whom are support staff.
897077_18_ITEM1_P83_S2	Amounts expended on research and development activities were approximately $ 9,849,000 in 2017 , $ 8,847,000 in 2016 and $ 8,590,000 in 2015 .
897077_18_ITEM1_P83_S3	As a percentage of sales, research and development was approximately 1.1% in 2017 , 1.0% in 2016 and 1.0% in 2015 , and is expected to continue at similar levels in 2018 .
897077_18_ITEM1_P84_S0	The Company s unit sales are fairly constant quarter to quarter.
897077_18_ITEM1_P84_S1	However, replacement parts are generally higher in the second and third quarters of the year, because a substantial number of the Company s products are used for maintenance activities such as vegetation maintenance, highway right-of-way maintenance, construction, and street and parking lot sweeping.
897077_18_ITEM1_P84_S2	Usage of this equipment is typically lower in harsh weather.
897077_18_ITEM1_P85_S0	The Company utilizes an annual twelve-month sales forecast provided by the Company s marketing departments which is updated quarterly in order to develop a production plan for its manufacturing facilities.
897077_18_ITEM1_P85_S1	In addition, many of the Company s marketing departments attempt to equalize demand for products throughout the calendar year by offering seasonal sales programs which may provide additional incentives, including discounts and extended payment terms.
897077_18_ITEM1_P86_S0	The Company s products are sold in highly competitive markets throughout the world.
897077_18_ITEM1_P86_S1	The principal competitive factors are price, quality, availability, service and reputation.
897077_18_ITEM1_P86_S2	The Company competes with several large national and international companies that offer a broad range of equipment and replacement parts, as well as with numerous small, privately-held manufacturers and suppliers of a limited number of products, mainly on a regional basis.
897077_18_ITEM1_P86_S3	Some of the Company s competitors are significantly larger than the Company and have substantially greater financial and other resources at their disposal.
897077_18_ITEM1_P86_S4	The Company believes that it is able to compete successfully in its markets by effectively managing its manufacturing costs, offering high quality products, developing and designing innovative products and, to some extent, avoiding direct competition with significantly larger potential competitors.
897077_18_ITEM1_P86_S5	There can be no assurance that the Company s competitors will not substantially increase the resources devoted to the development and marketing of products competitive with the Company s products or that new competitors with greater resources will not enter the Company s markets.
897077_18_ITEM1_P87_S0	As of December 31, 2017 , the Company had unfilled customer orders of $ 218,158,000 compared to $ 147,245,000 at December 31, 2016 .
897077_18_ITEM1_P87_S1	Management expects that substantially all of the Company s unfilled orders as of December 31, 2017 will be shipped during fiscal year 2018 .
897077_18_ITEM1_P87_S2	The amount of unfilled orders at a particular time is affected by a number of factors, including manufacturing and shipping schedules which, in most instances, are dependent on the Company s seasonal sales programs and the requirements of its customers.
897077_18_ITEM1_P87_S3	Certain of the Company s orders are subject to cancellation at any time before shipment; therefore, a comparison of unfilled orders from period to period is not necessarily meaningful and may not be indicative of future actual shipments.
897077_18_ITEM1_P88_S0	No single customer or group of customers is responsible for 10% or more of the aggregate revenue of the Company.
897077_18_ITEM1_P89_S0	The principal raw materials used by the Company include steel, other metal components, hydraulic hoses, paint and tires.
897077_18_ITEM1_P89_S1	During 2017 , the raw materials needed by the Company were available from a variety of sources in adequate quantities and at prevailing market prices.
897077_18_ITEM1_P90_S0	While the Company manufactures many of the parts for its products, a significant percentage of parts, including most drivelines, gearboxes, industrial engines, and hydraulic components, are purchased from outside suppliers which manufacture to the Company s specifications.
897077_18_ITEM1_P90_S1	In addition, the Company, through its subsidiaries, purchases tractors and truck chassis as a number of the Company s products are mounted and shipped with a tractor or truck chassis.

897077_18_ITEM1_P91_S1	No one supplier is responsible for supplying more than 10% of the principal raw materials or purchased goods used by the Company.

897077_18_ITEM1_P95_S0	The Company knows that its Indianola, Iowa property is contaminated with chromium which most likely resulted from chrome plating operations which were discontinued before the Company purchased the property.
897077_18_ITEM1_P95_S1	Chlorinated volatile organic compounds have also been detected in water samples on the property, though the source is unknown at this time.
897077_18_ITEM1_P95_S2	The Company voluntarily worked with an environmental consultant and the state of Iowa with respect to these issues and believes it completed its remediation program in June 2006.
897077_18_ITEM1_P95_S3	The work was accomplished within the Company s environmental liability reserve balance.
897077_18_ITEM1_P95_S4	We requested a no further action classification from the state.
897077_18_ITEM1_P95_S5	In January 2009, we received a "no further action" letter from the Iowa Department of Natural Resources, according to which the Iowa property will be subject to certain ongoing environmental covenants that create restrictions regarding the use and future development of the property.

897077_18_ITEM1A_P0_S0	You should carefully consider each of the risks described below, together with all of the other information contained in this Annual Report on Form 10-K, before making an investment decision with respect to the Company s securities.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P0_S1	If any of the following risks develop into actual events, the Company s business, financial condition or results from operations could be materially and adversely affected and you could lose all or part of your investment.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Deterioration of industry conditions could harm our business, results of operations and financial condition.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our business depends to a large extent upon the prospects for the mowing, right-of-way maintenance and agricultural markets in general.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Future prospects of the industry depend largely on factors outside of our control.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Any of those factors could adversely impact demand for our products, which could adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P3_S0	increase in unfunded pension plan liability due to financial market deterioration.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P4_S0	In addition, our business is susceptible to a number of factors that specifically affect agricultural customer spending patterns, including the following:
897077_18_ITEM1A_P5_S0	A downturn in general economic conditions and outlook in the United States and around the world could adversely affect our net sales and earnings.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The strength and profitability of our business depends on the overall demand for our products and upon economic conditions and outlook, including but not limited to economic growth rates; consumer spending levels; financing availability, pricing and terms for our dealers and end-users; employment rates; interest rates; inflation; consumer confidence and general economic and political conditions and expectations in the United States and the other economies in which we conduct business.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P7_S0	and end-user customers, increased unemployment rates, and recessionary economic conditions and outlook could cause consumers to reduce spending, which may cause them to delay or forgo purchases of our products and could have an adverse effect on our net sales and earnings.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The pending exit by the U.K. from the European Union ( Brexit ) and the impact of the withdrawal may adversely affect business activity, political stability and economic conditions in the U.K., the European Union and elsewhere.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P8_S1	The economic conditions and outlook could be further adversely affected by the uncertainty concerning the timing and terms of the exit and new or modified trading arrangements between the U.K. and other countries.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P8_S2	Any of these developments, or the perception that any of these developments are likely to occur, could negatively affect economic growth or business activity in the U.K., the European Union and elsewhere, and could materially and adversely affect our business and results of operations.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Changes in U.S. tax legislation could have a material adverse impact on our results of operations.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P10_S0	On December 22, 2017, President Trump signed into law legislation known as the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 ("TCJA") that significantly reforms the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P10_S1	We are currently evaluating provisions of TCJA, which among other things, lowers the U.S. corporate tax rate from 35% to 21%, moves the country towards a territorial tax system with a one-time mandatory tax on previously deferred foreign earnings of foreign subsidiaries, imposes significant additional limitations on the deductibility of interest expense and executive compensation, creates taxes such as the base erosion anti-abuse tax ( BEAT ) and Global Intangible Low Taxed Income ( GILTI ) tax, and allows for the expensing of certain capital expenditures.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P11_S0	As we do not have all the necessary information to analyze all income tax effects of TCJA, we have recorded a provisional amount which we believe represents a reasonable estimate of the accounting implications of TCJA.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P11_S1	We will continue to evaluate and adjust the provisional amounts as additional information is obtained.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P11_S2	We may not understand the full effect that this tax reform legislation will have on our business and it is possible that the impact of the legislation could adversely and materially impact our results of operations.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P11_S3	We expect to complete our detailed analysis no later than the fourth quarter of 2018.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P11_S4	For further information, see Note 12 to the consolidated financial statements.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P12_S0	We depend on governmental sales and a decrease in such sales could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P13_S0	A substantial portion of our revenues is derived from sales to federal, state and local governmental entities and related contractors, both in the U.S. and in other countries in which we sell our products.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P13_S1	These sales depend primarily on the levels of budgeted and appropriated expenditures for highway, airport, roadside and parks maintenance by various governmental entities and are affected by changes in local and national economic conditions.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Our dependence on, and the price and availability of, raw materials as well as purchased components may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We are subject to fluctuations in market prices for raw materials such as steel and energy.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P15_S1	In addition, although most of the raw materials and purchased components we use are commercially available from a number of sources, we could experience disruptions in the availability of such materials.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P15_S2	If we are unable to purchase materials we require or are unable to pass on price increases to our customers or otherwise reduce our cost of goods sold, our business, results of operations and financial condition may be adversely affected.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P15_S3	In addition, higher energy costs could negatively affect spending by farmers, including their purchases of our products.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Impairment in the carrying value of goodwill could negatively impact our consolidated results of operations and net worth.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P17_S0	The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units using a discounted cash flow analysis.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P17_S1	This analysis requires the Company to make significant assumptions and estimates about the extent and timing of future cash flows, discount rates and growth rates.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P17_S2	The cash flows are estimated over a significant future period of time, which makes those estimates and assumptions subject to an even higher degree of uncertainty.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P17_S3	The Company also utilizes market valuation models and other financial ratios, which require the Company to make certain assumptions and estimates regarding the applicability of those models to its assets and businesses.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P18_S0	As of December 31, 2017 , goodwill was $ 84,761,000 , which represents 13% of total assets.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P19_S0	The Company recognized no goodwill impairment in 2017 , 2016 or 2015 .
897077_18_ITEM1A_P19_S1	During the third quarter of 2015, the Company changed its annual goodwill and intangible assets impairment testing date from December 31 to October 1.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P19_S2	During the 2017 impairment analysis review, we performed a sensitivity analysis for goodwill impairment with respect to each of our reporting units and determined that a hypothetical 15% decline in the fair value of each reporting unit as of October 1, 2017 would not result in an impairment of goodwill for any of the reporting units.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P19_S3	If we were to have a significant goodwill impairment caused by a greater than a 15% decline in fair value, it could impact our results of operations as well as our net worth.

897077_18_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Changes in the European regulatory environment regarding privacy and data protection regulations could have a material adverse impact on our results of operations.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P24_S0	The EU has recently adopted a comprehensive overhaul of its data protection regime in the form of the General Data Protection Regulation ( GDPR ), which comes into effect in May of 2018.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P24_S1	GDPR extends the scope of the existing EU data protection law to foreign companies processing personal data of EU residents.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P24_S2	The regulation imposes a strict data protection compliance regime with severe penalties of 4% of worldwide turnover or 20 million, whichever is greater, and includes new rights such as the right of erasure of personal data.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P24_S3	Although the GDPR will apply across the EU, as has been the case under the current data protection regime, EU Member States have some national derogations and local data protection authorities ( DPAs ) will still have the ability to interpret the GDPR, which has the potential to create inconsistencies on a country-by-country basis.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Implementation of, and compliance with the GDPR could increase our cost of doing business and/or force us to change our business practices in a manner adverse to our business.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P25_S1	In addition, violations of the GDPR may result in significant fines, penalties and damage to our brand and business which could, individually or in the aggregate, materially harm our business and reputation.

897077_18_ITEM1A_P42_S0	The agricultural industry and the infrastructure maintenance industry are seasonal and are affected by the weather, and seasonal fluctuations may cause our results of operations and working capital to fluctuate from quarter to quarter.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P43_S0	In general, agricultural and governmental end-users typically purchase new equipment during the first and second calendar quarters.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P43_S1	Other products such as street sweepers, excavators, snow removal equipment, front-end loaders and pothole patchers have different seasonal patterns, as do replacement parts in general.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P43_S2	In attempting to achieve efficient utilization of manpower and facilities throughout the year, we estimate seasonal demand months in advance and manufacturing capacity is scheduled in anticipation of such demand.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P43_S3	We utilize an annual plan with updated quarterly sales forecasts provided by our marketing divisions and order backlog in order to develop a production plan for our manufacturing facilities.
897077_18_ITEM1A_P43_S4	In addition, many of our marketing departments attempt to equalize demand for their products throughout the calendar year by offering seasonal sales programs which may provide additional incentives, including discounts and extended payment terms, on equipment that is ordered during off-season periods.

897077_18_ITEM7_P0_S0	This report contains forward-looking statements that are based on Alamo Group s current expectations.
897077_18_ITEM7_P0_S1	Actual results in future periods may differ materially from those expressed or implied because of a number of risks and uncertainties which are discussed below and in the Forward-Looking Information section beginning on page 11.
897077_18_ITEM7_P1_S0	In 2017 we experienced several market factors that helped drive positive results in our business including, among other things, strengthening agricultural markets, improving non-governmental sales and rentals of vacuum truck equipment, a strengthening European market and a softening U.S. dollar.
897077_18_ITEM7_P1_S1	While the Company believes that these market forces are showing some signs of stability for 2018, we remain cautious in terms of our outlook since market conditions can and do change regularly.
897077_18_ITEM7_P1_S2	As a result of overall improving market conditions our backlog substantially increased during the course of 2017 and, as of December 31, 2017, was in excess of $218 million.
897077_18_ITEM7_P1_S3	While this level of backlog is encouraging, the potential effect this level of demand will have on our production lead times has given us some cause for concern.
897077_18_ITEM7_P1_S4	As a response to this concern, in 2018 we are increasing our focus on ongoing operational improvement initiatives and will likely increase our capital expenditure levels above the average capital expenditure levels of the past several years.
897077_18_ITEM7_P1_S5	We also expect that inflation pressures may be more of a negative factor in 2018 as labor availability tightens and some commodity prices, such as the price of steel, increase.
897077_18_ITEM7_P1_S6	We may also be negatively affected by several other unanticipated factors such as a weakness in the overall economy; significant changes in currency exchange rates; changes in trade policy, increased levels of government regulations; weakness in the agricultural sector; acquisition integration issues; budget constraints or revenue shortfalls in governmental entities; and other risks and uncertainties as described in Risk Factors.

897077_18_ITEM7_P29_S6	Consequently, the Company now intends to repatriate foreign cash and cash equivalents in excess of amounts needed to fund foreign operating and investing activities.

897077_18_ITEM7_P37_S0	In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606), which supersedes the revenue recognition requirements in Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") Topic 605, Revenue Recognition, and most industry-specific guidance and clarifies the principles for recognizing revenue.
897077_18_ITEM7_P37_S1	This ASU is based on the principle that revenue is recognized to depict the transfer of goods or services to customers in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.
897077_18_ITEM7_P37_S2	The ASU also requires additional disclosure about the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from customer contracts, including significant judgments and changes in judgments, and assets recognized from costs incurred to obtain or fulfill a contract.
897077_18_ITEM7_P38_S0	This new standard is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim reporting periods within those annual periods.
897077_18_ITEM7_P38_S1	We have completed our evaluation of the provisions of this standard and concluded that our adoption will not change the amount or timing of revenue recognized by us, nor will it affect our financial position.
897077_18_ITEM7_P38_S2	Revenue from contracts with customers are recognized at the point we satisfy our performance obligation.
897077_18_ITEM7_P38_S3	Revenue is measured as the amount of consideration we expect to receive in exchange for providing the service.
897077_18_ITEM7_P39_S0	We will adopt this new standard effective January 1, 2018 using the modified retrospective method of adoption as permitted by the standard.
897077_18_ITEM7_P39_S1	Under this method, the cumulative effect of initially applying the standard is recognized as an adjustment to the opening balance of stockholders equity, and revenues reported in the periods prior to the date of adoption are not changed.
897077_18_ITEM7_P39_S2	We will not, however, make such an adjustment to stockholder s equity as result of our evaluation.
897077_18_ITEM7_P39_S3	The adoption of Topic 606 will not have a material impact on our financial position, results of operations, stockholders equity or cash flows.
897077_18_ITEM7_P40_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02, Leases.
897077_18_ITEM7_P40_S1	This update requires that a lessee recognize in the statement of financial position a liability to make lease payments and a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset for the lease term.
897077_18_ITEM7_P40_S2	For leases with a term of 12 months or less, a lessee is permitted to make an accounting policy election by class of underlying asset not to recognize lease assets and lease liabilities.
897077_18_ITEM7_P40_S3	Similar to current guidance, the update continues to differentiate between finance leases and operating leases, however this distinction now primarily relates to differences in the manner of expense recognition over time and in the classification of lease payments in the statement of cash flows.
897077_18_ITEM7_P40_S4	The updated guidance leaves the accounting for leases by lessors largely unchanged from existing GAAP.
897077_18_ITEM7_P41_S0	Entities are required to use a modified retrospective adoption, with certain relief provisions, for leases that exist or are entered into after the beginning of the earliest comparative period in the financial statements when adopted.
897077_18_ITEM7_P41_S1	The guidance will become effective for us on January 1, 2019.
897077_18_ITEM7_P42_S0	The impacts that adoption of the ASU is expected to have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures are being evaluated.
897077_18_ITEM7_P42_S1	Additionally, we have not yet determined the effect of the ASU on our internal control over financial reporting or other changes in business practices and processes.
897077_18_ITEM7_P43_S0	In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-13, Financial Instruments - Credit Losses, to improve information on credit losses for financial instruments.
897077_18_ITEM7_P43_S1	The ASU replaces the current incurred loss impairment methodology with a methodology that reflects expected credit losses.
897077_18_ITEM7_P43_S2	The ASU is effective for the Company for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019, including interim periods within those fiscal years.
897077_18_ITEM7_P43_S3	Early adoption is permitted beginning in fiscal years beginning after December 18, 2018.
897077_18_ITEM7_P43_S4	The Company has not yet evaluated the effect the adoption of this ASU will have on its consolidated financial statements.
897077_18_ITEM7_P44_S0	In March 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017-07 Improving the Presentation of Net Periodic Pension Cost and Net Periodic Post-retirement Benefit Cost to provide income statement classification guidance for components of the net benefit cost.
897077_18_ITEM7_P44_S1	The ASU requires entities to disaggregate the current-service-cost component from the other components of net benefit cost (the other components ) and present it with other current compensation costs for related employees in the income statement.
897077_18_ITEM7_P44_S2	Furthermore, entities should present the other components elsewhere in the income statement and outside of income from operations if such a subtotal is presented.
897077_18_ITEM7_P45_S0	The ASU is to be adopted retrospectively and is effective for the Company for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017, including interim periods within those fiscal years and may be early adopted.

897077_18_ITEM7_P50_S0	Definitions: (A) Long-term debt obligation means a principal payment obligation under long-term borrowings.
897077_18_ITEM7_P50_S1	(B) Interest obligation represents interest due on long-term debt and capital lease obligations.
