897077_18_ITEM7_P52_S0	Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations are based upon our Consolidated Financial Statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ( GAAP ).
897077_18_ITEM7_P52_S1	The preparation of these financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
897077_18_ITEM7_P52_S2	Management bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
897077_18_ITEM7_P52_S3	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
897077_18_ITEM7_P53_S0	An accounting policy is deemed to be critical if it requires an accounting estimate to be made based on assumptions about matters that are highly uncertain at the time the estimate is made, and if different estimates that reasonably could have been used, or changes in the accounting estimates that are reasonably likely to occur periodically, could materially impact the financial statements.
897077_18_ITEM7_P54_S0	For further information on the critical accounting policies, see Note 1 of our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
897077_18_ITEM7_P55_S0	Business acquisitions are accounted for by the acquisition method of accounting.
897077_18_ITEM7_P55_S1	Under this method, the purchase price is allocated to the assets acquired and the liabilities assumed based on the fair value at the time of the acquisition.
897077_18_ITEM7_P55_S2	Any excess purchase price over the fair value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed is recorded as goodwill.
897077_18_ITEM7_P56_S0	We believe the fair values assigned to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed are based on reasonable assumptions; however, these assumptions may be incomplete or inaccurate, and unanticipated events and circumstances may occur.
897077_18_ITEM7_P57_S0	Tangible assets are typically valued using a replacement or reproduction cost approach, considering factors such as current prices of the same or similar equipment, the age of the equipment, and economic obsolescence.
897077_18_ITEM7_P58_S0	In making other assumptions on valuation and useful lives, we considered the unique nature of the acquisition and we utilized a third-party valuation firm to assist us in the valuation of the acquired intangibles and the resulting allocation of purchase price for the acquisition.
897077_18_ITEM7_P59_S0	On December 31, 2017 , the Company had $ 15,652,000 in reserves for sales discounts compared to $ 13,488,000 on December 31, 2016 on product shipped to our customers under various promotional programs.
897077_18_ITEM7_P59_S1	The Company reviews the reserve quarterly based on analysis made on each program outstanding at the time.
897077_18_ITEM7_P60_S0	The Company bases its reserves on historical data relating to discounts taken by the customer under each program.
897077_18_ITEM7_P60_S1	Historically, between 85% and 95% of the Company s customers who qualify for each program actually take the discount that is available.
897077_18_ITEM7_P61_S0	The Company had a reserve of $ 6,932,000 on December 31, 2017 and $ 7,262,000 on December 31, 2016 to cover obsolete and slow moving inventory.
897077_18_ITEM7_P61_S1	The decrease in the reserve was primarily attributable to reductions of obsolete inventory in the Company's Industrial Division.
897077_18_ITEM7_P61_S2	The obsolete and slow moving inventory policy states that the reserve is to be calculated as follows: 1) no inventory usage over a three-year period is deemed obsolete and reserved at 100 percent; and 2) slow moving inventory with little usage requires a 100 percent reserve on items that have a quantity greater than a three-year supply.
897077_18_ITEM7_P61_S3	There are exceptions to the obsolete and slow moving classifications if approved by an officer of the Company, based on specific identification of an item or items that are deemed to be either included or excluded from this classification.
897077_18_ITEM7_P61_S4	In cases where there is no historical data, management makes a judgment based on a specific review of the inventory in question to determine what reserves, if any, are appropriate.
897077_18_ITEM7_P61_S5	New products or parts are generally excluded from the reserve policy until a three-year history has been established.
897077_18_ITEM7_P62_S0	The reserve is reviewed and, if necessary, adjustments are made on a quarterly basis.
897077_18_ITEM7_P62_S1	The Company relies on historical information when available to support its reserve.
897077_18_ITEM7_P62_S2	The Company does not adjust the reserve balance until the inventory is liquidated.
897077_18_ITEM7_P63_S0	The Company s warranty policy is generally to provide its customers warranty for up to one year on all wholegood divisions and 90 days on parts, though some components can have warranty for longer terms.
897077_18_ITEM7_P64_S0	Warranty reserve, as a percentage of sales, is generally calculated by looking at the current twelve months expenses and prorating that amount based on twelve months sales with a ninety-day to six-month lag period.
897077_18_ITEM7_P64_S1	The Company s historical experience is that an end-user takes approximately 90 days to six months from the receipt of the division to file a warranty claim.
897077_18_ITEM7_P64_S2	A warranty reserve is established for each different marketing group.
897077_18_ITEM7_P64_S3	Reserve balances are evaluated on a quarterly basis and adjustments made when required.
897077_18_ITEM7_P65_S0	The current liability warranty reserve balance was $ 5,335,000 on December 31, 2017 and $ 5,262,000 on December 31, 2016 .
897077_18_ITEM7_P66_S0	Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price of acquired businesses over the estimated fair value of the identifiable net assets acquired.
897077_18_ITEM7_P66_S1	Goodwill is not amortized but is tested at least annually for impairment at the reporting unit level.
897077_18_ITEM7_P66_S2	Definite-lived intangible assets are also tested for impairment at the reporting unit level whenever events or circumstances make it likely that an impairment may have occurred.
897077_18_ITEM7_P67_S0	Reporting units are operating segments or components of operating segments for which discrete financial information is available.
897077_18_ITEM7_P67_S1	To evaluate goodwill, the fair value of each reporting unit is compared to its carrying value.
897077_18_ITEM7_P67_S2	Where the carrying value is greater than the fair value, the implied fair value of the reporting unit goodwill is determined by allocating the fair value of the reporting unit to all the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit with any remainder being allocated to goodwill.
897077_18_ITEM7_P67_S3	The implied fair value of the reporting unit goodwill is then compared to the carrying value of that goodwill to determine whether an impairment loss exists.
897077_18_ITEM7_P67_S4	Any impairment loss is recognized in earnings.
897077_18_ITEM7_P68_S0	We typically measure the fair value of each reporting unit using a discounted cash flow analysis (income approach) based on assumptions that market participants would apply.
897077_18_ITEM7_P68_S1	Because the business is assumed to continue in perpetuity, the discounted cash flows include a terminal value.
897077_18_ITEM7_P68_S2	Cash flows to perpetuity are forecast based on projected revenue growth and our planned business strategies in future periods.
897077_18_ITEM7_P68_S3	Examples of planned strategies would include a plant or line expansion at an existing facility; a reduction of working capital at a specific location; and price increases or cost reductions within a reporting unit.
897077_18_ITEM7_P69_S0	The discount rate is based on a reporting unit s targeted weighted-average cost of capital, which is not necessarily the same as our weighted-average cost of capital.
897077_18_ITEM7_P70_S0	We perform our annual test for goodwill impairment in the fourth quarter of each fiscal year.
897077_18_ITEM7_P70_S1	In 2017 a qualitative testing was performed and the Company determined there was no goodwill impairment related to our reporting units.
897077_18_ITEM7_P70_S2	During 2016 and 2015 , we determined that none of the goodwill associated with our reporting units were impaired in any of those years which was based on the quantitative testing.
897077_18_ITEM7_P70_S3	These reporting units would be most likely affected by changes in the Company s assumptions and estimates.
897077_18_ITEM7_P70_S4	The calculation of fair value could increase or decrease depending on changes in the inputs and assumptions used, such as changes in the reporting unit s future growth rates, discount rates, etc.
897077_18_ITEM7_P70_S5	These assumptions and projections underlying the fair value estimates are subject to change and are impacted by our ability to achieve our forecasts and by economic conditions that may impact future results and result in projections not being attained.
897077_18_ITEM7_P70_S6	A change in any of these estimates and assumptions could produce a different fair value, which could have a material impact on our results of operations.
897077_18_ITEM7_P71_S0	Each year we re-evaluate the assumptions used to reflect changes in the business environment.
897077_18_ITEM7_P72_S0	No. 118, Income Tax Accounting Implications of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, issued by the SEC.
897077_18_ITEM7_P72_S1	As a result, we will record the effect in 2018 for items where we were unable to make a reasonable estimate in 2017, and we may revise estimates that we recorded in 2017.
897077_18_ITEM7_P72_S2	See Note 12 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for a further discussion of our tax liabilities and the impact from Tax Reform on those liabilities.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P0_S0	The Company is exposed to various financial market risks.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Market risk is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in market prices and rates.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The Company does not enter into derivative or other financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P2_S0	A portion of the Company s operations consists of manufacturing and sales activities in international jurisdictions.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P2_S1	The Company manufactures its products primarily in the United States, the U.K., France, Canada, Brazil and Australia.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P2_S2	The Company sells its products primarily within the markets where the products are produced, but certain of the Company s sales from its U.K. and Canadian operations are denominated in other currencies.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P2_S3	As a result, the Company s financials, specifically the value of its foreign assets, could be affected by factors such as changes in foreign currency exchange rates in the U.K. and Canada or weak economic conditions in the other markets in which the subsidiaries of the Company distribute their products.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P3_S0	To mitigate the short-term effect of changes in currency exchange rates on the Company s functional currency-based sales, the Company s U.K. and Canadian subsidiaries regularly enter into foreign exchange contracts for over 90% of their future net foreign currency cash receipts over a period of six months.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P3_S1	As of December 31, 2017 , the Company had a notional amount of $ 1,142,000 in outstanding forward exchange contracts related to accounts receivable.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P3_S2	A 15% fluctuation in exchange rates for these currencies would change the fair value by approximately $ 171,000 .
897077_18_ITEM7A_P3_S3	However, since these contracts offset foreign currency denominated transactions, any change in the fair value of the contracts should be offset by changes in the underlying value of the transaction.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The Company s earnings are affected by fluctuations in the value of the U.S. dollar as compared to foreign currencies, predominantly in European countries and Canada and, to a lesser extent, Australia and Brazil, as a result of the sale of its products in international markets.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P4_S1	Foreign currency forward exchange contracts in the U.K. are used to offset the earnings effects of such fluctuations.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P4_S2	On December 31, 2017 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have been a decrease in gross profit of $ 6,564,000 .
897077_18_ITEM7A_P4_S3	Comparatively, on December 31, 2016 , the result of a uniform 10% strengthening in the value of the dollar relative to the currencies in which the Company s sales are denominated would have been a decrease in gross profit of approximately $ 5,755,000 .
897077_18_ITEM7A_P5_S0	This calculation assumes that each exchange rate would change in the same direction relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P5_S1	In addition to the direct effects of changes in exchange rates, which are a changed dollar value of the resulting sales, changes in exchange rates may also affect the volume of sales or the foreign currency sales price as competitors products become more or less attractive.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P5_S2	The Company s sensitivity analysis of the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates does not factor in a potential change in sales levels or local currency prices.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P5_S3	The translation adjustment during 2017 was a gain of $16,966,000 .
897077_18_ITEM7A_P5_S4	On December 31, 2017 , the British pound closed at 0.7400 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.8331 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P5_S5	By comparison, on December 31, 2016 , the British pound closed at 0.8100 relative to the U.S. dollar, and the Euro closed at 0.9506 relative to the U.S. dollar.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P5_S6	No assurance can be given as to future valuation of the British pound or Euro or how further movements in those or other currencies could affect future earnings or the financial position of the Company.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P6_S0	Interest Rate Risk The majority of the Company s long-term debt bears interest at variable rates.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P6_S1	Accordingly, the Company s net income is affected by changes in interest rates.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P6_S2	Assuming the average level of borrowings at variable rates and a two hundred basis point change in the 2017 average interest rate under these borrowings, the Company s 2017 interest expense would have changed by approximately $ 2,535,000 .
897077_18_ITEM7A_P7_S0	In the event of an adverse change in interest rates, management could take actions to mitigate its exposure.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P7_S1	Further, this analysis does not consider the effects of the change in the level of overall economic activity that could exist in such an environment.
897077_18_ITEM7A_P7_S2	However, challenges affecting the banking industry and credit markets in general can potentially cause changes to credit availability and cost of borrowing, which creates a level of uncertainty.

897077_18_ITEM9B_P0_S1	Executive Incentive Plan (the Plan ) under which executive officers and other employees will be eligible to receive annual cash incentive awards based on the achievement of objective and subjective performance goals for performance periods commencing on or after January 1, 2018 was approved by the Board of Directors on March 1, 2018.
897077_18_ITEM9B_P0_S2	The Plan is similar to the Executive Incentive Plan approved by the Board of Directors on March 7, 2013 and approved by the stockholders of the Company at the Company s 2013 annual meeting of shareholders, but it has been modified as a result of recent changes in U.S. federal tax law.
897077_18_ITEM9B_P1_S0	The purpose of the Plan is to retain and motivate officers and other employees of the Company who are designated by the Company to participate in the Plan for a specified performance period commencing on or after January 1, 2018 (a Performance Period ) by providing such designated officers and employees with the opportunity to earn incentive payments based upon the extent to which specified performance goals have been achieved or exceeded for that Performance Period.
897077_18_ITEM9B_P1_S1	The following is a brief summary of some of the material terms of the Plan:
897077_18_ITEM9B_P2_S0	All officers of the Company and its subsidiaries are eligible to be designated for participation in the Plan.
897077_18_ITEM9B_P2_S1	The Compensation Committee will designate the eligible employees who will participate in the Plan for a specified Performance Period, and will do so not later than 90 days after the beginning of the Performance Period or, if earlier, the date on which 25% of the Performance Period has been completed (the Applicable Period ).
897077_18_ITEM9B_P2_S2	Under the Plan, payment awards to participating employees are subject to the attainment of specific performance goals and other terms and conditions established by the Compensation Committee for each Performance Period during the Applicable Period.
897077_18_ITEM9B_P2_S3	A participant may receive an award under the Plan based upon the achievement of stated subjective performance measures or the achievement of stated performance goals using one or more objective corporate-wide or subsidiary, division, operating unit or individual measures.
897077_18_ITEM9B_P3_S0	interest and taxes ( EBIT earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization ( EBITDA earnings as determined other than in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles ( GAAP stock price; price per share of common stock; market share; economic value; financial return ratios, consisting of return on invested capital, return on assets, debt to total capital, return on stockholders' equity, and return on sales; the ratio of EBIT to capital; the ratio of EBITDA to capital; net income; adjusted net income; operating income; revenues; profit margin; cash flow(s); expense reduction; working capital ratios; achievement of balance sheet or income statement objectives; inventory reductions; inventory turns; successful implementation of strategic initiatives; customer satisfaction measures; and successful integration of acquisitions.
897077_18_ITEM9B_P3_S1	Each such goal may be expressed on an absolute or relative basis and may include comparisons based on current internal targets, the past performance of the Company (including the performance of one or more subsidiaries, divisions, or operating units) or the past or current performance of other companies (or a combination of such past and current performance).
897077_18_ITEM9B_P4_S0	In the case of earnings-based measures, in addition to the ratios specifically enumerated above, performance goals may include comparisons relating to capital (including, but not limited to, the cost of capital).
897077_18_ITEM9B_P4_S1	If the relevant performance goals are attained during the Performance Period, a participant will be eligible to receive a cash award.
897077_18_ITEM9B_P5_S0	Determination of the performance compensation awarded to each participant is to be made at a time determined by the Compensation Committee after the last day of each Performance Period.
897077_18_ITEM9B_P5_S1	During the Applicable Period, the Compensation Committee will establish terms regarding the timing of the payment awards.
897077_18_ITEM9B_P5_S2	The Compensation Committee may delegate its responsibilities under the Plan to our chief executive officer or such other executive officer of the Company as it deems appropriate, except that the Compensation Committee may not delegate its responsibilities with respect to the bonuses payable to covered employees as such term is defined under Section 162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended.
897077_18_ITEM9B_P5_S3	The Board of Directors may terminate the Plan at any time.
